headline: Paid Notice: Deaths LARSON, RUTH MARIE
summary: LARSON--Ruth Marie. Passed away on August 23, 2012, at 76 years of age, at home in Berkeley, CA, USA with her husband and family and caregivers, after a long and difficult illness with Parkinson's Disease, and having received the Sacrament of Anointing of the Sick by Fr. Bruno Gibson, OP. Surviving are her husband Ronald, and her children Christopher, Peter and Hans, her brother Harris Steiner, her daughters-in-law: Mary, Jennifer, and Anessa, her beloved grandchildren Katharine, Eric and Soren, Alexandra Ruth (in utero), and her nieces Laura Durbahn of Kerman, CA, Cynthia Ganz of Seattle, Elise Winter of Loomis, CA., nephew Carl Steiner of San Diego, and grandnieces and grandnephews. Ruth will be greatly missed by her dear friends: sorority sister and fellow teacher Celia Gunn Ginnado of Arlington Heights, Ill., Sra. Imelda Espiritu of Berkeley, and Christina Ahengua of Richmond. And also her classmates and friends from The Sigma Kappa sorority at UC Berkeley, and her classmates from Kerman HS., the parishioners and teachers at School of the Madeleine, and at St. Mary's College HS. A proud native of California, she was born at St. Agnes Hospital in Fresno. She graduated from Kerman HS with honors, Cheerleader, Girls Athletic Association and Tennis Team letters, International Quill and Scroll Society for Journalism, and a California Scholarship Federation (CSF) Member. The daughter of Thelma Harris Steiner, a California school teacher, and Rene Steiner, a Kerman raisin grower and RFD mailman. Ruth was a member of the The Order of Rainbow for Girls, and a California Raisin Queen. She was a 5-year 4H Achievement Award winner. Following her brother Harris's example, Ruth matriculated at UC Berkeley in 1953 and joined the Sigma Kappa sorority. Walking to class one day in her first year, she met her husband-to-be, and they began an odyssey for life. Ruth as: teacher, then through the active years of raising her boys, as an interior designer and her designs include offices and living areas for the Christian Brothers-De La Salle Institute Winery (her leaded glass door panels bearing the CB seal are still in use at the Sutter Home Winery in St. Helena, CA.) For nearly six years she was national sale representative for her partnership in the Abundance Winery in Sonoma. In the latter role she was thrilled to encounter a former member of her son's class at the Madeleine - he was a competitor salesman at a dealer in Chicago. He afterward joked of losing that sale, as it was unfair to have to compete against "a Mom with all that charm." Meantime, she completed her studies at UC, graduating BA as an UC Alumni Scholar in the same ceremony with Ron gaining his JD. Now all of the Larsons were Cal Bears. Ruth was active in the School of the Madeleine at their family parish: re-founding the Bridge Club, leading the Cub's Scouts, and singing in Father Larry's choir. The boys went on to the St. Mary's College High School where she helped the Brothers of the Christian Schools, Eunice Jackson and other mothers, found the Belles of St. Mary's as a scholarship organization for the school. She didn't know "slow." She spent her days and nights teaching, counseling, feeding and loving her family, gardening, playing the piano at midnite home sessions, dancing at the Parish parties, traveling with Ron, skiing with the boys, and as a member of the Art Deco Society of San Francisco. Always a lady: raised by her Convent trained mother, she was initiated in 1953, by her new friend on Milvia Street, Pat Sager, to wear gloves and scarf and hat and take lunch at the City of Paris. A propriety she must have been one of the last to relinquish. But she wore her scarves and gloves until the day she died. All Services will be at the St. Mary Magdalen Catholic Church 2005 Berryman St, Berkeley, California 94709 (510-526-4811) as follows: Thursday, September 6th at 7PM - The Holy Rosary of the Virgin Mary; Friday, September 7th at 10:30AM - Mass - followed immediately by reception and refreshments in Norton Hall (directly under the Church - entry from the parking lot). Private interment services are pending. SUNSET VIEW MORTUARY Telephone (510) 525-5111

headline: What's On Today
summary: 10 P.M. (BBC America) MISTRESSES This soap opera about four women in Bristol, England, balancing friendship and extramarital intrigue, left American viewers dangling when Season 2 wrapped in May 2009. Now it returns for a four-episode finale. When last we saw the girlfriends, Katie (Sarah Parish), the doctor who helped her terminally ill married lover commit suicide in Season 1 (and then went on to have an affair with his son and then with an old, also-married flame), was about to find out if her latest beau would sweep her off to Australia in an act of forgiveness. Trudi (Sharon Small), who thought her husband had died in the terror attacks of Sept. 11 and discovered that he was in fact still alive, had gotten married to a man who also wasn't what he seemed. Jessica (Shelley Conn, above), a pregnant event planner in an open marriage, learned that her spouse had decided to be monogamous. Or so he said. And Siobhan (Orla Brady) was relegated to single-mother status after struggling with infertility in her marriage, then getting pregnant by a colleague -- which sent her husband packing. In this Season 3 premiere the women are summoned to Katie's house, where their icy demeanor suggests that they are friends no more. Joanna Lumley joins the cast as Vivienne, Katie's imperious mother. 1 P.M. (HBO Signature) SOMETHING'S GOTTA GIVE (2003) In this double bill from the director Nancy Meyers, a music executive in his 60s (Jack Nicholson) with a fondness for young women finds the rug pulled out from under him when he falls for the mother (Diane Keaton, above) of a woman he's dating (Amanda Peet). Writing in The New York Times, A. O. Scott said that Mr. Nicholson and Ms. Keaton sparred ''with the freedom of professionals with nothing left to prove, and Mr. Nicholson has the gentlemanly grace to step aside and let Ms. Keaton claim the movie.'' He added, ''She in turn brings out the best in everyone around her.'' At 3:15, in ''It's Complicated,'' Meryl Streep plays Jane Adler, a successful California restaurateur who is about to settle into life as an empty nester when she is blindsided by advances from her ex-husband (Alec Baldwin), who had left her a decade earlier for a pretty young thing (Lake Bell). Steve Martin is thrown into the mix as the architect overseeing the renovation of Jane's house, and he is not without his own charms. The truth, Manohla Dargis wrote in The Times, is ''that everyone needs a little coddling, which could be the key to Ms. Meyers's peculiar talent: She pampers her audience shamelessly.''

headline: Sherman Hemsley, Star Of 'Jeffersons,' Dies at 74
summary: Sherman Hemsley, the bantamweight comic actor who portrayed the scrappy, nouveau riche George Jefferson on the hit CBS sitcom ''The Jeffersons,'' died on Tuesday at his home in El Paso. He was 74. His death was confirmed by his agent, Todd Frank. He did not specify a cause.

headline: Republicans Warn of Inaction on Syria
summary: WASHINGTON — Republicans on Capitol Hill took President Obama to task Sunday for what they characterized as dangerous inaction in Syria, while Democrats urged the White House to step up its humanitarian response to the two-year-old civil war that has killed 70,000 people and displaced hundreds of thousands more. The lawmakers’ comments came after revelations last week that the Syrian president, Bashar al-Assad, is believed to have used chemical weapons against his own people. On Sunday, several leading Republicans — including Senators Lindsey Graham of South Carolina and John McCain of Arizona, both of whom are members of the Armed Services Committee — used appearances on television talk shows to warn that failure to intervene in Syria would embolden nations like Iran and North Korea.

headline: Op-Ed Contributor: For God So Loved The 1 Percent ...
summary: Princeton, N.J. IN recent weeks Mitt Romney has become the poster child for unchecked capitalism, a role he seems to embrace with relish. Concerns about economic equality, he told Matt Lauer of NBC, were really about class warfare.

headline: Ready for More? The Next Hurdle
summary: After a memorable opening weekend in the N.C.A.A. tournament, the Round of 16 this week will feature an eclectic mix: the brand names, the underdogs, the overlooked and the never-saw-it-coming. All eyes will turn again to Florida Gulf Coast, which became the first No. 15 seed to reach the Round of 16 with its 81-71 victory over San Diego State on Sunday night. The Eagles have come out of nowhere as this year’s tournament darling, but they proved they are not a one-hit wonder. They have outscored their two opponents by 20 while shooting 49.5 percent.

headline: Jets (1-0) at Steelers (0-1)
summary: 4:25 p.m. Eastern, CBS Matchup to Watch

headline: Esther Kartiganer, 74, a Force As a '60 Minutes' Producer
summary: Esther Kartiganer, who as senior producer in charge of vetting content on CBS's ''60 Minutes'' became entangled in a controversy over a program that raised questions about President George W. Bush's military service during the Vietnam War, died on Wednesday in Aspen, Colo. She was 74. The cause was a heart attack, said her brother, Joseph.

headline: Paid Notice: Deaths WRIGHT, WILLIAM
summary: WRIGHT--William. A former publishing executive who is credited with helping to revive the industry in the 1990s, died on February 26, 2012 surrounded by family at his home in Zionsville, Ind. He was 62 years old. The cause was complications from ocular melanoma, a rare cancer, his daughter Diana said. His strong and loving character, wisdom and generosity will be missed by all. Mr. Wright had a reputation in the publishing industry as a strong motivational leader. He left the Chief Operating Officer post at Random House Inc, to serve as President and CEO of the Hearst Book Group in 1995 after the publisher fell into tumult when many of its top authors and editors defected. Mr. Wright streamlined costs and grew the business by attracting new editorial talent. He published numerous bestselling books from authors as diverse as Pope John Paul II, President George H. W. Bush, Sidney Sheldon and Whoopi Goldberg. Mr. Wright was dedicated to promoting the publishing industry and serving his community. He was a past Chairman of New York is Book Country and was a board member of the Association of American Publishers from 1996 to 1998. While at the helm of Hearst Book Group he was a strong advocate for Literacy Volunteers, a statewide network of community-based volunteer services that exists to foster and strengthen literate communities throughout New York. His community service continued during his retirement. He served as a volunteer for Child Advocates of Indiana, an organization that intervenes on behalf of abused and neglected children. Prior to joining Random House in 1992, Wright was Senior Vice President of Bantam Doubleday Dell Publishing Group. Before that he was Senior Vice President of CBS Educational and Professional Publishing. He joined CBS in 1980 as Director of Distribution and went on to hold several positions of increasing responsibility. Mr. Wright held a B.S. in Economics from Villanova University (1972) and an M.B.A from Temple University (1973). Bill received a scholorship to play basketball at Villanova but later relinquished his scholarship to focus on the arrival of his first child. "Despite his pressing job and community service responsibilities, Bill remained close to his children and remarked in his final hours that their success and happiness as adults was his proudest accomplishment," remarked Patricia Reber, his beloved longtime executive assistant. Mr. Wright is survived by his second wife Chandra of Zionsville, IN, his daughter Diana Wright Milkowski and her husband Matt Milkowski of Rumson, NJ and his son Jason Wright of Manhattan. He is also survived by grandchildren Kevin, Jake, Lyla and Mia and stepchildren Brittany, Charles and Corttany. There will be a memorial service at Assumption Church in Fairfield, CT on Friday, March 9, 2012 at 2pm. In lieu of flowers, memorial donations may be made to the Opportunity Network, 55 Exchange Place, Suite 503, New York, NY 10005 or online at opportunitynetwork.org.

headline: What's On Sunday
summary: 9 P.M. (ABC) DESPERATE HOUSEWIVES The ladies who scheme and lunch wrap up loose ends as the series comes to a close. Bree's lawyer, Trip (Scott Bakula), begs her to tell him what really happened the night of Alejandro's murder when it looks as if she were about to be convicted. Gaby (Eva Longoria) tries to come up with a way to take the burden off Bree (Marcia Cross, above with Mr. Bakula). Susan (Teri Hatcher) works to conceal the sale of her house until she can break the news to her neighbors; Katherine Mayfair (Dana Delany) returns to Wisteria Lane with a job offer for Lynette (Felicity Huffman) -- one that could end her chances of reconciliation with Tom (Doug Savant). Renee (Vanessa Williams) reaches the end of her rope when Ben (Charles Mesure) is arrested before their wedding. And all the women agree to take care of Mrs. McCluskey (Kathryn Joosten) when she decides to die at home. 7 A.M. (Starz) EASY A (2010) Emma Stone plays Olive, a good girl who pretends to be bad to raise her social standing in high school, as well as that of some persecuted class virgins, in this satire directed by Will Gluck. But when her faked promiscuity generates an unexpected chain reaction, she sews a capital A on her clothes and parades around the school in suggestive outfits. Amanda Bynes is the leader of the Christian club, who denounces Olive as a slut. Penn Badgley is Olive's prince-in-waiting. ''Whatever else it accomplishes, the sassy high school comedy 'Easy A' commands attention for the irresistible presence'' of Ms. Stone, Stephen Holden wrote in The New York Times.

headline: What's On Today
summary: 8 P.M. (OWN) OPRAH AND THE LEGENDARY CAST OF 'ROOTS' 35 YEARS LATER Oprah Winfrey welcomes Cicely Tyson, LeVar Burton, John Amos, Leslie Uggams, Louis Gossett Jr. and Ben Vereen into her home in Montecito, Calif., as she, above with several cast members, pays tribute to the 35th anniversary of the mini-series adapted from Alex Haley's Pulitzer Prize-winning autobiographical novel of his family's descent from an African slave, Kunta Kinte. The saga, which drew nearly 80 million viewers, remains one of the highest-rated television mini-series ever. 9:45 A.M. (HBO2) THE TIME TRAVELER'S WIFE (2009) In this adaptation of the Audrey Niffenegger best seller, Eric Bana plays Henry, a Chicago librarian and unwilling time traveler who flits -- naked -- in and out of the life of his true love, Clare (Rachel McAdams), only to return each time with increasingly disconcerting information about her future. ''The director Robert Schwentke lays a heavy hand on every nuance and has made a dirge about love instead of an ode,'' Manohla Dargis wrote in The New York Times.

headline: Univision and ABC to Start an English Channel to Reach Hispanics
summary: 10:30 a.m. | Updated The Walt Disney Company's ABC News division and Univision have tentatively agreed to create an English-language cable television channel for Hispanics in the United States. The companies, which will each own 50 percent of the joint venture, said Monday morning that the channel - which is, as yet, unnamed - would start sometime in the first half of 2013. Ben Sherwood, the president of ABC News, said it would be ''a 24/7 news, information and lifestyle network primarily in English that will serve the youngest and fastest-growing demographic in the country: U.S. Hispanics.''

headline: Paid Notice: Deaths SWEETNAM, ELIZABETH ANN
summary: SWEETNAM--Elizabeth Ann, died on March 21, 2014 after a brave fight with breast cancer. Her husband and friends were at her side. She was 66 and lived in SoHo and Shelter Island, NY. Elizabeth was born in Vancouver, Canada. After graduating York University in Ontario, she did post-graduate work at Brown University. Liz was a founding member of the University of the New World at Valais, Switzerland. While teaching High School English, she co-produced the independent documentary "Shopping Bag Ladies" in the 1970's, Elizabeth was very proud of the many stories that she edited at CBS "60 Minutes". She loved the arts and cared deeply about people and the environment we live in. Elizabeth is forever in our hearts and is survived by her husband, Vincent Novak, her brother, Gerry and many other family members and friends across the U.S. and Canada. A memorial service will be announced at a later date. Donations may be made to the VNSNY Haven Hospice in NYC.

headline: A Delicate Balance For the President
summary: As President Obama shifts more fully into campaign mode, he faces the increasingly difficult task of balancing his policy duties as president with his political imperatives as a candidate. The week ahead will test his ability to manage those two roles as the White House and his campaign advisers juggle fund-raising, legislative maneuvering and continuing controversy over health care and religious freedom.

headline: ‘Duck Dynasty’ Soars
summary: “Duck Dynasty” only gets bigger. It season finale Wednesday night set new ratings records for the A&E network and in the process made even “American Idol” shrink under its growing wingspan. The finale was watched by 9.6 million viewers, the show’s biggest audience yet. Only two shows on broadcast television, “Idol” on Fox (12.5 million) and “Survivor” on CBS (10.3 million), had more viewers Wednesday night.

headline: Grammy Concert Moves to Nashville
summary: The televised concert to announce nominees for the Grammy Awards will be held in Nashville this year, in a nod to the power of country music within the music industry, the National Academy of Recording Arts and Sciences announced on Tuesday.The show, entitled "The Grammy Nominations Concert Live!!!," will be broadcast from the Bridgestone Arena on CBS on Dec. 5 at 10 p.m.

headline: What's On Today
summary: 8 P.M. (NBC) THE 69TH ANNUAL GOLDEN GLOBE AWARDS Ricky Gervais, above, returns for his third stint as host of these awards -- considered predictors of the Oscars -- sponsored by the Hollywood Foreign Press Association and broadcast live from the Beverly Hilton Hotel in Los Angeles. In the motion picture drama division, nominees include ''The Descendants,'' ''The Help,'' ''Hugo,'' ''The Ides of March,'' ''Moneyball'' and ''War Horse'' for best picture; Glenn Close, Viola Davis, Rooney Mara, Meryl Streep and Tilda Swinton for best actress; and George Clooney, Leonardo DiCaprio, Michael Fassbender, Ryan Gosling and Brad Pitt for best actor. In the comedy or musical division, the nominees are ''50/50,'' ''The Artist,'' ''Bridesmaids,'' ''Midnight in Paris'' and ''My Week With Marilyn'' for best picture; Jodie Foster, Charlize Theron, Kristen Wiig, Michelle Williams and Kate Winslet for best actress; and Jean Dujardin, Brendan Gleeson, Joseph Gordon-Levitt, Ryan Gosling and Owen Wilson for best actor. Morgan Freeman will receive the Cecil B. DeMille Award. Awards will also be handed out for television work. Coverage from the red carpet begins at 5 on E! and at 7 on NBC; E! will visit after-parties at 11. 9 A.M. (CNN) STATE OF THE UNION WITH CANDY CROWLEY Ms. Crowley speaks with the Republican presidential candidate Gov. Rick Perry of Texas, who appears on ''This Week With George Stephanopoulos'' at 10 on ABC. The comedian Stephen Colbert is also a guest.

headline: In Sun Valley, Less Adulation of Tech Start-Ups
summary: As moguls descended on Sun Valley on Tuesday for Allen & Company's annual gathering, they were greeted by a giant plume of smoke. Fanned by wind, wildfires in southern Idaho had spawned a huge cloud, obscuring the area's verdant hills and creating a mess on the runways. Commercial and private jets were delayed. Many circled Friedman Memorial Airport, waiting for their turn to land. And about a dozen private jets were diverted to the airport in Twin Falls -- an hour and a half drive from the resort.

headline: Corrections
summary: An obituary on Monday about Esther Kartiganer, a senior producer on ''60 Minutes,'' misstated the action CBS took against her after an independent panel concluded that a ''60 Minutes II'' segment about President George W. Bush's military service during the Vietnam War had been unfair and had been rushed to broadcast without proper vetting. Ms. Kartiganer was removed from ''60 Minutes'' and reassigned; she was not dismissed from the network.

headline: Dispute Erupts at N.Y.U. Over Credits for 1982 TV Movie
summary: 4:56 p.m. | Updated " The Royal Romance of Charles and Diana " was a forgettable made-for-TV movie broadcast by CBS in 1982. But it has re-emerged 30 years later at the center of an esoteric but messily contentious dispute about screenwriting credits involving faculty members at New York University's prestigious Tisch School of the Arts .

headline: Split Decision in Ratings Battle
summary: In the battle for Thursday ratings supremacy, Fox and CBS split the spoils, as the former finished first in the 18-to-49-year-old demographic loved by advertisers and the latter reached the highest overall viewership. Fox's ''American Idol'' averaged 15.3 million total viewers and at least temporarily ended its slide in the 18-to-49-year-old demographic after a month of drops. NBC was also able to claim a small victory as ''Community'' held steady in the 18-to-49 category when compared to last week despite direct competition from a new episode of ''The Big Bang Theory'' on CBS at 8 p.m. ''Big Bang Theory'' on CBS was the No. 1 Thursday program with adults 18-to-49, but the show was down 12 percent in that category and dropped in total viewers (from 15 million to 13.6 million) when compared to the last new episode three weeks ago.

headline: Paid Notice: Deaths SPENCER, EDSON WHITE
summary: SPENCER--Edson White, age 85, passed away peacefully at home in Wayzata, MN on March 25, 2012 after a valiant battle with PSP. He was surrounded by his wife of 62 years Harriet, and their four children, Linda Spencer Murchison, Edson W. Spencer Jr., Douglas Stuart Spencer and James McClure Spencer. Born June 4, 1926, and raised in Chicago, Illinois, Spencer served in the U.S. Navy and was honorably discharged in 1946. A graduate of Williams College, he went on to Oxford University as a Rhodes Scholar, earning an M.A. in 1950. He and Harriet McClure Stuart married in August 1950. He worked for Sears Roebuck in Sioux City, IA, La Crosse, WI, and in Venezuela before settling in Minneapolis in 1954. Ed began his 32 year career at Honeywell as an aeronautical engineer, then as Regional Manager for Honeywell Asia based in Tokyo, Japan from 1959 to 1964. He ultimately served as Chairman and CEO of Honeywell from 1973-1987. During that time he served on the boards of Norwest Corporation, CBS, and American Express Mutual Funds Group, and the international advisory boards of NEC, Chase Manhattan Bank, and Robert Bosch, Gmbh. Ed's personal interests were many and varied and he brought passion, insight and intellectual curiosity to everything he took on. He was most proud of his service on the boards of the Ford Foundation, Carnegie Endowment for International Peace, the Mayo Foundation and the Minneapolis Foundation. Throughout his career he pursued his interest in US Japan relations with membership on the U.S. Japan Business Council and the Trilateral Commission. Additionally, he served on Governor Perpich's Blue Ribbon Commission on the University of Minnesota, Governor Carlson's Roundtable on Higher Education, and the Board of Carleton College. Ed was actively engaged in the Humphrey Institute at the University of Minnesota and a dedicated advisor to the Center for Victims of Torture. Between many a trip to interesting places around the world you could find Ed (and Harriet) casting a line in the Clarks Fork of the Yellowstone in Northwestern Wyoming. Deeply committed to the national treasure that is Yellowstone National Park, he and Harriet were founders of the Yellowstone Park Foundation, and served on the Advisory Board of the National Parks and Conservation Association. Spencer was accomplished athlete who enjoyed competition throughout his life. He was an excellent college hockey and tennis player; later in life he enjoyed skiing, tennis, fly fishing and hiking. These many professional accomplishments never masked what was most important to him, which was spending time with family and friends. He is survived by his wife Harriet; children Linda (Reid) Murchison, Ed (Val) Spencer, Doug (Kathleen Parrish) Spencer and Jim (Polly) Spencer, and nine wonderful grandchildren, Sarah (Andy), Clare, Emily, Julia, Katie, Alison, Teddy, James, and Michael. The family would like to express special appreciation to Becky Fredericks and her team of nurses for their gracious and wonderful care, and to Allina Hospice Care. A memorial service will be held at the Wayzata Community Church on Tuesday, April 3rd at 3pm. In lieu of flowers, memorial gifts can be made to Cure PSP, 30 E. Padonia Road, Suite 201, Timonium, MD 21093; www.curepsp.org; The Center for Victims of Torture, 649 Dayton Avenue St. Paul, MN 55104; www.cvt.org; or The Mayo Foundation: www.mayoclinic.org.

While teaching High School English, she co-produced the independent documentary "Shopping Bag Ladies" in the 1970's, Elizabeth was very proud of the many stories that she edited at CBS "60 Minutes". She loved the arts and cared deeply about people and the environment we live in. Elizabeth is forever in our hearts and is survived by her husband, Vincent Novak, her brother, Gerry and many other family members and friends across the U.S. and Canada. A memorial service will be announced at a later date. Donations may be made to the VNSNY Haven Hospice in NYC.

headline: What's On Today
summary: 8 P.M. (13, 49) KANGAROO MOB In the last 50 years, the population of eastern gray kangaroos around Canberra, the capital of Australia, has multiplied from a few hundred to tens of thousands. Forced to search for food beyond the city's drought-stricken hills, the hungry creatures have moved into urban territory, dining on parkland and lawns -- and dying by the thousands in run-ins with cars. That has led the government to reduce herds through extermination, prompting an emotional backlash. This ''Nature'' episode follows a gang of street-wise kangaroos to reveal how they survive in the city. Among them are Black Spot, above, at more than 6 feet tall the mob's dominant male and the father of most of the joeys in his group, and Madge, who teaches her son Sonny about survival among humans while carrying a nursing joey named Alice in her pouch. The program also ponders the prospect of relocating kangaroo herds or controlling their numbers through forced contraception. 11 A.M. (MoreMax) OUT OF AFRICA (1985) Meryl Streep earned her sixth best-actress Oscar nomination as the Danish writer Karen Blixen, who later published under the name Isak Dinesen, in this sweeping drama about her life on a coffee plantation in British East Africa, now Kenya, for which Sydney Pollack won for best director; the film won best picture. Klaus Maria Brandauer was also nominated for his role as Baron Bror Blixen, her Swedish-born cousin and husband. Robert Redford plays Denys Finch Hatton, the love of her life.

headline: Paid Notice: Deaths KNOX, CORNELIUS V.
summary: KNOX--Cornelius Van Santvoord, 92, formerly of Darien, CT, passed away July 8 in Shelburne, VT. After 40 years in broadcasting, he retired as CBS Radio's Vice President of Affiliate Relations. He lived every day to the fullest; he bought new skis at 91. His wife, Nancy Cronyn Knox, passed away in 2010. He is survived by his sister, his four children, six grandchildren and a great-grandchild. We'll celebrate his life 3pm, Friday, August 23, Darien Community Association, 274 Middlesex Rd., Darien.

headline: Paid Notice: Deaths ENGER, PAUL
summary: ENGER--Paul, 86, retired newsman, playwright and co-founder of a soup kitchen for the homeless, died November 29, 2013. Born in Fargo, ND, Paul graduated from the University of Minnesota, began a career as a newspaper reporter in his hometown, worked for UPI and CBS News in New York. There he wrote for evening anchors Walter Cronkite and Dan Rather. He also wrote for Good Morning America and All My Children on ABC-TV, as well as scripts for A&E Cable and The History Channel. He holds three awards from the Writers Guild of America and is the recipient of the International Radio NY Festival Gold Award. Paul authored nine full-length plays, including "Vestigial Parts" and "Harmon and Ruth." His works have been performed Off Broadway as well as in Massachusetts, Florida, Arizona, California and Indiana. His most recent play, "Benefit Performance," a play with songs written with Tom Ferriter and Michael Valenti is slated for production at Stageplays Theatre in the coming season. Paul was an active member of Holy Trinity Lutheran Church on West 65th Street in Manhattan, where he co-founded HUG, a soup kitchen program for homeless men and women, and assisted in planning the Bach Vespers program. Paul, who lived in Jackson Heights, Queens, was the beloved brother of Mary K. Katz and beloved uncle of Gretchen Browne and Richard Katz. A funeral service will be held at Holy Trinity Lutheran Church on Saturday, December 7 at 9:30am. Burial will be at Riverside Cemetery in Fargo, ND. Services are under the direction of Conway Funeral Home, Jackson Heights.

headline: Tight Senate Races Seen In Virginia and Wisconsin
summary: A new poll finds tight races for Senate seats in the presidential swing states of Virginia and Wisconsin.In Virginia, where the race pairs two former governors, 48 percent of likely voters support the Democratic candidate, Tim Kaine, and 46 percent back the Republican nominee, George Allen, a difference that is within the poll's margin of sampling error of plus or minus 3 percentage points.

headline: What's On Today
summary: 8 P.M. (HBO) THE WEIGHT OF THE NATION More than two-thirds of the adults in the United States and one-third of children are overweight, leading to an increase of deaths from heart disease, Type 2 diabetes, cancer, stroke and kidney disease. This four-part documentary -- a collaboration among HBO, the Institute of Medicine, the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention, and the National Institutes of Health -- is at the center of a public health campaign that includes a book, a social media component and a nationwide outreach to more than 40,000 community organizations. This first installment, ''Consequences'' (above, a scene from the film), explores the health effects of being overweight. Part 2, ''Choices,'' at 9:10, investigates the science of weight loss and offers diet and exercise tips that will help people find success. Parts 3 and 4 will be broadcast on Tuesday, starting at 8. 2 P.M. (AMC) CINDERELLA MAN (2005) In this biopic from Ron Howard, Russell Crowe, right, portrays James J. Braddock, the Depression-era heavyweight boxing champion with a 75-inch reach, who on June 13, 1935, fought the fight of his life against Max Baer (Craig Bierko), a k a the Livermore Larruper, whose reach was 81 inches. But it's the face-off between Braddock and his manager, Joe Gould (Paul Giamatti), that gives the film its bite. One of its satisfactions is that the story that unfolds inside the ring is not the same one the filmmakers seem keen to sell, Manohla Dargis said in The New York Times. ''Their Cinderella Man is the decent little guy who affirms what movie people call the triumph of the human spirit,'' she wrote. ''The story Mr. Crowe tells, with Mr. Giamatti as a gleeful Mephistopheles, is that of a man who, having sampled the blood of others, clearly enjoyed the taste.''

headline: What's On Today
summary: 8 P.M. (HBO) THE WEIGHT OF THE NATION More than two-thirds of the adults in the United States and one-third of children are overweight, leading to an increase in deaths from heart disease, Type 2 diabetes, cancer, stroke and kidney disease. This four-part documentary -- a collaboration by HBO, the Institute of Medicine, the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention and the National Institutes of Health -- is at the center of a public health campaign that includes a book, a social media component and an effort to reach more than 40,000 community groups. Part 3, ''Children in Crisis,'' looks at the struggle of overweight children and at their medical issues; above, a middle school gym class in Austin, Tex. It also examines school lunch standards and the debate over the definition of good nutrition among food and beverage makers, researchers and the government. The conclusion, ''Challenges,'' at 9:10, explores factors behind the obesity epidemic, including subsidized agriculture, evolutionary biology, racial and socioeconomic disparities, physical inactivity and the strong influence of the food and beverage industry. ''It wouldn't surprise me if people look back on the early part of the 21st century and call this the obesity era,'' says Dr. Thomas Farley, the New York City health commissioner. 9 A.M. (Sundance) ENCOUNTERS AT THE END OF THE WORLD (2008) For this documentary Werner Herzog traveled to Antarctica, where he met scientists and journeymen at the American outpost McMurdo Station and the penguins, seals, clams and jellyfish that surround them on what might as well be another planet. ''Few filmmakers make the end of days seem as hauntingly beautiful as Werner Herzog does, or as inexorable,'' Manohla Dargis wrote in The New York Times. One of the film's beauties, Ms. Dargis said, ''is that all the furry and floating animals are no more wondrous than the bipeds tramping through and around McMurdo: the linguist turned philosopher, the banker turned bus driver, and the female adventurer who, for drama and odd entertainment, likes to have herself zipped up in a carryall bag. (She's her own baggage.) Mr. Herzog opens his mind, heart and eyes to all these wayfarers who -- despite the persistent strain of melancholy that touches each and every person who appears on camera -- seem eerily at peace at the bottom of the world.'' The film received an Oscar nomination for best documentary feature.

headline: Letterman and Ferguson To Continue on CBS
summary: CBS, closing the lid on any speculation that change might be coming for its late-night lineup, announced Tuesday that both David Letterman and Craig Ferguson have agreed to continue in their shows for at least two more years. The ''at least'' may be the biggest news because Mr. Letterman -- whose tenure at night would now reach 32 years, passing the 30-year mark of his idol Johnny Carson and making him the longest-serving late-night host in TV history -- has been the subject of frequent speculation about when he might choose to step down. Mr. Letterman will turn 65 on April 12.

headline: What's On Today
summary: 9 P.M. (13); 10 P.M. (49) TONY BENNETT: DUETS II Soon after his 85th birthday on Aug. 3, Mr. Bennett released ''Duets II,'' the follow-up to his Grammy-winning album ''Duets: An American Classic,'' made in honor of his 80th. ''Duets II'' started atop the Billboard 200 chart, making Mr. Bennett the oldest artist to reach No. 1. This ''Great Performances'' presentation captures recording sessions in Los Angeles, London, New York, Nashville and at the home of Andrea Bocelli in Italy. It also features performances including ''Body and Soul,'' with Amy Winehouse, in what would be her last recorded track; ''The Lady Is a Tramp,'' with Lady Gaga (above, with Mr. Bennett); ''Speak Low,'' with Norah Jones; ''The Way You Look Tonight,'' with Faith Hill; ''It Had to Be You,'' with Carrie Underwood; and ''On the Sunny Side of the Street,'' with Willie Nelson. ''Duets II'' has been nominated for three Grammy Awards, including for best pop duo/group. 7:15 A.M. (IFC) LITTLE MISS SUNSHINE (2006) Abigail Breslin, right, received an Academy Award nomination for her portrayal of the unlikely preteen princess Olive Hoover in this comedy about a family of misfits determined to get a 7-year-old to a beauty pageant. Alan Arkin won an Oscar for best supporting actor as the heroin-snorting grandfather who helps put Olive's talent routine over the top. Greg Kinnear and Toni Collette play the parents driving the ravaged family and its equally dilapidated Volkswagen bus. Steve Carell portrays Olive's suicidal gay uncle, and Paul Dano is the Hoovers' teenage son, who has decided to keep his mouth shut about the situation. Writing in The New York Times, Manohla Dargis called the film ''a tale about genuine faith and manufactured glory that unwinds in the American Southwest, but more rightly takes place at the terminus of the American dream, where families are one bad break away from bankruptcy.''

headline: Paid Notice: Deaths CONNABLE, JOEL B.
summary: CONNABLE--Joel Barnes. A bright light has gone out of our lives. Our wonderful, cheerful, courageous son died Tuesday, November 6 in Seattle. Joel was born in New Orleans, grew up in Roslyn, Long Island, graduated from the St. Vincent School of Emergency Medicine, served as a Paramedic with the Nassau County Police Department, and graduated from the University of Southern California. He was an Emmy-winning TV reporter and anchor, starting at WLTX (CBS) in Columbia, SC, then KCAL (CBS) in Los Angeles and WTVJ (NBC) in Miami, FL. Founder and CEO of Travel TV News and Deals, Joel had recently joined KOMO (ABC) in Seattle. He was also a Spokesman for the Juvenile Diabetes Research Foundation. He leaves his loving parents, Alfred and Roma; his devoted brother Major Benjamin (USMC ret.); and sister-in-law Rebecca Morrissey; much loved nephews Aram and Charlie and his adoring fiancee Angela Shlyakhov. A memorial service will be announced at a later date.

headline: U.S. Open Could Add Rest Day By 2013
summary: MELBOURNE -- The Australian Open, once the weakest of the four Grand Slam tennis tournaments, now has two stadiums with retractable roofs and a third one on the way. Player response continues to be positive. ''Of the four Grand Slams, it is the tournament that behaves better toward the players,'' Rafael Nadal said after losing in the men's final last Monday.

headline: Network TV Viewers Keep Vanishing
summary: The case of the missing network viewers continued Wednesday night as more shows, including some of the biggest hits on television, recorded their lowest ratings of the year. That happened to ABC's ''Modern Family,'' considered the strongest comedy on television, which sank to a season-low 4 rating in the 18-to-49-year-old audience that drives most ad sales. The pattern continued with other ABC shows on the night. The comedy ''Suburgatory'' hit a low for that series, a 2 rating, and the much-talked about drama ''Revenge'' returned from a seven-week hiatus with its own season low, a 2.3 rating.

headline: What's On Sunday
summary: 7 P.M. (NBC) 2012 LONDON OLYMPICS The United States female gymnasts, including Jordyn Wieber, above, and Gabby Douglas, make their debuts at the Summer Games in a qualification round. Swimming finals include the women's 100-meter butterfly and 400-meter freestyle as well as the men's 100-meter breaststroke and 4x100-meter free relay. The first gold medal in women's diving will be awarded in the synchronized springboard final. Earlier in the day the men's basketball team, whose roster includes Kobe Bryant, LeBron James and Kevin Durant, faces off against France, for whom the N.B.A. star Tony Parker will play, at 9:30 a.m. on NBC Sports. The men's water polo team will take on Montenegro at 2:40 p.m. on NBC. And the women's field hockey team will meet Germany at 4:15 on NBC Sports. 9 A.M. (CNN) STATE OF THE UNION Senator Richard J. Durbin, Democrat of Illinois, and Senator Kelly Ayotte, Republican of New Hampshire, discuss Mitt Romney's trip abroad.

headline: Television Schedule
summary: MONDAY -- FRIDAY 11 a.m.â7 p.m. Tennis Channel

headline: What's On Today
summary: 9 A.M. (MoreMax) GIRL WITH A PEARL EARRING (2003) This feature directorial debut from Peter Webber, based on the novel by Tracy Chevalier, imagines the life of Griet (Scarlett Johansson, right), a teenage maid in the Netherlands in the 1660s who becomes the muse for Johannes Vermeer (Colin Firth) and is immortalized in one of his most famous paintings. ''Ms. Johansson is photographed so that her skin is as opalescent as her earring, but the movie is opaque,'' Elvis Mitchell wrote in The New York Times. ''It is an earnest, obvious melodrama with no soul, filled with the longing silences that come after a sigh.'' Yet, he added, the film is ''a dexterous and absorbing visual re-creation of the lighting and the look that Vermeer achieved in his work.'' The movie received Oscar nominations for art direction, set decoration, cinematography and costume design. 9:15 A.M. (HBO2) CRIMES AND MISDEMEANORS (1989) When the mistress (Anjelica Huston) of Judah Rosenthal (Martin Landau, in an Oscar-nominated performance), a Manhattan ophthalmologist, threatens to go public with their affair and his unethical financial dealings, he hires his mobster brother (Jerry Orbach) to kill her in this movie from Woody Allen, who received best director and best screenplay nominations. Mr. Allen also plays Cliff Stern, a married documentarian infatuated by another woman (Mia Farrow). Sam Waterston is Judah's best friend, a rabbi; Alan Alda is a successful television producer and Cliff's brother-in-law. ''The wonder of 'Crimes and Misdemeanors' is the facility with which Mr. Allen deals with so many interlocking stories of so many differing tones and voices,'' Vincent Canby wrote in The Times. ''The film cuts back and forth between parallel incidents and between present and past with the effortlessness of a hip, contemporary Aesop.''

headline: 'Chronicle' Leads on Slow Weekend for Movies
summary: Score one for 20th Century Fox, whose low-budget movie ''Chronicle'' turned out a bigger-than-expected crowd at theaters on what is typically one of Hollywood's slowest weekends of the year. ''Chronicle,'' about three teenage boys who learn they have superpowers, was No. 1 at North American theaters, taking in about $22 million, according to Hollywood.com, which compiles box office data. The solid result for ''Chronicle,'' made in-house for a mere $12 million (not easy for a huge studio to do), validates Fox's decision to aggressively aim for elusive male moviegoers -- and on Super Bowl weekend, no less. Notably, Fox relied heavily on Twitter to create buzz, buying zero newspaper ads.

headline: TV Ratings
summary: In an odd twist, the time change due to Daylight Savings apparently continued to depress television ratings among the networks for the fourth night in a row on Wednesday. Overall viewership in the 18-to-49-year-old demographic was down by 9 percent compared to last week and almost every show experienced a drop in ratings of some kind. Fox was the No. 1 network for the night and ''American Idol'' had 17.9 million total viewers, but that was down from the 18.7 million who tuned in for last Wednesday's episode. On ABC, ''Modern Family'' finished with season lows in the 18-to-49 category and in total viewers (10.5 million). ''Criminal Minds'' on CBS hit a series low in viewers 18-to-49 and had 11.3 million total viewers.

headline: What's On Sunday
summary: 9 P.M. (13, 49) BIRDSONG Eddie Redmayne (''My Week With Marilyn''), above, pulls out the romantic stops as Stephen Wraysford, a lieutenant in the British Army who, on the Allied front in 1916, barely seems to register the surrounding destruction as he remembers the summer of 1910 and his singular love, Isabelle Azaire (Clémence Poésy), in this ''Masterpiece Classic'' presentation. The two-part dramatization, adapted from the 1993 novel by Sebastian Faulks, cuts between the trenches of World War I and the woods of northern France as it chronicles the relationship of Stephen and Isabelle, the wife of a textile factory owner, from its initial passion to its startling demise. 9 A.M. (CNN) STATE OF THE UNION WITH CANDY CROWLEY The scandals surrounding the Secret Service and the General Services Administration make the rounds of the morning news shows, starting with an appearance here by Representative Elijah E. Cummings, Democrat of Maryland. The discussion continues on ''Fox News Sunday,'' at 10, with Senator Joseph I. Lieberman, independent of Connecticut, and Gov. Mitch Daniels of Indiana; Senator Susan Collins, Republican of Maine, and Representative Sheila Jackson Lee, Democrat of Texas, on ''This Week With George Stephanopoulos,'' at 10 on ABC; Mr. Lieberman and W. Ralph Basham Jr., a former director of the Secret Service, on ''Face the Nation,'' at 10:30 on CBS; Representatives Darrell Issa, Republican of California, and Peter T. King, Republican of New York, on ''Meet the Press,'' at 10:30 on NBC; and Representative Cummings on ''Washington Watch With Roland Martin,'' at 11 on TV One.

headline: Alan Suna
summary: Mr. Suna, 59, is chief executive of Silvercup Studios, a TV and film production studio with two shooting locations in Long Island City. Silvercup has been home to several series, including ''Sex and the City,'' ''The Sopranos,'' ''30 Rock'' and ''Gossip Girl.'' Mr. Suna's brother, Stuart, is the president. Interview conducted and condensed by

headline: What's On Sunday
summary: 7:30 P.M. (13) PHIL OCHS: THERE BUT FOR FORTUNE Inspired by Woody Guthrie, Elvis Presley and even John Wayne, Ochs, above, one of the most politically active singer-songwriters of his generation, created folk-protest songs emblematic of the 1960s, among them ''I Ain't Marching Anymore,'' ''Power and the Glory'' and ''The War Is Over.'' Unyielding in principle and unbending in artistic vision, he spiraled into depression after the assassinations of the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. and Robert F. Kennedy in 1968 and committed suicide in 1976 at 35. ''American Masters'' begins a 26th season with this documentary from Kenneth Bowser, who chronicles Ochs's life through interviews with Joan Baez, Tom Hayden, Sean Penn and Pete Seeger. 9 A.M. (CNN) STATE OF THE UNION WITH CANDY CROWLEY Ms. Crowley interviews the Republican presidential candidate Rick Santorum in the wake of the South Carolina primary. He also appears on ''This Week With George Stephanopoulos,'' at 10 on ABC.

headline: Paid Notice: Deaths BARRETT, DOLORES J.
summary: BARRETT--Dolores J. Dolores died peacefully in her sleep on December 24, 2013, after a series of long and debilitating illnesses, which she suffered with her characteristic restraint, dignity, and indomitable spirit. Her many friends in the fields of fashion, design, medicine, and media admired her as an elegant woman of impeccable taste, rock-steady values, and an empathetic nature that allowed her to understand and share the feelings of others. She was the middle child of Mildred and Dwight Cupp, both of whom were well-known residents of Johnstown, Pennsylvania. Her father died when she was two years old, and she eventually adopted the surname of her stepfather, Robert Jones. She was a graduate of Penn State, where she was invited to join Mortar Board, the premier national honor society recognizing college seniors. After receiving her master's degree from the University of Pennsylvania's Annenberg School for Communication, she embarked on a distinguished career as a public relations executive at The New York Hospital, CBS, and Polo Ralph Lauren. During the eight years in which she served as the Senior Vice President for Worldwide Public Relations at Polo, Dolores worked closely with the designer Ralph Lauren, and is widely credited with helping him build his global brand and making Ralph Lauren a household name beyond the fashion industry. She was married for 26 years to Edward Klein, the former editor in chief of The New York Times Magazine and the author of numerous nonfiction bestsellers. Her son, Robertson Barrett, is Vice President of Yahoo News and Finance. Her daughter, Melissa Barrett Rhodes, is Vice President of Brand Development for Clarins. Her stepdaughter, Karen Hirsch, is the former co-manager of the Four Seasons Restaurant. Dolores was a loving and deeply involved grandmother to John and Annalise Rhodes, Nathaniel and Cora Barrett, and Jesse Hirsch. She is also survived by her sister, Natalie Kearns, and her brother, John Jones. She leaves a void in the hearts of her family and friends that can only be filled by the memories of love, warmth and happiness that she left behind.

headline: What's On Today
summary: 8 P.M. (ABC) EXTREME MAKEOVER: HOME EDITION The series travels to Fayette County, Iowa, to surprise Audrey Gibbs, who, seven months after the death of her husband, had a brain aneurysm that left her legally blind. Doctors cannot predict whether she will lose her sight completely. Unable to continue her work as a cosmetologist, she has become a massage therapist, which doesn't require sight, the better to support her six children. In this, the penultimate episode, Ty Pennington (above, foreground, with Ms. Gibbs) and his crew remodel the family's farmhouse, which has no working toilet and a caved-in ceiling. The musician Bret Michaels lends a hand. 7:15 A.M. (Sho2) THE LAST PLAY AT SHEA (2010) The histories of Shea Stadium, the Mets, Billy Joel (below) and New York City itself across four and a half decades intersect in this documentary from Paul Crowder, which focuses on Mr. Joel's concerts on July 16 and July 18, 2008 -- the last performances given in the stadium, which was torn down the next year. ''For the July 18 concert,'' Stephen Holden wrote in The New York Times, Paul McCartney ''miraculously appeared, having been whisked through customs at Kennedy International Airport after a flight from London that had been allowed to land early. He was sped to the stadium by a motorcade in 11 minutes and driven onto the field in time to perform by Pete Flynn, the dedicated groundskeeper who had driven the Beatles to the same stage 43 years earlier.'' Mr. Holden added: '' 'If it weren't for the Beatles,' Mr. Joel declares, 'I wouldn't do what I do.' Call it perfect symmetry. The final number, 'Let It Be,' rings as a sweet valedictory to all the struggle, the teamwork and the glory captured in this wonderful film.'' In the film ''The Love We Make'' (2011), at 11 on Showtime, Albert Maysles, Bradley Kaplan and Ian Markiewicz capture Mr. McCartney's experiences in New York City after the Sept. 11, 2001, attacks and his performance the next month with Elton John, Mr. Joel and David Bowie in the ''Concert for New York City'' at Madison Square Garden. Mr. McCartney had been on the runway at Kennedy when the attacks occurred.

headline: An MTV Veteran Joins ‘Fuse News’
summary: With each new employee hired, the news division at Fuse is increasingly coming to resemble a cable rival that once put the M in music television. On Monday, Fuse said that it had hired John Norris , a veteran producer and on-air personality at MTV, as supervising producer of “Fuse News,” its daily music-news program. Mr. Norris, who joined MTV in the halcyon year of 1990, worked there as a writer and correspondent for MTV News, hosted its weekly “MTV News 1515″ program and its daily series “Hangin’ with MTV” and reported for its “Choose or Lose” political specials; he was also the MTV news anchor and senior correspondent from 2000 to 2008 and has been a correspondent for the CBS programs “Sunday Morning” and “48 Hours.”

summary: BARRETT--Dolores J. Dolores died peacefully in her sleep on December 24, 2013, after a series of long and debilitating illnesses, which she suffered with her characteristic restraint, dignity, and indomitable spirit. Her stepdaughter, Karen Hirsch, is the former co-manager of the Four Seasons Restaurant. headline: Polls Favor Two Democrats
summary: Democratic incumbents have an edge over their challengers in the Florida and Ohio Senate races, while in Wisconsin, fresh from winning the Republican primary, former Gov. Tommy Thompson has a six-point advantage over Representative Tammy Baldwin. New Quinnipiac University/New York Times/CBS News polls of the three swing states offer a view of the competition for control of the Senate.

headline: Paid Notice: Deaths KNOX, CORNELIUS VAN SANTVOORD
summary: KNOX--Cornelius Van Santvoord, 92, formerly of Darien, CT, passed away July 8 in Shelburne, VT. After 40 years in broadcasting, he retired as CBS Radio's Vice President of Affiliate Relations. He lived every day to the fullest; he bought new skis at 91. His wife, Nancy Cronyn Knox, passed away in 2010. He is survived by his sister, his four children, six grandchildren and a great-grandchild. We'll celebrate his life 3pm, Friday, August 23, Darien Community Association, 274 Middlesex Rd., Darien.

headline: A Pact Ends a Nine-Day Blackout of Cable Channels
summary: DirecTV and Viacom may have quarreled bitterly over the costs of a new contract this month, but they agree on at least one thing: the preservation of television as they know it, provided only to paying subscribers. After a marathon negotiating session Thursday, the two companies announced early Friday morning that they had reached an agreement to end a nine-day blackout of Nickelodeon, MTV, Comedy Central and other cable channels in DirecTV homes.

headline: 'Jesse Stone: Benefit of the Doubt'
summary: This is the eighth television movie in which Tom Selleck portrays Jesse Stone.

headline: A New Editor to Take the Helm of Cosmopolitan
summary: 12:10 p.m. | Updated In January, Kate White went to David Carey, the president of Hearst Magazines, and told him she was thinking about stepping down after 14 years as the editor of Cosmopolitan magazine. Given the importance of the franchise to the company, Mr. Carey immediately set about looking for a successor.

headline: Paid Notice: Deaths LISANBY, CHARLES A.
summary: LISANBY--Charles Alvin Jr., passed away peacefully in the presence of his family in Los Angeles, California, on August 23, 2013, at the age of 89. Mr. Lisanby had a seven decade career in the arts and entertainment industry, marked by 16 Emmy Nominations and three Wins for Baryshnikov on Broadway, Ben Franklin, The Ambassador - mini series, and (Barry) Manilow: Big Fun on Swing Street. Born in Princeton, KY, Mr. Lisanby arrived in New York City at the age of 16 to pursue art studies and an apprenticeship with the legendary Broadway and Film Art Director, Cecil Beaton. Following a stint in the Army, he landed a position at CBS and later at ABC as their first Art Director. He worked on many variety shows including the Garry Moore Show, where Carol Burnett, among others got their start. In fact, it was Charles who recommended Ms. Burnett to Moore's producer, Bob Banner. Bob Banner, hired Charles for many variety shows, for Alan King, Paul Lynde, Bob Hope, Kathy Lee Gifford, Barry Manilow, Barbra Streisand, Carol Burnett and Julie Andrews, Mikhail Baryshnikov, and Diana Ross. Twelve of his musical specials won Emmys for best Variety Show. He did multiple Motion Picture Academy Awards Shows, the Grammys, and the first MTV Awards shows. Commercial producers also reached out to Mr. Lisanby to design, the CLIO award winning original, Merrill Lynch "bull" commercials, and seven Dr. Pepper commercials and the Panasonic "hands" commercials. He was the designer of Radio City's Christmas Show from '78 thru '95 and the full run of their Easter show during that period. His one act play adaptation of "Christmas Carol" ran for seven years at Radio City. Commencing in 1980, he was the designer of the Crystal Cathedral's Christmas and Easter Productions for their entire run. Mr. Lisanby wrote an original musical entitled, "Family Tree", which became the basis for the musical, "Children of Eden" with lyrics and music by Stephen Schwartz. He also wrote the title and dialogue for Andy Warhol's, "25 Cats Name Sam & One Blue Pussy," which earned both of them their first copyrighted work. Charles has been honored by the Art Directors Guild at the Museum of Television and Radio, the Television Academy with his election to their Hall of Fame as the first in his peer group, Production Designers/ Art Directors and a display of a major body of his designs at the Los Angeles Main Public Library in Getty Hall. Mr. Lisanby is survived by his nieces, Dr. Sarah Hollingsworth Lisanby of Durham, NC, Mrs. Elizabeth Ann Lisanby Bianchi of Huntsville, AL; his sister-in-law, Mrs. Gladys Elnora Kemp Lisanby of Princeton, KY; and his partner Mr. Richard Bostard. He is preceded in death by his brother, Rear Admiral James Walker Lisanby, USN Ret, and his parents Rebecca Hollingsworth Lisanby and Charles Alvin Lisanby, Sr. Funeral services will be held at 3pm on Sunday, September 1st, at Morgan's Funeral Home at 301 W Washington St Princeton, KY 42445 Princeton, KY. In lieu of flowers, memorial donations may be made to the Charles Lisanby Center Checks should be made to: JMU Foundation -- Charles Lisanby Center, Mailing address: James Madison University, Advancement Gifts and Records, MSC 3603, 220 University Blvd., Harrisonburg VA 22807.

headline: What's On Sunday
summary: 11 P.M. (13) FLORENT: QUEEN OF THE MEAT MARKET (2011) David Sigal traces the trajectory of Restaurant Florent, a 24-hour diner-cum-bistro on Gansevoort Street in Manhattan's meatpacking district, from 1985, when it was the lone eatery in a shadowy industrial area, to 2008 when, after a successful run, it became a relic of a bohemian utopia in a quickly changing neighborhood. The film also chronicles the life of the restaurant's owner, Florent Morellet, above, a French expatriate, artist-cartographer and political activist who, after learning in 1987 that he was H.I.V. positive, disregarded the advice of friends and revealed his status, even keeping a running tabulation of his T-cell count on the restaurant's menu board. Writing in The New York Times, Stephen Holden called this film, which features appearances by Julianne Moore, Diane von Furstenberg, Isaac Mizrahi and Michael Musto, ''a touching, elegiac tale of the rise (and some would say fall) of a colorful New York neighborhood under the relentless march of gentrification.'' 9 A.M. (CNN) STATE OF THE UNION WITH CANDY CROWLEY Ms. Crowley interviews David Plouffe, a senior adviser to President Obama, about the administration's plan to turn around the economy. She also speaks with Rick Santorum, a former Republican presidential candidate, about the conservative agenda. Later in the morning, Mr. Plouffe appears on ''Fox News Sunday With Chris Wallace,'' at 10; on ''This Week With George Stephanopoulos,'' at 10 on ABC; and on ''Meet the Press,'' on NBC at 10:30.

headline: 80-Yard Touchdown Pass Delivers Two Victories
summary: Fueled by Tim Tebow mania and capped by Tebow's 80-yard game-winning touchdown pass on the first play of overtime, the broadcast of the Denver Broncos' 29-23 victory over the Pittsburgh Steelers produced huge ratings for CBS on Sunday. According to preliminary overnight Nielsen estimates it was the highest-rated National Football League wild-card playoff game in 24 years and CBS averaged nearly 42 million viewers during the 7 p.m. hour. Later in the night the two-hour series premiere of NBC's ''The Firm'' struggled mightily out of the gate. It averaged 6.3 million viewers and was the lowest-rated regular-season drama debut ever for NBC in the 18-to-49-year-old demographic. But it wasn't all bad news for the other networks. On ABC ''Once Upon a Time'' reversed its recent decline and returned strongly after a short holiday hiatus with 10.3 million viewers, accompanied by its best rating among viewers 18 to 49 since mid-November.

headline: Stand-Up Comedy Booker for 'Late Show' Loses Job
summary: 4:05 p.m. | Updated Eddie Brill, a longtime gatekeeper for rising stand-ups at ''Late Show With David Letterman,'' will no longer be the comedy booker at that CBS late-night series, ending the tenure of a respected and contentious figure in the stand-up comedy world.

headline: Paid Notice: Deaths GRAD, ROBERT JOHN
summary: GRAD--Robert John, 65, of Brewster, NY, died April 17, 2013. He was born January 17, 1948. Bob had many loves: science, music, technology and his friends and family. He was a guitar and auto enthusiast and a huge early fan of the Everly Brothers and Bob Dylan. In his teens, he invented, among other things, an early illuminated Frisbee-type device; designed a primitive lie detector faithfully tested out on a partially willing younger brother, and constructed an elevator device that carried pebbles, hair brushes and turtles outside a seventh floor apartment window facing Arnow Avenue in the Bronx. He went on to create and manage computer systems for IBM and CBS and design software programs, working feverishly for years on a high-speed stock-trade software program before the concept became popular, and came close to putting the final touches on it before the onset of an intestinal disorder that eventually claimed his life. He attended Christopher Columbus High School and the Courant Institute of Mathematical Sciences at NYU. He was predeceased by his father, Zoltan, and is survived by his mother, Fay, of the Bronx; his brother, Peter, of Ridgewood, NJ., cousins, aunts and an extended family of close friends from Kerhonkson to Brewster to Cold Spring, NY.

headline: American Views and Supreme Court Issues
summary: Rulings are expected soon on three big cases: same-sex marriage, affirmative action and voting rights. Here is what the latest New York Times/CBS News poll found about views on those issues.

headline: What's On Today
summary: 9 P.M. (NBC) MACY'S 4TH OF JULY FIREWORKS SPECTACULAR Katy Perry and Kenny Chesney, both at right, headline this 36th annual spectacle, in which 40,000 shells -- about 1,500 a minute -- are scheduled to explode from six barges on the Hudson River. Regis Philbin hosts this fireworks display, the largest in the nation. The theme this year is ''Ignite the Night.'' The ''Boston Pops Fireworks Spectacular,'' at 10 on CBS, will feature Jennifer Hudson and the Boston Pops Orchestra, under the direction of Keith Lockhart, on the banks of the Charles River. Michael Chiklis hosts. 7 A.M. (TMC) GREY GARDENS (1975) Before the Broadway musical and the HBO film there was this portrait of Edith Bouvier Beale and her daughter, Little Edie, directed by David and Albert Maysles. An aunt and a first cousin of Jacqueline Kennedy Onassis, the two lived as recluses in a deteriorating mansion in East Hampton, N.Y. ''There is no doubt about the artistry and devotion that the Maysles have used in recording the life in 'Grey Gardens,' '' said a review in The New York Times. ''There is no reason to doubt them when they say they love and admire the Beales. But the moviegoer will still feel like an exploiter. To watch 'Grey Gardens' is to take part in a kind of carnival of attention with two willing but vulnerable people who had established themselves, for better or worse, in the habit of not being looked at. And what happens when the carnival moves on?''

headline: Another Armstrong Rides to Victory
summary: HAMPTON COURT, England -- For a brief time, Kristin Armstrong thought her competitive cycling days were over. She had a gold medal from the Beijing Olympics and a beautiful little boy named Lucas, and since it felt right, she retired. Six weeks after giving birth, she went for a bike ride. Twenty-two months after that, on Wednesday she found herself at a start line, defending the women's time-trial gold medal she captured in 2008. That she won again could have been expected. That she won by more than 15 seconds, after the birth and the retirement and a broken collarbone, surprised even Armstrong.

headline: Corrections
summary: An obituary on Monday about the television journalist Mike Wallace referred incorrectly to an interview he conducted for the CBS News program ''60 Minutes'' with the chemist Jeffrey Wigand, who said tobacco executives had lied when they testified before Congress that they believed nicotine was not addictive. While CBS did not broadcast the interview in November 1995 as originally scheduled, it did indeed broadcast it three months later; it is not the case that ''the interview was not broadcast.'' The obituary also misstated the year when ''60 Minutes'' moved to its longtime time slot, Sunday nights at 7. It was 1975, not 1970.

headline: Tonys Ceremony Is Set
summary: The 66th annual Tony Awards ceremony will be held on Sunday, June 10, at the Beacon Theater in New York and broadcast live on CBS, organizers of the ceremony announced on Tuesday. The Tonys are the best-known awards for Broadway musicals and plays, voted on by hundreds of producers, tour presenters, directors and others in the theater industry. (Off Broadway and regional shows are not eligible.) The organizers also set April 26 as the cutoff date for Broadway shows to open and be eligible for Tony nominations and awards; the nominations are expected to be announced the week of April 30. This is a more complete version of the story than the one that appeared in print.

headline: Times Minute | Clinton’s 2016 Numbers
summary: Former first lady Hillary Clinton is the popular choice among Democrats in a New York Times/CBS News poll. Also on the Minute, the future for troops in Afghanistan and the growing trend of "phablets."

headline: Paid Notice: Deaths KUTRZEBA-FAJWISZYS, JOSEPH S.
summary: KUTRZEBA-FAJWISZYS-- Joseph S., 85. Born in Poland, died January 24 in New York City. Holocaust survivor. In United States Army, Korea. Five decorations, Two Battle Stars. MFA Yale University, PhD and faculty NYU. CBS TV, United Nations Radio. Founder Queens Playhouse. Tony nomination for "The Lieutenant. New York Film and TV award "Children in the Holocaust." Author "Contract- A Life for a Life."

headline: Tony Winners Gain At Ticket Window, Too
summary: The Broadway musicals ''Once,'' ''Newsies,'' and ''The Gershwins' Porgy and Bess'' all had stronger ticket sales than usual on Monday after their respective wins and televised performance numbers at the Tony Awards on Sunday night, according to publicists for the productions or theater executives familiar with the sales. ''Once,'' which won the best musical Tony and seven others, was on track to sell five times its usual number of tickets on Monday, by far its best day since performances began in February. ''Newsies,'' which won for best score and choreography, was selling almost twice as many tickets as usual. And ''Porgy and Bess,'' which won for best musical revival and best actress in a musical (Audra McDonald), had ''one of its best days since opening'' in January, Jeffrey Richards, a producer of the show, said. Other shows were hoping to rebound from shutouts at the Tonys. The revival of ''Godspell'' didn't have any Tony nominations but did get to stage a number on the CBS telecast, and the producer Ken Davenport said on Monday that he hoped that visibility would yield more ticket sales. ''Godspell'' has been struggling; last week the show grossed its lowest amount, $156,437, since performances began in October. Mr. Davenport, who had said he would close the musical on June 24 if ticket sales did not pick up, said on Monday that he would make a decision on a closing notice soon. Another play, Nicky Silver's comedy ''The Lyons,'' lost its one shot at a Tony on Sunday: best actress in a play for Linda Lavin. ''The Lyons'' has been among the lowest-grossing plays this spring, but a spokesman said on Monday that there were no plans to close it.

headline: New Lineup at E!
summary: The E! network announced an ambitious lineup of original programming Monday, including a new singing competition from one of the producers of ''American Idol,'' a relationship show with a Jonas brother (and his wife), and a weekly talk show with the comedian Whitney Cummings, which could raise questions about the future of her NBC sitcom. The channel also signaled that it intends to enter the arena of scripted series for the first time, announcing a list of shows in development for 2013, including several from top creative names, like producers John Wells and Phillip Noyce, and the actor Kevin Spacey.

headline: Shake-Up in Co-Hosts of CBS's Morning Show
summary: CBS on Thursday shuffled the deck of its six-month-old morning show, replacing Erica Hill with Norah O'Donnell, the network's chief White House correspondent. The casting change came as a surprise to staff members of ''CBS This Morning,'' the network's latest effort to create a competitive morning show. The CBS News executives who orchestrated the change said they felt that Ms. O'Donnell was a perfect fit for the co-host role, particularly given the current busy period of political news. She will join the other two co-hosts, Charlie Rose and Gayle King, in the early fall, they said.

headline: Paid Notice: Deaths SWING, MARLIN G.
summary: SWING--Marlin G., passed away peacefully on October 10th in New York City. He was a graduate of the Cincinnati Conservatory of Music and received his Masters degree from Columbia University. He taught classes in Harmony and Theory at Mannes College and later joined CBS Radio Network, where he spent 40 years as a producer and director of dramatic shows. After his retirement he returned to CBS at the request of Walter Cronkite where they worked on many shows together. During his time at CBS he was also Assistant Director of CBS Radio Mystery Theater as well as its Music Director. He will be greatly missed by his many friends and colleagues. There are no immediate survivors. At this time there are no plans for a public service. Goodbye beloved old friend.

headline: What's On Sunday
summary: 8 P.M. (CBS) THE 54TH ANNUAL GRAMMY AWARDS ''Music's Biggest Night'' pulls out the stops with performances by Glen Campbell, this year's recipient of the Recording Academy Lifetime Achievement Award, who will be joined by the Band Perry and Blake Shelton. The program also features Adele, who will sing live for the first time since her surgery five months ago; Paul McCartney, the 2012 MusiCares Person of the Year; Alicia Keys and Bonnie Raitt, in a tribute to Etta James; Chris Brown, Deadmaus, the Foo Fighters, David Guetta and Lil Wayne in a salute to electronica music; and the Beach Boys, who will reunite after more than two decades of not performing together live, backed up by Maroon 5 and Foster the People. Kanye West leads the nominations with seven, followed by Adele, the Foo Fighters and Bruno Mars with six, and Lil Wayne and Skrillex with five. L L Cool J, above with Taylor Swift, hosts this ceremony, broadcast from the Staples Center in Los Angeles. ''Countdown to the Red Carpet'' will be shown at 5 and ''Live From the Red Carpet'' at 6, both on E! 10 A.M. (ABC) THIS WEEK WITH GEORGE STEPHANOPOULOS The Republican presidential candidate Rick Santorum talks about his victories in Colorado, Minnesota and Missouri, and how he intends to maintain momentum. Jack Lew, the White House chief of staff, discusses the economic recovery, the White House budget and tension with Syria and Iran. Mr. Lew will also appear with Sarah Palin on ''Fox News Sunday With Chris Wallace,'' at 10; with Mr. Santorum on ''Meet the Press,'' at 10:30 on NBC; and with the Republican presidential candidate Representative Ron Paul of Texas on ''Face the Nation,'' at 10:30 on CBS.

headline: Paid Notice: Deaths ROSENBAUM, MICHAEL
summary: ROSENBAUM--Michael, 64, on May 17. Family, friends, the journalism community and Cornell classmates mourn the loss of this award-winning CBS News producer. He rose from cub reporter at the Rochester Democrat & Chronicle to a distinguished 27-year career with CBS News, including as producer for the Evening News, Tel Aviv bureau chief and producer for 60 Minutes. He worked closely with Dan Rather and Bob Simon. Jeff Fager, chairman of CBS News, said Michael was â€œskeptical of almost everything.â€ His 1996 interview with Ethel Rosenberg's brother, who said he lied in testimony that helped send his sister to the electric chair, won Michael his fourth Emmy. He died peacefully at home in Manhattan after a brain tumor diagnosed in September. He is survived by his brother, David, of Los Angeles, sister, Judy Witt of Evanston, Ill., nephews Adam and Daniel Rosenbaum, niece Abby Witt and many loving friends. Services: 10:30am, Monday, Congregation Rodeph Shalom, 7 West 83d St., NYC.

headline: Abortion and Akin Off-Limits
summary: It's the sort of statement that leaves journalists slack-jawed: ''The one stipulation to the interview was that I not ask him about abortion or Todd Akin.'' That's what Mitt Romney's campaign demanded, said Shaun Boyd, a reporter for the CBS-owned television station in Denver, when she interviewed the Republican presidential candidate on Thursday. Ms. Boyd was one of four Denver reporters to be granted five minutes with the candidate via satellite, and the only reporter to tell viewers about any preset restrictions.

headline: Paid Notice: Deaths CHOOK, PAUL H.
summary: CHOOK--Paul H., of Forest Hills, NY passed away on May 23, 2014 in Brooklyn, NY. Paul's professional career spanned a period of over 40 years in the advertising and publishing business. He specialized in marketing and advertising research to guide planners in media evaluation and advertising development. Paul served as President of Alfred Politz Media Studies, President of W.R. Simmons Research, Vice President of Young & Rubicam, and Executive Vice President of Ziff-Davis Publishing and the CBS Magazine Division. Paul was a Director and Board Chairman of the Advertising Research Foundation, a member of the Market Research Council and was elected to the MRC Hall of Fame. He is an alumnus of Columbia University in (Graduate School of Business) and of the City College of New York (Baruch School) where he also taught undergraduate and graduate courses in statistical methods and analysis over a period of 12 years. Funeral services will be held Sunday, May 25, 2014 12 noon, at Schwartz Bros.-Jeffer Memorial Chapels 114-03 Queens Blvd (at 76 Road) Forest Hills, NY.
