headline: Recent Sublease
summary: $40/SQUARE FOOT $182,400 approximate annual rent

headline: What's On Sunday
summary: 9 P.M. (MTV, Logo, VH1) 2013 MTV MOVIE AWARDS Rebel Wilson (above right, with Channing Tatum) hosts this ceremony, broadcast live from the Sony Pictures Studio in Culver City, Calif. The awards bestow Golden Popcorn statuettes on winners in “best” categories like kiss, villain, fight and shirtless performance. Jamie Foxx will be presented with the annual MTV Generation Award; Will Ferrell will be honored with the first Comedic Genius Award; and Emma Watson is the Trailblazer Award recipient. Presenters include Brad Pitt, Peter Dinklage, Steve Carell, Zac Efron, Kerry Washington, Seth Rogen, Chris Rock, Adam Sandler and Kim Kardashian. Macklemore and Ryan Lewis, Selena Gomez and the cast of “Pitch Perfect” are scheduled to perform. 10 A.M. (Fox) FOX NEWS SUNDAY Senator Marco Rubio, Republican of Florida and a member of the bipartisan Senate group known as the Gang of Eight, discusses the group’s plan for comprehensive immigration reform. He also appears on “This Week,” at 10 on ABC; “Face the Nation,” at 10:30 on CBS; and “Meet the Press,” at 10:30 on NBC.

headline: Paid Notice: Deaths CHOOK, PAUL H.
summary: CHOOK--Paul H.,of Forest Hills, NY passed away on May 23, 2014 in Brooklyn, NY. Paul's professional career spanned a period of over 40 years in the advertising and publishing business. He specialized in marketing and advertising research to guide planners in media evaluation and advertising development. Paul served as President of Alfred Politz Media Studies, President of W.R. Simmons Research, Vice President of Young & Rubicam, and Executive Vice President of Ziff-Davis Publishing and the CBS Magazine Division. Paul was a Director and Board Chairman of the Advertising Research Foundation, a member of the Market Research Council and was elected to the MRC Hall of Fame. He is an alumnus of Columbia University in (Graduate School of Business) and of the City College of New York (Baruch School) where he also taught undergraduate and graduate courses in statistical methods and analysis over a period of 12 years. Funeral services will be held Sunday, May 25, 2014 12 noon, at Schwartz Bros.-Jeffer Memorial Chapels 114-03 Queens Blvd (at 76 Road) Forest Hills, NY.

headline: What's On Today
summary: 7:30 P.M. (Showtime) THE HELP (2011) Skeeter (Emma Stone), an aspiring writer from a prominent family in early 1960s Mississippi, causes an uproar in her community when she interviews black female servants in this adaptation of the Kathryn Stockett novel, directed and written by Tate Taylor. Viola Davis earned a best actress Oscar nomination for her portrayal of Aibileen, a maid who has raised several of the town's white babies. Octavia Spencer (above right, with Ms. Davis) won for best supporting actress as Aibileen's best friend, Minny, who endures soul-killing work for Hilly (Bryce Dallas Howard), a housewife who believes in white superiority. And Cicely Tyson is Constantine, the woman who raised Skeeter -- and who inspires her former charge's journey of discovery. Writing in The New York Times, Manohla Dargis called this best picture nominee a ''big, ole slab of honey-glazed hokum.'' The movie's ''vision of a divided America that while consistently insulting and sometimes even terrifying, is rarely grotesque, despite Hilly's best (worst) segregationist efforts,'' she added. ''Inside all these different homes, black and white women tend to the urgent matters of everyday life, like the care and feeding of children. And while every so often the roar of the outside world steals in like thunder, Mr. Taylor makes sure it doesn't rattle the china or your soul.'' 8 P.M. (HBO) SOMETHING BORROWED (2011) Ginnifer Goodwin stars as Rachel, a New York lawyer who imagines herself a wallflower until, on her 30th birthday, she finally ends up in bed with her longtime crush, Dex (Colin Egglesfield). Kate Hudson is Darcy, a brassy blond bombshell and Rachel's lifelong best friend -- and the woman Dex happens to be engaged to. ''The contrast between Darcy and Rachel is a bit overdrawn, but it should have given the conflict between them at least a hint of comic snap,'' A. O. Scott wrote in The Times about this film, adapted by Luke Greenfield from the novel by Emily Giffin. ''And the premise should have been a surefire recipe for farce, especially when everyone piles into a summer share in the Hamptons.'' Why this film ''should be so cautious and tepid,'' Mr. Scott said, ''is a puzzle.''

headline: An Autobiography From Clive Davis
summary: Read! About how Bruce Springsteen and Bob Dylan were persuaded in the making and marketing of classic albums. Gasp! At how Janis Joplin wanted to celebrate the signing of her deal with Columbia Records.

headline: Paid Notice: Deaths ROSENBAUM, MICHAEL
summary: ROSENBAUM--Michael, 64, on May 17. Family, friends, the journalism community and Cornell classmates mourn the loss of this award-winning CBS News producer. He rose from cub reporter at the Rochester Democrat & Chronicle to a distinguished 27-year career with CBS News, including as producer for the Evening News, Tel Aviv bureau chief and producer for 60 Minutes. He worked closely with Dan Rather and Bob Simon. Jeff Fager, chairman of CBS News, said Michael was skeptical of almost everything. His 1996 interview with Ethel Rosenberg's brother, who said he lied in testimony that helped send his sister to the electric chair, won Michael his fourth Emmy. He died peacefully at home in Manhattan after a brain tumor diagnosed in September. He is survived by his brother, David, of Los Angeles, sister, Judy Witt of Evanston, Ill., nephews Adam and Daniel Rosenbaum, niece Abby Witt and many loving friends. Services: 10:30am, Monday, Congregation Rodeph Shalom, 7 West 83d St., NYC.

headline: Best Sellers: Hardcover Nonfiction: Sunday, June 17th 2012
summary: About the Best Sellers: These lists are an expanded version of those appearing in the June 17, 2012 print edition of the Book Review, reflecting sales for the week ending June 2, 2012. An asterisk (*) indicates that a book's sales are barely distinguishable from those of the book above it. A dagger (†) indicates that some retailers report receiving bulk orders. For an explanation of our methodology, visit http://www.nytimes.com/best-sellers.

headline: Best Sellers: Combined Print & E-Book Nonfiction: Sunday, June 17th 2012
summary: About the Best Sellers: These lists are an expanded version of those appearing in the June 17, 2012 print edition of the Book Review, reflecting sales for the week ending June 2, 2012. An asterisk (*) indicates that a book's sales are barely distinguishable from those of the book above it. A dagger (†) indicates that some retailers report receiving bulk orders. For an explanation of our methodology, visit http://www.nytimes.com/best-sellers.

headline: What's On Sunday
summary: 8 P.M. (BET) BET AWARDS '12 The Rev. Al Sharpton will be honored for his humanitarianism, and the band Maze, featuring Frankie Beverly, for lifetime achievement at this 12th-annual ceremony honoring excellence by African-Americans and other minorities in entertainment and sports. Samuel L. Jackson, right, hosts this event, broadcast live from the Shrine Auditorium in Los Angeles. Marsha Ambrosius, Beyoncé, Mary J. Blige, Melanie Fiona and Rihanna are nominated for best female R&B artist; Chris Brown, Bruno Mars, Miguel, Trey Songz and Usher for best male R&B artist; Big Sean, Drake, J. Cole, Lil Wayne, Rick Ross and Young Jeezy for best male hip-hop artist; Diamond, Nicki Minaj, Brianna Perry and Trina for best female hip-hop artist; and ASAP Rocky, Big Sean, Diggy, Future and Meek Mill for best new artist. Reporting from the red carpet starts at 6; an after-party follows at 11:30. 9 A.M. (CNN) STATE OF THE UNION WITH CANDY CROWLEY Ms. Crowley interviews Jacob J. Lew, the White House chief of staff, about the Supreme Court's ruling on the Affordable Care Act. Mr. Lew also appears on ''This Week With George Stephanopoulos'' alongside Victoria Kennedy, the widow of Senator Edward M. Kennedy, and Representative Paul Ryan, Republican of Wisconsin, at 10 on ABC, and on ''Fox News Sunday With Chris Wallace,'' at 10, where Senator Mitch McConnell, Republican of Kentucky, will discuss his party's efforts to repeal the Affordable Care Act.

headline: Never Too Late to Find His Brigadoon
summary: LOS ANGELES -- In his seven years as host of ''The Late Late Show'' on CBS, Craig Ferguson has had many an unusual broadcast, whether it was an episode partly lighted by flashlight when his studio lost power or an evening dedicated to the BBC science-fiction series ''Doctor Who.'' But until now Mr. Ferguson had never taken his show to Scotland, his home country. Following in the tradition of a series of ''Late Late Show'' episodes filmed in Paris last year, Mr. Ferguson traveled to Scotland in March, taking along his robot sidekick, Geoff Peterson, a team of celebrity pals like Mila Kunis, Rashida Jones, Michael Clarke Duncan and David Sedaris, and, wisest of all, some cameras to film his journeys there.

headline: Obama 'Super PAC' Runs Anti-Romney Ad
summary: The ''super PAC'' supporting President Obama is out with its first commercial this year, being broadcast in Michigan, and it highlights Mitt Romney's opposition to the federal loan program that helped rescue General Motors and Chrysler. ''His message was clear,'' an announcer says as the ad cuts to a brief sound bite of Mr. Romney saying ''Let Detroit go bankrupt.'' The end of that sound bite - where Mr. Romney utters ''bankrupt'' - is repeated three separate times with the audio amplified to create an echo effect.

headline: What's On Sunday
summary: 9 P.M. (MTV, Logo, VH1) 2012 MTV MOVIE AWARDS Russell Brand, above, hosts this show, broadcast live from the Gibson Theater in Universal City, Calif., which bestows the Golden Popcorn statuettes on winners in ''best'' categories like kiss, villain, fight, jaw-dropping moment and breakout star. New ''bests'' include hero, on-screen transformation, gut-wrenching performance and on-screen dirtbag. Johnny Depp will be honored with the MTV Generation Award. Presenters include Adam Sandler, Emma Watson, Leighton Meester, Emma Stone, Andrew Garfield, Charlize Theron, Michael Fassbender and Matthew McConaughey. The director Christopher Nolan and the actors Christian Bale, Joseph Gordon-Levitt and Gary Oldman will be on hand for a preview of their film ''The Dark Knight Rises.'' Performers include the Black Keys, in a rendition of their single ''Gold in the Ceiling''; Fun., in a tribute to the greatest party films of all time; and the rapper Wiz Khalifa. Martin Solveig will be the house D.J. Ashton Kutcher will punk Kim Kardashian and Drake in a preparty at 8. The Season 2 premiere of ''Teen Wolf'' follows at 11. 8:30 A.M. (BBC AMERICA); 9 A.M. (Fox News Channel); 11 A.M. (CNN) QUEEN ELIZABETH II'S DIAMOND JUBILEE Britain celebrates the 60-year reign of Queen Elizabeth -- only Victoria ruled longer -- as a flotilla of more than 1,000 boats adorned with streamers and Union Jacks sails down the Thames. On BBC America, a marathon of tell-alls, including ''William & Kate: The First Year,'' at 7 p.m., leads up to ''The Diamond Queen,'' at 8, in which Andrew Marr interviews royals and Prime Minster David Cameron to analyze the effect of the royal family on British trade and international relations. At 9, C-Span will broadcast the arrival of the queen, above, at Parliament, where the speakers of the House of Commons and the House of Lords will pay tribute to the occasion, and she will offer comments in return. And at 4:15 a.m. on Tuesday on BBC America, early risers can catch the queen and Prince Philip as they attend a service of thanksgiving at St. Paul's Cathedral, followed by a carriage procession.

headline: If Disney Owns It, Comcast Will Soon Be Streaming It
summary: 1/5/12 | Updated In a deal that represents billions of dollars in revenue for the Walt Disney Company, the entertainment giant and Comcast said Wednesday that they had reached a decade-long distribution agreement covering all of Disney's television content, including streaming for iPads and other devices. The unusually long-term agreement provides a window into the future of television viewing and how its content will be consumed. Comcast, the nation's largest cable provider, will gain the rights to provide the Disney Channel, ESPN, Disney XD, ABC Family and the ABC broadcast network, among other Disney-owned services, to subscribers wherever they want to watch.

headline: Paid Notice: Deaths LISANBY, CHARLES ALVIN JR.
summary: LISANBY--Charles Alvin Jr.,passed away peacefully in the presence of his family in Los Angeles, California, on August 23, 2013, at the age of 89. Mr. Lisanby had a seven decade career in the arts and entertainment industry, marked by 16 Emmy Nominations and three Wins for Baryshnikov on Broadway, Ben Franklin, The Ambassador - mini series, and (Barry) Manilow: Big Fun on Swing Street. Born in Princeton, KY, Mr. Lisanby arrived in New York City at the age of 16 to pursue art studies and an apprenticeship with the legendary Broadway and Film Art Director, Cecil Beaton. Following a stint in the Army, he landed a position at CBS and later at ABC as their first Art Director. He worked on many variety shows including the Garry Moore Show, where Carol Burnett, among others got their start. In fact, it was Charles who recommended Ms. Burnett to Moore's producer, Bob Banner. Bob Banner, hired Charles for many variety shows, for Alan King, Paul Lynde, Bob Hope, Kathy Lee Gifford, Barry Manilow, Barbra Streisand, Carol Burnett and Julie Andrews, Mikhail Baryshnikov, and Diana Ross. Twelve of his musical specials won Emmys for best Variety Show. He did multiple Motion Picture Academy Awards Shows, the Grammys, and the first MTV Awards shows. Commercial producers also reached out to Mr. Lisanby to design, the CLIO award winning original, Merrill Lynch "bull" commercials, and seven Dr. Pepper commercials and the Panasonic "hands" commercials. He was the designer of Radio City's Christmas Show from '78 thru '95 and the full run of their Easter show during that period. His one act play adaptation of "Christmas Carol" ran for seven years at Radio City. Commencing in 1980, he was the designer of the Crystal Cathedral's Christmas and Easter Productions for their entire run. Mr. Lisanby wrote an original musical entitled, "Family Tree", which became the basis for the musical, "Children of Eden" with lyrics and music by Stephen Schwartz. He also wrote the title and dialogue for Andy Warhol's, "25 Cats Name Sam & One Blue Pussy," which earned both of them their first copyrighted work. Charles has been honored by the Art Directors Guild at the Museum of Television and Radio, the Television Academy with his election to their Hall of Fame as the first in his peer group, Production Designers/ Art Directors and a display of a major body of his designs at the Los Angeles Main Public Library in Getty Hall. Mr. Lisanby is survived by his nieces, Dr. Sarah Hollingsworth Lisanby of Durham, NC, Mrs. Elizabeth Ann Lisanby Bianchi of Huntsville, AL; his sister-in-law, Mrs. Gladys Elnora Kemp Lisanby of Princeton, KY; and his partner Mr. Richard Bostard. He is preceded in death by his brother, Rear Admiral James Walker Lisanby, USN Ret, and his parents Rebecca Hollingsworth Lisanby and Charles Alvin Lisanby, Sr. Funeral services will be held at 3pm on Sunday, September 1st, at Morgan's Funeral Home at 301 W Washington St Princeton, KY 42445 Princeton, KY. In lieu of flowers, memorial donations may be made to the Charles Lisanby Center Checks should be made to: JMU Foundation -- Charles Lisanby Center, Mailing address: James Madison University, Advancement Gifts and Records, MSC 3603, 220 University Blvd., Harrisonburg VA 22807.

headline: 'The Voice' Is Heard
summary: Riding its post Super Bowl send-off, NBC's singing competition ''The Voice'' exploded out of the gate in its first regular edition Monday night, squashing even the enormously popular CBS lineup of comedies. NBC got what might be called mixed results for its hugely anticipated new drama, ''Smash.'' The show dissipated a large portion of the ''Voice'' audience, but still managed to hit the best rating for any 10 p.m. drama on any network this season.

headline: Paid Notice: Deaths SMITH, OPHELIA MARIE
summary: SMITH--Ophelia Marie, Cherished sister of Amelia Kaye Byer and Claude Byer, devoted aunt of Ernestine and David Byer-Tyre, LaVonne and Aaron Brown, Claudia, Constance and Janiya Byer-Tyre; loving cousin of Valerie Gresham; and beloved colleague of the board and staff of Win (Women In Need, Inc.). Born in New Bern North Carolina, Ophelia held a Ph.D. in Clinical Psychology from Columbia University as well as a BA in German and BM in Piano Performance from Oberlin College and Conservatory. After an early multidisciplinary career in recording, publishing and corporate divisions at CBS, she shifted gears to helping New York's most in need, becoming the Director of the Continuing Care Clinic at Fordham-Tremont Community Mental Health Clinic. In 1996, she came to Win as Vice President for Client Services where she led all program services overseeing administrative and organizational development activities for the more than 200 division staff employees who serve more than 10,000 women and children each year in Win's transitional family homeless shelters, supportive housing and alcohol and substance abuse clinic. She worked tirelessly to help homeless and distressed women and their families achieve independence and lead more fulfilling lives by guiding innovative holistic programming. Under her direction, Win opened seven family homeless shelters and one women's shelter in New York City. Most recently Dr. Smith led the team that conceptualized and developed Win Academy. She has helped well over 100,000 clients during her tenure at Win. A Celebration of Life will be held at The Church of the Holy Apostles, 296 Ninth Ave, New York, NY (at 28th St) on Saturday, November 23rd at 10:00am. The family asks that in lieu of flowers donations be made to Win (Women In Need) 115 West 31st St. NYC 10001 or Abhyasa Ashram Yoga and Meditation Center, 505 Hooper Drive, Ft. Walton Beach, FL 32548.

headline: Political Memo: Social Issues Return to Dominant Role in National Debate
summary: Rick Santorum creates a stir by speaking out against prenatal testing. Virginia's governor and legislature get caught up in an emotional debate over requiring women seeking abortions to undergo an ultrasound. President Obama, under pressure, recalibrates his position on health-insurance coverage of contraception for employers with religious affiliations. Social issues are back with a vengeance, dominating the dialogue on the presidential campaign trail, in Congress and in state capitals.

headline: 'Tonight Show' Lays Off 20, And Leno Takes Salary Cut
summary: The NBC network on Friday instituted budget cuts at ''The Tonight Show,'' a television mainstay that has played home to Jack Paar, Johnny Carson and now Jay Leno.Between 20 and 25 ''Tonight'' staff members were laid off, according to a person with direct knowledge of the cuts, who spoke on the condition of anonymity because the details of the restructuring are private. To stave off additional staff reductions, Mr. Leno took a sizable pay cut, said the person, who would not specify the amount. Some producers also agreed to salary reductions in order to keep their jobs, according to Deadline Hollywood, which earlier reported news of the cutbacks .

headline: Tuning In: Fox Wins Convention Viewers
summary: TAMPA, Fla. - More than 20 million people tuned in to the Republican National Convention on Tuesday night, and more of them watched on Fox News than on any other channel by far. According to preliminary ratings, 6.9 million people tuned in to Fox News from 10 to 11 p.m., the hour that featured the evening's major speeches, by Ann Romney and Gov. Chris Christie of New Jersey.

headline: Paid Notice: Deaths SMITH, OPHELIA M.

Walton Beach, FL 32548.

headline: What's On Sunday
summary: 9 P.M. (13, 49) SHERLOCK, SERIES 2: A SCANDAL IN BELGRAVIA Benedict Cumberbatch and Martin Freeman (above from left) reprise their roles as Sherlock Holmes and Dr. John Watson for the 21st century in this ''Masterpiece Mystery!'' presentation. The sleuthing begins as they plunge into a case of blackmail involving the clever dominatrix Irene Adler (Lara Pulver), whose motto is ''know when you are beaten.'' It seems she has performed some ''recreational scolding'' on a British royal -- and she has the photographs to prove it. Now she's trying to trump Holmes at his own game. 10 A.M. (ABC) THIS WEEK WITH GEORGE STEPHANOPOULOS David Axelrod, the senior adviser to the Obama campaign, and Senator John McCain, Republican of Arizona, discuss the latest jobs report, the diplomatic crisis over the Chinese dissident Chen Guangcheng and whether the White House has taken too much credit for the killing of Osama bin Laden.

headline: New Poll Finds Voters Dubious of Obama's Announcement on Same-Sex Marriage
summary: WASHINGTON -- Most Americans suspect that President Obama was motivated by politics, not policy, when he declared his support for same-sex marriage, according to a new poll released on Monday, suggesting that the unplanned way it was announced shaped public attitudes. Sixty-seven percent of those surveyed by The New York Times and CBS News since the announcement said they thought that Mr. Obama had made it ''mostly for political reasons,'' while 24 percent said it was ''mostly because he thinks it is right.'' Independents were more likely to attribute it to politics, with nearly half of Democrats agreeing.

headline: CBS Profit Sets Quarterly Record, Though TV Revenue Falls
summary: The CBS Corporation reported record operating income for the second quarter of 2012, even though overall revenue declined slightly from a year ago because of shifts in television programming schedules and a decline in digital sales. The company on Thursday reported $769 million in operating income for the three months ended June 30. That was a 5 percent increase over the same period last year and the highest second quarter for CBS since it was established as a separate entity from Viacom six years ago.

headline: Museum Plans Program On Kovacs and Adams
summary: The poet Percy Dovetonsils, disc jockey Wolfgang von Sauerbraten, magician Matzoh Hepplewhite and storyteller Auntie Gruesome are getting a retrospective at the Museum of the Moving Image - and so, too, are Ernie Kovacs, who portrayed these characters, and Edie Adams, his wife and frequent co-star, who appeared with him in several pioneering television series of the 1950s and 60s. The museum said on Wednesday that it will host a month-long program, running from April 27 through May 27, honoring Kovacs and Adams, whose innovative character skits and comedy pieces influenced any number of self-aware, self-referential performers and shows, including David Letterman, ''Sesame Street'' and Pee-wee Herman.

headline: Pakistan Is Razing House Where Bin Laden Lived
summary: ISLAMABAD -- The Pakistani authorities moved on Saturday to demolish the house where Osama bin Laden died at the hands of Navy SEALs last May, erasing a three-story building that had acquired a painful symbolism for Pakistan's powerful military, which was badly embarrassed by the American raid. Working by floodlight, heavy machinery operators broke through the tall perimeter wall of the 3,000 square-meter compound in Abbottabad, 35 miles north of Islamabad, after dark on Saturday. Hours later, they started to knock down the main house where Bin Laden had lived with his family and three smaller buildings.

headline: Mort Lindsey, 89, Pianist And Versatile Bandleader
summary: Mort Lindsey, who led Merv Griffin's television orchestra, accompanied Barbra Streisand on the piano in Central Park and played with Judy Garland in her celebrated comeback concert at Carnegie Hall, died on May 4 at his home in Malibu, Calif. He was 89. The cause was complications of a broken hip, his son Steve said.

headline: Paid Notice: Deaths PREDIGER, CRAIG R.
summary: PREDIGER--Craig R.,on August 1, 2013. Beloved husband of Sarah Shafer Prediger. Devoted father of Catherine Brady Prediger. Dear son of the late Marion Rudolph Prediger and Lindsley Prediger. B.A., Hillsdale College, 1969. Researcher, producer, documentarian for Newsweek, CBS, NBC, MSNBC, Sony Music and History Channel. Proud son of the American Revolution. Reposing at Walter B. Cooke Funeral Home 352 East 87th Street NYC Monday 3-5pm and 6-9pm. Funeral Mass St. Ignatius Loyola RCC Tuesday 10:30am. In lieu of flowers, contributions to Hillsdale College Marion Prediger Journalism Award or St. Ignatius Loyola School will be appreciated.

headline: Political Sex Scandals Onstage in 'Tail! Spin!'
summary: When politics and sex meet it makes for great political theater. This summer they'll be theater when Mo Rocca (''CBS Sunday Morning''), Rachel Dratch (''Saturday Night Live'') and Sean Dugan (''Smash'') take the stage in ''Tail! Spin!'' -- a verbatim recitation of steamy e-mails, texts, interviews and Twitter messages that surfaced during recent political sex scandals. The show, created by the NPR contributor Mario Correa, is scheduled to play five performances, from Aug. 11-16, at the Kraine Theater as part of the 2012 New York International Fringe Festival. Directed by the Tony nominee Dan Knechtges (''Lysistrata Jones''), ''Tail! Spin!'' focuses on the sexual transgressions of four American politicians: Mark Sanford, the former governor of South Carolina who admitted to having an affair with a lover he had met while on vacation in Argentina; Larry E. Craig, a former Republican senator from Idaho who was caught in an undercover sex sting; and two former United States congressmen, Anthony Weiner of New York, who resigned over lewd online behavior, and Mark Foley of Florida, who resigned after he was caught sending sexually explicit texts to teenage Capitol Hill pages. The cast will portray some 30 different roles, including members of the media and the politicians' paramours and relatives.

headline: Paid Notice: Deaths PREDIGER, CRAIG R.
summary: PREDIGER--Craig R., on August 1, 2013. Beloved husband of Sarah Shafer Prediger. Devoted father of Catherine Brady Prediger. Dear son of the late Marion Rudolph Prediger and Lindsley Prediger. B.A., Hillsdale College, 1969. Researcher, producer, documentarian for Newsweek, CBS, NBC, MSNBC, Sony Music and History Channel. Proud son of the American Revolution. Reposing at Walter B. Cooke Funeral Home 352 East 87th Street NYC Monday 3-5pm and 6-9pm. Funeral Mass St. Ignatius Loyola RCC Tuesday 10:30am. In lieu of flowers, contributions to Hillsdale College Marion Prediger Journalism Award or St. Ignatius Loyola School will be appreciated.

headline: Romney's Former Rivals Speak Out on Bain Attacks
summary: Republicans have been assailing President Obama and his re-election team for days for pointedly - and they say unfairly -- questioning the private equity experience of Mitt Romney. But on Sunday, three prominent Republicans were called to answer for their own past criticisms of the former Massachusetts governor. Rudolph W. Giuliani, the former New York mayor and a rival of Mr. Romney's in the 2008 Republican presidential primary, had painted a dim picture during that campaign of the former governor's economic policies and the health care program he put in place in Massachusetts.

headline: Fond Memories at That 'Deluxe Apartment in the Sky'
summary: Officially, the high-rise at 185 East 85th Street has a name: Park Lane Towers. ''But nobody calls it that,'' said Rod Behren, who has lived there for more than a decade. ''The de facto name of the building is 'the Jeffersons' building.' You meet people. They say, 'Where do you live?' You say, '85th and Third.' They say, 'Oh, the Jeffersons' building.' ''

headline: Million-Dollar Chorus For Obama Tax Plan
summary: Wednesday's installment of President Obama's running campaign to raise the taxes of millionaires featured a group of wealthy people who agree with him, standing at his side as he professed that the idea is popular among the gilded elite from Warren Buffett on down. ''The people who've joined me here today are extremely successful,'' Mr. Obama said during an appearance in the White House complex.

headline: David Simon and What He Thinks About the 'Wire' Fandom, Late Adopters or Early
summary: It seemed like a good idea to check in with David Simon. As a reporter whose book was the basis of the NBC series ''Homicide: Life on the Street'' and as the creator of the HBO series ''The Wire,'' he might have some pertinent things to say about his friend Richard Price's new show, ''NYC 22'' on CBS. Mr. Simon had hired Mr. Price, the author of ''Clockers'' and other novels, to write for ''The Wire,'' and we thought Mr. Simon would understand the differences involved in writing a cop show for cable and one for broadcast. But when the conversation wound back to ''The Wire,'' four years after that endlessly exalted show went off the air, a controversy was born. In the interview, for ArtsBeat, we mentioned that Mr. Price had said that though many people praise ''The Wire'' now, at the time the show was broadcast it didn't draw many viewers and almost couldn't get a Season 4, much less a Season 5.

headline: Paid Notice: Deaths ENGER, PAUL
summary: ENGER--Paul, 86, retired newsman, playwright and co-founder of a soup kitchen for the homeless, died November 29, 2013. Born in Fargo, ND, Paul graduated from the University of Minnesota, began a career as a newspaper reporter in his hometown, worked for UPI and CBS News in New York. There he wrote for evening anchors Walter Cronkite and Dan Rather. He also wrote for Good Morning America and All My Children on ABC-TV, as well as scripts for A&E Cable and The History Channel. He holds three awards from the Writers Guild of America and is the recipient of the International Radio NY Festival Gold Award. Paul authored nine full-length plays, including "Vestigial Parts" and "Harmon and Ruth." His works have been performed Off Broadway as well as in Massachusetts, Florida, Arizona, California and Indiana. His most recent play, "Benefit Performance," a play with songs written with Tom Ferriter and Michael Valenti is slated for production at Stageplays Theatre in the coming season. Paul was an active member of Holy Trinity Lutheran Church on West 65th Street in Manhattan, where he co-founded HUG, a soup kitchen program for homeless men and women, and assisted in planning the Bach Vespers program. Paul, who lived in Jackson Heights, Queens, was the beloved brother of Mary K. Katz and beloved uncle of Gretchen Browne and Richard Katz. A funeral service will be held at Holy Trinity Lutheran Church on Saturday, December 7 at 9:30am. Burial will be at Riverside Cemetery in Fargo, ND. Services are under the direction of Conway Funeral Home, Jackson Heights.

headline: Glaad Grades Networks
summary: Most of the broadcast networks are satisfactorily portraying gays and lesbians on television, a leading media advocacy group said in a report released on Thursday. The Gay & Lesbian Alliance Against Defamation, in its annual check-up of sorts on the networks, found that gay characters "are increasingly presented as matter-of-fact manner rather than a curiosity" and lauded the CW in particular. But it also labeled one broadcaster, CBS, as "failing" and called for more ethnic and cultural diversity in the portrayals of gay characters.

headline: What's On Sunday
summary: 9 P.M. (ABC) A SMILE AS BIG AS THE MOON (2012) John Corbett, above, stars as Mike, a high school football coach and special-education teacher who takes a class of disabled students to NASA's Space Camp, in this Hallmark Hall of Fame presentation, based on the memoir by Mike Kersjes. Mike's inspiration: Ben (Peter ten Brink), a boy with Down syndrome who dreams of becoming an astronaut. Jessy Schram plays Robynn McKinney, a fellow teacher who helps Mike buck the opposition of school administrators. And Cynthia Watros is Dr. Deborah Barnhart, the Space Camp official who is skeptical that Mike's class will be able to hold its own with some of the brightest science students from across the country. The cast includes young actors with Down syndrome, autism and learning disabilities. 9 A.M. (CNN) STATE OF THE UNION WITH CANDY CROWLEY Ms. Crowley interviews the Republican presidential candidate Ron Paul. Rick Scott, the Republican governor of Florida, offers a preview of Tuesday's primary. Carlos Gutierrez, a former commerce secretary, and Antonio Villaraigosa, the mayor of Los Angeles, talk about the Latino vote. And Senator Mitch McConnell, Republican of Kentucky, responds to the State of the Union address.

headline: At News Corp., A Plan to Sever Publishing Arm
summary: After years of defending its financially underperforming newspapers, News Corporation is now in talks to break up the company and sever its publishing assets, like The Wall Street Journal, The Times of London and The New York Post, from its lucrative entertainment units. The spinoff proposal will be reviewed by the News Corporation board on Wednesday and a decision to split up the company could be made as early as Thursday.

headline: Romney Backs Israeli Position On Facing Iran
summary: JERUSALEM -- Mitt Romney said Sunday that preventing Iran from obtaining nuclear capability should be America's ''highest national security priority,'' stressing that ''no option should be excluded'' in the effort. ''We have a solemn duty and a moral imperative to deny Iran's leaders the means to follow through on their malevolent intentions,'' Mr. Romney, the presumptive Republican presidential nominee, told an audience of about 300, including a large contingent of American donors who flew here to accompany him. ''We must not delude ourselves into thinking that containment is an option.''

headline: Paid Notice: Deaths LANIN, MIKE
summary: LANIN--Mike. President of Howard Lanin Productions passed away in New York on April 14, 2014 at age 90. In 1952 Mike hired a 22-year old conductor for a nationwide Gershwin concert tour that ran for two seasons (1952-54) and played in 170 cities. His name: Lorin Maazel. It was the only orchestra in history dedicated exclusively to the music of one composer. Mike pursued his interest in George Gershwin in collaboration with Michael Feinstein. Mike, a well-known producer of shows for large corporations (IBM, Coca Cola, CBS, AT&T) hired star performers such as Harry Belafonte, Tony Bennett, Liza Minnelli, Diahann Carroll, Leslie Huggams, Lena Horne, Bob Hope, Duke Ellington, Ella Fitzgerald, Ray Bolger, Doc Severinsen and Bill Cosby among others. Memorable productions Mike presented include The Royal Danish Ballet in its US debut and The Conservatory Without Walls, a glittering event in honor of the country's greatest Afro-American musicians which launched the Duke Ellington Fellowship Fund at Yale University. Mike also served on the board of The Martha Graham School of Contemporary Dance. Mike Lanin was born in Philadelphia on March, 8, 1924, the son of the band leader Howard Lanin and the nephew of Lester Lanin, the internationally known society band leader. During World War II he enlisted in the U.S. Army Air Corps. At that time he discovered a young and talented pianist, still unknown, Bobby Short. They became friends for the rest of their lives. Mike was a graduate of Yale University where he was an imaginative caricaturist for the Yale Record. He is also remembered for his fond portrayal of Orson Welles' Citizen Kane. Mike was an elegant man both in appearance and in spirit. He was always courteous, soft spoken, never one to boast of his many achievements and of his friendships with famous artists. He was a loyal friend, a witty but considerate companion with a dry sense of humor. He was an entertaining guest. Mike has been called "the dean of entertainment who pioneered the theme party, the pops concert, the anniversary revue and the multimedia production." He was an avid reader and traveler. He kept homes in New York and Paris. He is survived by his wife of 45 years, the love of his life, Yvonne Constant-Lanin, a performer herself and a frequent guest (45 times) on the Johnny Carson Show. It was always a pleasure to see how much Mike enjoyed his wife's performances. He was proud of her interpretations of French and American songs. At her recitals he would greet friends with a radiant smile. He was also proud of Yvonne having been named "Chevalier des Arts et des Lettres", an important French cultural award. Other immediate survivors include his sister, Suzanne Lande, his adopted daughter Kristina Stufano from a previous marriage, his stepson, Gerard Pinguet and numerous grandchildren.

headline: What's On Today
summary: 9 P.M. (13, 49) BEING ELMO: A PUPPETEER'S JOURNEY (2011) As a teenager in Baltimore in the 1970s Kevin Clash had a singular wish: to be a puppeteer on the team of Jim Henson, the creative force behind ''Sesame Street'' and the Muppets. Mr. Clash's dream eventually came true when he attracted the attention of the Muppet designer Kermit Love. And then one day the veteran puppeteer Richard Hunt tossed a furry red monster at him in a fit of frustration, unable to find the character's voice. Mr. Clash eventually did, and Elmo (above, with Mr. Clash), one of the world's most beloved characters, was born. ''Independent Lens'' presents this documentary, directed by Constance Marks and narrated by Whoopi Goldberg, which Neil Genzlinger, writing in The New York Times, called ''a winning tale of the persistence and creativity behind one of the most famous and fuzziest faces in the world.'' 8 P.M. (CBS) HOW I MET YOUR MOTHER Ted (Josh Radnor), Marshall (Jason Segel) and Barney (Neil Patrick Harris) watch the original ''Star Wars'' trilogy and imagine what their lives will be like in three years. In ''2 Broke Girls,'' at 8:30, Max (Kat Dennings) persuades Caroline (Beth Behrs) to take part in a clinical drug trial to raise money for her father. In ''Two and a Half Men,'' at 9, Walden (Ashton Kutcher) tells Zoey (Sophie Winkleman) that he's going into business with his ex-wife (Judy Greer). And in ''Mike & Molly,'' at 9:30, the outspokenness of Molly (Melissa McCarthy) costs her and Mike (Billy Gardell) a wedding chapel.

headline: CBS Tops Sunday
summary: In a rare instance of the Sunday night television schedule featuring no live sporting event or awards show, CBS managed to draw the most total viewers over all, thanks to the season premiere of ''The Amazing Race.'' According to preliminary Nielsen estimates the reality competition had 10.9 million total viewers, up slightly from the 10.4 million total viewers who tuned in to last year's premiere. The two-hour season premiere of ''Celebrity Apprentice'' on NBC did not fare as well, averaging 7.4 million total viewers.

headline: What's On Today
summary: NOON (Sundance) THE POOL (2008) Venkatesh (Venkatesh Chavan), an Indian teenager on the verge of manhood who ekes out a living cleaning hotel rooms and selling plastic bags on the street, becomes obsessed with the shimmering pool of a luxurious home in which no one seems to swim. Eventually he approaches the property's owner (Nana Patekar, above right, with Mr. Chavan) and becomes his assistant; the rich man, in turn, promises to become Venkatesh's benefactor if he will move from Goa to Mumbai and go to school. ''At first 'The Pool' suggests an inspirational fable in which a selfless older man rescues a youth from the streets,'' Stephen Holden wrote in The New York Times about this film by Chris Smith, adapted from a short story by Randy Russell. ''But just when you expect the film to turn into a predictable, rose-colored valentine to opportunity and hope, it goes to a deeper, more ambiguous place. Contemplating poverty from Venkatesh's perspective, it understands that his pursuit of upward mobility will require a terrifying leap of faith.'' The film was chosen as a New York Times Critics' Pick. In ''Summer Hours'' (2009), a movie from Olivier Assayas, at 1:45 p.m., Charles Berling and Juliette Binoche play Frédéric and Adrienne, siblings who must decide what to do with their mother's charming country house and cherished art collection after her death. Frédéric wants to keep everything the way it is for the enjoyment of the next generation. Adrienne and another brother (Jérémie Renier) want to sell the house and most of its contents, donating the best paintings and furnishings to the Musée d'Orsay. ''That, in a nutshell, is the dramatic arc of this extraordinary film, which, in spite of its modest scale, tactful manner and potentially dowdy subject matter, is packed nearly to bursting with rich meaning and deep implication,'' A. O. Scott wrote in The Times. 10:55 A.M. (HBO2) SOMEWHERE (2010) In the first entry in a double bill from Sofia Coppola, Johnny Marco (Stephen Dorff) is a movie star existing in a mind-numbing purgatory -- he drinks, he has anonymous sex, he burns rubber in his Ferrari -- at the Chateau Marmont hotel in Hollywood. He finds something to live for after his ex-wife leaves their 11-year-old daughter (Elle Fanning, right, with Mr. Dorff) in his care. Writing in The Times, A. O. Scott described the movie as ''exquisite, melancholy and formally audacious.'' What happens, he added, ''is something marvelous: a film that never raises its voice (its loudest and most assertive sound is that Ferrari) or panders to your emotions, but that nonetheless has the power to refresh your perceptions and deepen your sympathies.'' ''Lost in Translation'' (2003), for which Ms. Coppola won an Oscar for best original screenplay, follows at 12:40 p.m.

headline: Paid Notice: Deaths KORMAN, MARVIN
summary: KORMAN--Marvin, born in the Bronx, June 23, 1927 died on March 9, 2014 a long time Village resident. He was much loved by family and friends for his warmth, genial spirit and graciousness. He shared his life long passions for baseball, art, baking, sketching, American political history, music, travel, good writing and food with everyone he met. He loved to work starting in his father's bakery then becoming a copy boy for The New York Times and PM as a college student. He graduated NYU in 1948, and attended its Art Institute which led him to a career in art galleries including establishing the Korman Gallery on Madison Avenue, the forerunner of the Zabriski gallery. He worked in advertising and publicity for MCA, Dell Publishing, CBS Radio, and Columbia Pictures where he rose to be vice-president of Advertising. After a three year stint at NBC TV he left the corporate world to establish his own boutique Advertising agency Korman, Mohamad, Korman. After retirement, Red Rock Press published his recipe book When the Kaiser Roll was King' and his memoir 'In My Father's Bakery' which is now available in e-book form. He taught many people to bake bread and has an Onion Roll recipe in The New York Times Jewish Cook Book. He is survived by many friends, several cousins, nieces and nephews his beloved wife of sixty-one years Eleanore Zolotow Korman, (retired Dean of the NYU Silver School of Social Work), and two loving daughters Candy Korman and Justine Korman Fontes. Both of his daughters have followed his path as authors. Donations in his memory can be sent to CF Care C/O Dr. Gwen M. Engelhard, 55 East End Avenue Suite 14D New York, NY 10028.

headline: Paid Notice: Deaths JORDAN, RUTH BENNETT
summary: JORDAN--Ruth Bennett, died on March 8, 2014, peacefully in New York City. Known as Rudy, she was born on September 11, 1924 in Chicago, one of five daughters of James Ewing Bennett and Mary Mable Dwyer. She attended the Girls' Latin School in Chicago and graduated from Sarah Lawrence College with a B.A. in 1946. Rudy served as a volunteer ambulance driver for the Red Cross Motor Corps in Chicago during World War II. She volunteered as a nurse's aide during and after college. A long term member of The Madison Avenue Presbyterian Church, New York, New York, and St. John's Episcopal Church, Cold Spring Harbor, New York, Rudy was a person of strong values and a leader in ethics. Rudy studied at Columbia University Teacher's College towards a Master's degree in Teaching and taught English and American History for 10 years at The Lenox School in Manhattan. She subsequently earned her Juris Doctor from New York Law School in 1981, and was admitted to the New York State Bar in 1982 at the age of 57. She worked as an assistant in the Law Department at the New York County Surrogate's Court, and later at a law firm and also volunteered in the field of environmental law. Rudy was a direct descendant of Thomas Soule and Richard Warren of the Mayflower. She was a long term member of the Colony Club, The New York Junior League, the Cold Spring Harbor Beach Club and The Colonial Dames of America. She was a champion bridge player, representing the bridge team for the Colony Club for many years. She was interviewed by Dan Rather on CBS 60 Minutes II, and by others on television, on the topic of the Dennis Kozlowski, Tyco International Ltd. trial, in which she was involved as the sole "hold out" juror against conviction. She advocated that as there was not sufficient evidence in the initial trial to establish the defendant's guilt, as she saw it, the presumption of innocence must prevail. Rudy was an optimist and an idealist; a person of great fortitude and original thought. Always supportive of her children and grandchildren, and an extremely warm and devoted mother, she set an example of determination and creative solutions in the face of adversity. Rudy is survived by her two children, Jennifer Jordan McCall and William Winston Jordan, a daughter-in-law, Denise A. Walter, three grandchildren, Caroline Debevoise Clark, Hillary Sage Clark and Samantha Marie Jordan, and by a sister, Joan Bennett Gordon of Glenview, Illinois. A Memorial Service will be held at 10:30am on Saturday, March 15 at St. John's Episcopal Church, Cold Spring Harbor, New York.

headline: Paid Notice: Deaths KORMAN, MARVIN
summary: KORMAN--Marvin, born in the Bronx, June 23, 1927 died on March 9, 2014 a long time Village resident. He was much loved by family and friends for his warmth, genial spirit and graciousness. He shared his life long passions for baseball, art, baking, sketching, American political history, music, travel, good writing and food with everyone he met. He loved to work starting in his father's bakery then becoming a copy boy for The New York Times and PM as a college student. He graduated NYU in 1948, and attended its Art Institute which led him to a career in art galleries including establishing the Korman Gallery on Madison Avenue, the forerunner of the Zabriski gallery. He worked in advertising and publicity for MCA, Dell Publishing, CBS Radio, and Columbia Pictures where he rose to be vice-president of Advertising. After a three year stint at NBC TV he left the corporate world to establish his own boutique Advertising agency Korman, Mohamad, Korman. After retirement, Red Rock Press published his recipe book When the Kaiser Roll was King' and his memoir 'In My Father's Bakery' which is now available in e-book form. He taught many people to bake bread and has an Onion Roll recipe in The New York Times Jewish Cook Book. He is survived by many friends, several cousins, nieces and nephews his beloved wife of sixty-one years Eleanore Zolotow Korman, (retired Dean of the NYU Silver School of Social Work), and two loving daughters Candy Korman and Justine Korman Fontes. Both of his daughters have followed his path as authors. Donations in his memory can be sent to CF Care C/O Dr. Gwen M. Engelhard, 55 East End Avenue Suite 14D New York, NY 10028.

headline: Paid Notice: Deaths MACCOWATT HASKELL P.
summary: MacCOWATT Haskell P.,April 15, 1931February 16, 2014 of Summit, NJ and Edgartown, MA, passed away peacefully on Sunday, February 16, 2014. He was 82. Born April 15, 1931 in Plainfield, NJ. He received an AB from Colgate University and a MS from MIT Sloan School of Management. He began his career at Batten, Barton, Durstine & Osborn (BBDO) as a copywriter and account executive. He later joined CBS Inc. in New York, where he worked for 26 years, including serving as Vice President Investor Relations, Vice President and Treasurer, and retired as Senior Vice President of Administration in 1988. Throughout his life, he was active in a variety of civic, cultural and educational organizations. He was President of the Summit Common Council, Chairman of the Board of the Visual Arts Center of New Jersey, President of the Board of the Reeves Reed Arboretum and a trustee of the Summit Area Public Foundation. He was a Trustee Emeritus of Colgate University. He was President of the Edgartown Reading Room, President and a Trustee Emeritus of the Martha's Vineyard Preservation Trust and a trustee of the Edgartown Yacht Club. He is survived by his wife of 54 years, Margaret Gentles MacCowatt, son Thomas H. MacCowatt (Anne L.), daughters Nancy M. Sanford, and Sally M. Black (Josiah M.) and seven grandchildren. Funeral services will be private. In lieu of flowers, donations in Paul's memory may be made to the Martha's Vineyard Preservation Trust or Colgate University.

headline: Timberlake Still No. 1
summary: Justin Timberlake’s latest album is No. 1 on the Billboard chart for a third week, beating new albums by the Band Perry and the rapper Tyler, the Creator. Mr. Timberlake’s album “The 20/20 Experience” (RCA), his first new release in almost seven years, arrived in stores on a wave of marketing and promotion , and is still selling strong, or at least more strongly than anything else. Last week it sold 139,000 copies, according to Nielsen SoundScan, down 56 percent from the week before.

headline: What's On Today
summary: 9 P.M. (13) RENÉE FLEMING @ THE PENTHOUSE ''Live From Lincoln Center'' presents Ms. Fleming, the soprano, in a concert at the Stanley H. Kaplan Penthouse featuring Samuel Barber's ''Knoxville: Summer of 1915''; selections from ''Dark Hope,'' the recent indie-rock album from Ms. Fleming (above); Broadway songs; and a duet with Josh Groban. 2:25 P.M. (Flix) JOE STRUMMER: THE FUTURE IS UNWRITTEN (2007) Julien Temple, one of the first filmmakers to document Britain's punk scene, draws on archival footage, interviews and his own friendship to create a portrait of Joe Strummer, co-founder and lead singer of the Clash.

headline: Paid Notice: Deaths PHELPS, STOWE CATLIN
summary: PHELPS--Stowe Catlin. Born April 15, 1917, died peacefully at home on December 24th, 2013. He had lived "Many Very Good Years" to quote the title of his memoirs. On June 24, 1944 he married Charlton Yarnall Jacobs of Philadelphia. They had two daughters: Sophia Yarnall Payne of Fort Worth, TX and Meredith Phelps Rugg of New York City. Stowe had a varied, creative career that included acting on Broadway, working at CBS television and writing and producing documentary films. He spent many years on the Board of the Third Street Music School Settlement and was an active member of The Century Association. Music was central to his life and he was the oldest living Whiffenpoof. He loved golf and enjoyed his many years as a U.S. Senior. His family was all important to him and in addition to his wife and two daughters he is survived by his son-in-law Peter Rugg, five grandchildren and seven great-grandchildren. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to: The Third Street Music School Settlement, 235 E. 11th St, New York, NY 10003 or The Fishers Island Sea Stretcher, c/o FIFD Box 222, Fishers Island, NY 06390 or The Century Association Foundation, 7 West 43rd St, New York, NY 10036. There will be a memorial service soon in 2014.

headline: What's On Sunday
summary: 8:30 P.M. (ABC) THE 84TH ANNUAL ACADEMY AWARDS The tried-and-true Billy Crystal returns for his ninth stint as host of this ceremony broadcast live from the Kodak Theater in Los Angeles (above, setting the scene). George Clooney is up for best actor for ''The Descendants,'' but oddsmakers are predicting that Jean Dujardin will take home the Oscar for his role as a silent-movie star in ''The Artist,'' the black-and-white tribute to a golden age in Hollywood. That film is expected to win best picture as well, while its director, Michel Hazanavicius, is favored for the directing award. Viola Davis is the top best-actress contender for her turn as a courageous maid in ''The Help,'' though Meryl Streep, as Margaret Thatcher in ''The Iron Lady,'' could make it a close race. And in the best-supporting category, Christopher Plummer is expected to win as a father who comes out of the closet near the end of his life in ''Beginners,'' as is Octavia Spencer, who portrayed another determined maid in ''The Help.'' ''A Separation,'' the domestic drama set in Iran, is favored to win for best foreign film. The countdown begins at 1:30 on E!; at 4 on the TV Guide Channel; and at 6 on Channel 11. Tim Gunn, Robin Roberts, Jess Cagle, Nina Garcia and Louise Roe interview celebrities on the red carpet at 7 on ABC. Postshow coverage follows at 11:30 on E! 7 A.M. (Sho2) THE KING'S SPEECH (2010) Colin Firth, below, in the role for which he won the best-actor Oscar last year, portrays Albert Frederick Arthur George, or Bertie, as his family called him, the shy second son of George V of Britain (Michael Gambon) in this film from Tom Hooper. Geoffrey Rush is Lionel Logue, the speech therapist who helps him conquer his debilitating stutter. And Helena Bonham Carter is Elizabeth, Bertie's wife and staunch support system, who can't quite stomach Wallis Simpson (Eve Best), the American divorcée who leads Bertie's older brother, David (Guy Pearce), to abdicate as Edward VIII. ''It isn't exactly 'Pygmalion,' not least because Mr. Hooper has no intention of satirizing the caste system that is one of this movie's biggest draws,'' Manohla Dargis, writing in The New York Times, said of the film, which received 12 nominations and earned Mr. Hooper an Oscar as best director. ''Like many entertainments of this pop-historical type, 'The King's Speech' wears history lightly no matter how heavy the crown.'' The film also won Academy Awards for best picture and original screenplay (David Seidler).

headline: Paid Notice: Deaths MORGAN, DAVID W.
summary: MORGAN--David William, 85, died peacefully at home in Darien, CT January 20, 2014. A dedicated and beloved husband and father, he was surrounded by his wife of 42 years, Mary Louise Fitzsimmons, and children Mallory and David Jr. having battled Primary CNS Lymphoma for 22 months. Born July 6, 1928 in Cleveland, OH to Dr. John Benjamin Morgan and Bertha Amersbach Morgan; he graduated from La Salle University in 1950. Before founding Morgan Communications in 1978, he worked for Catalina Swimwear, Harper's Bazaar, Seventeen, and CBS. He represented the San Fransisco 49ers at the 2000-2006 NFL Drafts. A 32 year resident of Darien, he was active in town politics as elected Constable for 20 years. In 1986 he founded and ran the charity "Bikes For Bed-Stuy" for 13 years. He was a longtime member of the Spring Lake Bath & Tennis Club in NJ. Funeral Mass will be held at St. John Church in Darien on January 25, 2014 at 10:00am. Donations may be made to www.burke.org

headline: What's On Today
summary: 9 P.M. (13) NOVA In this episode, ''Cracking Your Genetic Code,'' scientists consider the possible impact of a genetic code sequencing revolution. The technology to read and analyze an individual's DNA exists, but high costs have kept it out of reach for many people. But within the next five years, according to this program, sequencing an individual's complete genome could cost less than $1,000, making the procedure more accessible. Scientists believe the sequencing could help predict a person's genetic vulnerability to particular illnesses. That, in turn, could mean more personalized preventive medical treatment. 10:45 A.M. (IFC) CHE: PART ONE (2008) Steven Soderbergh's film about the international revolutionary Ernesto Guevara (Benicio Del Toro), known as Che, is an ''epic hagiography,'' A. O. Scott wrote in The New York Times. The film, he said, ''not only participates in the worship of its subject but also spares no effort to insulate him from skepticism.'' This part chronicles Guevara's participation in the Cuban Revolution and his 1964 address to the United Nations, a bombastic speech that raised his profile.

headline: What's On Today
summary: 8 P.M. (NBC) COMMUNITY In the first half of a two-part episode Shirley (Yvette Nicole Brown) and Pierce (Chevy Chase) lose their appetites when a Subway shop opens in the college cafeteria, so they team up with Britta (Gillian Jacobs) to try to shut it down. Vice Dean Laybourne (John Goodman, guest starring) drops by to promote the college's air-conditioner-repair program, but it's a hard sell for Troy (Donald Glover, above far right, with Joel McHale, center, and Danny Pudi). 3 P.M. (Sundance) MADE IN CHINA (2009) In this comedy from Judi Krant, an aspiring inventor from Texas (Jackson Kuehn) thinks he has a million-dollar idea for a novelty product, and he flies to Shanghai to meet with manufacturers. Though he encounters problems with the language barrier and hasn't negotiated with factory owners before, he remains committed to what he calls his ''humorous domestic hygiene product.''

headline: What's On Today
summary: 9 P.M. (CBS) ACM PRESENTS: LIONEL RICHIE AND FRIENDS -- IN CONCERT In an evening of country collaborations Mr. Richie performs solo works and duets from his new greatest-hits album, ''Tuskegee,'' alongside Kenny Chesney, Tim McGraw, Jennifer Nettles, Kenny Rogers, Darius Rucker (above left, with Mr. Richie) and Rascal Flatts. Others offer renditions of Mr. Richie's signature songs, including Jason Aldean (''Say You, Say Me''), Luke Bryan (''Running With the Night''), Sara Evans and Marc Anthony (''Endless Love''), Martina McBride (''Still''), the Band Perry (''Penny Lover''), Big & Rich (''Brick House'') and Lady Antebellum (''Truly''). 11:15 A.M. (MoreMax) THE COMPANY (2003) In this ensemble drama featuring members of the Joffrey Ballet of Chicago, Robert Altman dissects the inner workings of a dance troupe through a few months of its season while focusing on Ry (Neve Campbell), a ballerina trying to make her way to the top as she keeps company with Josh (James Franco), a chef. Malcolm McDowell plays Alberto Antonelli, the company's genteel, bristling artistic director who is so self-absorbed that he has no idea of the damage he is capable of inflicting. In his review for The New York Times, Elvis Mitchell wrote that the film ''is enjoyably lithe and droll yet somehow almost water-soluble; it seems to dissolve on screen.''

headline: Paid Notice: Deaths LEIGHTON, HALLIE LELAND
summary: LEIGHTON--Hallie Leland, 42, who fought successfully for passage of New York State's Breast Density Inform Bill, while fighting her own losing battle with metastatic breast cancer died on April 30, 2013. She gave media interviews telling her own story, urging women to find out if they have dense tissue, not itself abnormal but sometimes masking tumors in mammograms, and to inquire about further testing. She supported the organization, "Are You Dense?," lobbied for the bill in Albany, and started an advocacy blog. The bill became NYS law in January, 2013. Hallie brought the same passion, intellect, and devotion to this cause as to her other interests and many friendships. Born and raised in NYC, Hallie went to the High School of Performing Arts, attended St. John's College in Annapolis, and graduated from the Santa Fe campus where she was editor of the college newspaper. Her career was varied, but never strayed far from her love of language and writing. She started collecting words at age 13 when she encountered hussar and bivouac in Tolstoy's War and Peace. "I treat words I have just learned like new acquaintances; no matter how well we hit it off on a first meeting, I don't assume intimacy." With her late father, the actor/impersonator Jan Leighton, she co-authored two books, Rare Words I and II (Levenger Press, 2003, 2008), which used humor to help master meanings. After college, Hallie worked at Random House and Knopf, was a writer's assistant on As the World Turns at CBS, and wrote columns for Cotton, Inc. that appeared regularly in Women's Wear Daily. She went to Israel in an arts program in the Negev, where she wrote about the Bedouin and stayed two more years because "the adventure wasn't over," working with organizations that promoted peace between Arabs and Israelis. Back in the U.S. she became Director of Communications for Charity Brands, a firm that connected corporations with good causes. At the time of her death, she was working on a documentary on her father's unusual career he had played more roles than any other actor (2407) according to the 1985 Guinness Book of World Records. Hallie is survived by her mother, Lynda Myles, her Aunt Wendie Myles, her brother Ross Leighton, and a large, loving extended family. There will be a memorial service to celebrate her life and share memories at The Society for Ethical Culture, 2 West 64th Street, NYC, Thursday, June 13, 5:30pm. Gifts to support Hallie's favored charities can be made to the Jewish Communal Fund (att: Hallie Leighton Tikkun Olam Fund), 575 Madison Ave. #
