headline: Plan Against Gay Marriage Sought to Enlist Blacks
summary: 9:05 p.m. | Updated An internal memorandum from one of the country's leading organizations against same-sex marriage outlined a plan to help its cause by exploiting unease among blacks over the issue. The undated memo was one of several documents unsealed by a federal judge on Monday in a case in Maine, where the group, the National Organization for Marriage, helped finance a successful ballot initiative in 2009 overturning the state's legalization of same-sex marriage.

headline: How Picking a Chief Executive Is More Random Than Wise
summary: What makes the perfect chief executive? If the way corporate boards at Yahoo and Duke Energy picked chief executives is any indication, it may be up to chance in large part. Take Marissa Mayer, the newly appointed chief of Yahoo. She is a Stanford graduate, age 37, and Google's 20th employee. Until her new gig, Ms. Mayer was one of Google's stars and helped develop Gmail. She was a well-known face for Google, serving on the board of Wal-Mart Stores, attending White House state dinners and appearing as a regular member of Fortune's 40 under 40 of the hottest young business executives. In the ultimate sign of tech prominence, she has almost 200,000 Twitter followers.

headline: Two Ohio Women, Two Views
summary: Dana Hogan and Kathleen Foley were interviewed as part of a Quinnipiac University/New York Times/CBS News poll of Ohio voters.

headline: Paid Notice: Deaths REED, HAROLD
summary: REED--Harold, art dealer, theatrical producer and community advocate, 75, died of natural causes on January 5, while en route to Hong Kong. Born in Newark, NJ, Reed studied at Stanford University then settled in New York in the mid 1960s. He began his career as a theatrical agent before turning to art; he founded the Mobile Art Gallery and later the Harold Reed Gallery, known for seminal shows of works by Botero, Alice Neel and many others. He was a member of the Art Dealers Association of America in the 1980s. In more recent years, Reed was an active member of the Manhattan Community Board 1 and lobbied in support of theater and the arts in Lower Manhattan, especially for the South Street Seaport area. He served on the boards of the CB1 Landmarks Committee as well as the Yaddo arts colony. He is survived by his son, Bradford Reed, a musician and composer. Plans for a memorial TBA.

headline: What's On Today
summary: 8 P.M. (MTV) THE BREAK (2012) More than 1.5 million children are estimated to live on the streets, in shelters and on friends' couches in the United States. Many come from troubled families and have run away from abuse or have aged out of the foster care system. Their futures often involve prostitution, crime and illegal drug use, and one in three are likely to attempt suicide. This documentary follows Ava, Nancy and Rob, young people currently without homes and in desperate need of improving their lives. Anne Mahlum -- an advocate for the homeless whose organization, Back on My Feet, uses running as a way of building strength and self-esteem -- offers them the opportunities and tools to bring about change. The project was envisioned by the Edge, from the band U2. 7:30 A.M. (Starz) HOW DO YOU KNOW (2010) Reese Witherspoon taps into her intimidating side to play Lisa, a 31-year-old softball star whose aspirations have been dealt a huge blow. Owen Wilson is Matty, the major league pitcher whose spell she falls under, and who thinks he may be ready to give commitment a try. Then George (Paul Rudd, above with Ms. Witherspoon) enters Lisa's life, first as a dud of a blind date and then as a friend whose father-cum-boss (Jack Nicholson) isn't all that unhappy about letting his son take the fall for his own financial misdeeds. Now Lisa needs to decide. Writing in The New York Times, Manohla Dargis said this romantic comedy from James L. Brooks was ''so wan and disconnected to anything that feels like real life or, just as good, a screwball interpretation of it, that it's hard to know what Mr. Brooks was really after, other than passing the time with some talented movie people.''

headline: Eugenio Derbez in 'Rob'
summary: The Mexican comedy star is starting to raise his profile in the United States.

headline: The Heart of Fifth Avenue Shopping Is Edging to the South
summary: Long the retail stepsister of upper Fifth Avenue, the stretch of the avenue south of 49th Street and north of 42nd Street seems finally to be coming into its own with the opening of several flagship stores by retailers from around the world. The list includes Joe Fresh and Aritzia, two Canadian fashion retailers; Ted Baker London; Tommy Bahama; and an expanded Lacoste. H&M, the Swedish fast-fashion retailer, also announced last month that it planned to open its largest store in the world, a 57,000-square-foot outlet at 48th Street and Fifth Avenue, next fall.

headline: New Arrivals In High-Def
summary: Jonny Lee Miller counts as a blessing that he knew early that he wanted to act. Performing in London school productions at 8, he had an agent by 9, parts on British TV in his teens and roles in movies like ''Hackers'' and '' Trainspotting '' in his 20s. Now near 40, Mr. Miller is playing a modern-day Sherlock Holmes in the CBS drama '' Elementary ,'' Thursdays at 10.

headline: Inside the Times
summary: International TALIBAN FREES HUNDREDS FROM PAKISTANI PRISON

headline: What's On Today
summary: 9 P.M. (VH1) LA LA'S FULL COURT LIFE In this Season 2 opener, La La Anthony (above, with her son, Kiyan), the wife of the basketball player Carmelo Anthony, adjusts to life in New York after her husband is traded to the Knicks. But her friends' talk about infidelity soon forces her to confront issues in her own marriage. In the premiere of ''Styled by June,'' at 9:30, June Ambrose, a fashion stylist for Jay-Z, Mariah Carey, Mary J. Blige and Jamie Foxx, helps some faded stars rebrand themselves. Ms. Ambrose's first client is the actress Mischa Barton, who says that her soul has been sucked dry by attention from the paparazzi. 7:05 P.M. (Sundance) PABLO'S HIPPOS (2010) Antonio Von Hildebrand chronicles the rise to power of the Colombian drug lord Pablo Escobar through the eyes of a pet hippopotamus.

headline: Inside The Times
summary: International EUROPEAN OFFICIAL CALLS

headline: Corrections
summary: An article on Thursday about Mitt Romney's declaring that the mandate in President Obama's health care program is a tax misstated the arrangements for an interview with CBS News in which Mr. Romney addressed the issue. The timing of the interview was set more than a week earlier. It was not ''hastily arranged.''

headline: Damien Bona, 56, Oscar Buff Who Became Oscar Scholar
summary: Flip to just about any page in ''Inside Oscar: The Unofficial History of the Academy Awards'' and something fascinating is bound to pop up. In 1997, when ''Breathing Lessons,'' about a man who spent most of his life in an iron lung, won the award for best short documentary, the director, Jessica Yu, stepped to the mike and said, ''You know you've entered new territory when you realize your outfit cost more than your film.''

headline: What's On Today
summary: 8:30 P.M. (HBO) SAVING FACE (2011) In Pakistan throwing acid on women to disfigure them is an alarmingly common form of revenge, often for rejected sexual advances or marriage proposals. The victims are left physically and emotionally scarred, with little or no access to reconstructive surgery, while the assailants, typically husbands or someone else close to the victim, are frequently released with minimal punishment. In this Oscar-winning short documentary Daniel Junge and Sharmeen Obaid-Chinoy tell the stories of two women -- 39-year-old Zakia, above, whose husband threw acid on her after she filed for divorce, and Rukhsana, 25, whose husband and in-laws threw acid and gasoline on her, then set her on fire -- as they seek justice with the help of the Acid Survivors Foundation in Islamabad and Dr. Mohammad Jawad, a Pakistani-born plastic surgeon who stepped away from his London practice to help victims of what he called society's disease. The film also follows the push for stricter sentencing laws for attacks on the women whom Rukhsana calls ''the living dead.'' 6 A.M. (Sundance) AMREEKA (2009) Nisreen Faour, below, plays Muna Farah, a divorced Palestinian with a green card who at the outset of the invasion of Iraq in 2003 forsakes a relatively comfortable existence to travel to America with her 16-year-old son, Fadi (Melkar Muallem). The result is an exercise in confronting hostility and prejudice. Writing in The New York Times about this film from Cherien Dabis, a Palestinian-Jordanian whose parents moved to the United States before she was born, Stephen Holden said, '' 'Amreeka' (the Arabic word for America) stands alongside 'The Visitor' and 'Maria Full of Grace' as one of the most accomplished recent films about a non-European immigrant coming to the United States.''

headline: Competition Gets a Break From CBS Reruns
summary: A full slate of repeats on CBS allowed the other broadcast networks to gain some ground in the ratings on Thursday. Fox was by far the No. 1 network for the night, according to Nielsen data, as both ''American Idol'' and ''Touch'' received a bump in viewership from last week. They finished with 15.3 million total viewers and 8.2 million, respectively. ABC also benefited from the lack of competition. Not only did ''Grey's Anatomy'' bounce back from season lows, but the political drama ''Scandal'' also posted higher numbers, including 7.5 million total viewers, in its second week than its premiere. It's a rare feat for a new program.

headline: Augusta, On Roberts's Terms
summary: To the Sports Editor: Re ''Augusta Wouldn't Bend for President,'' Aug. 22: From 1950 to 1952, I was a member of the CBS legal department. One time I was assigned the job of preparing the Masters television rights contract with Augusta National Golf Club. I had been warned that Clifford Roberts, the club chairman, was a difficult person, but that was an understatement. He treated me like a servant and told me exactly what was to be in the contract.

headline: Inside the Times
summary: International PHOTOS OF PROTESTER ON FIRE

headline: Ralph McQuarrie, Artist Who Helped Bring 'Star Wars' to Life, Dies at 82
summary: Ralph McQuarrie, the artist who transformed George Lucas's rudimentary concepts and earliest scripts into lush, vivid images of intergalactic expanse and light-saber combat that became the visual core of the ''Star Wars'' saga, died on Saturday at his home in Berkeley, Calif. He was 82. The cause was complications of Parkinson's disease, said Stan Stice, a friend and co-author of the 2007 book ''The Art of Ralph McQuarrie.''

headline: Shrouded in Secrecy, Parkinson's Takes Greater Toll
summary: When Nancy Mulhearn learned she had Parkinson's disease seven years ago, she kept the diagnosis mostly to herself, hiding it from friends, colleagues - even, at first, her mother, sister and teenage children. After seven months, she decided she had to tell her family, and they settled into an unspoken agreement not to talk about the disease. She also realized her colleagues already suspected the truth: One asked why she had trouble applying her lipstick. She sometimes could not control her shaking hands.

headline: No Best Actress Tony for ‘Matilda’ Quartet
summary: The four child actresses who rotate in the title role of the Broadway musical “Matilda” will not be eligible for a joint Tony Award nomination for best actress in a musical this spring, the Tony administrative committee ruled on Friday. The decision, the most newsworthy result of a busy committee meeting, sets aside a controversial precedent from 2009 when the three teenage boys sharing the lead role in “Billy Elliot” were deemed eligible for a joint best actor nomination — and went on to win that June. The producers of “Matilda,” itself a front-runner for the best musical Tony this year, had sought joint eligibility for the four girls — Sophia Gennusa, Oona Laurence, Bailey Ryon and Milly Shapiro. Instead of granting that request, the Tony committee announced in a statement that the actresses would receive a special award — Tony Honors for Excellence in the Theater — “to recognize their outstanding performances this season.” As a result, none will be eligible in the best actress category.

headline: What's On Sunday
summary: 10 P.M. (ABC) GCB It's payback time in this new prime-time soap opera, based on the novel ''Good Christian Bitches'' by Kim Gatlin and counting Robert Harling (''Steel Magnolias'') and Darren Star (''Sex and the City'') among its executive producers. Leslie Bibb stars as Amanda Vaughn, a onetime high school mean girl who is forced to return to Dallas in disgrace after her marriage ends in scandal. Annie Potts plays Gigi, her socialite mother who wants nothing more than to have her daughter back in the fold, the better to give her teenage grandchildren a proper Southern upbringing. Kristin Chenoweth, above, is Carlene Cockburn, a former ugly duckling who was tortured by Amanda as a girl but has made an ''assisted transformation'' into a picture-perfect life of luxury with a gorgeous husband -- if only she could let go of old grudges. Miriam Shor is Cricket Caruth-Reilly, whose boyfriend Amanda stole and later married. Jennifer Aspen is Sharon Peacham, whose chance at the Miss Teen Dallas crown was snatched away when Amanda started a malicious rumor. And Marisol Nichols is Heather Cruz, an outsider turned member of this clique of God-fearing women capable of instilling terror. ''The result is a network comedy that sends up sex, sin and Southern Baptists, or at least the pious parvenus of Dallas,'' Alessandra Stanley wrote in The New York Times. 10 A.M. (ABC) THIS WEEK WITH GEORGE STEPHANOPOULOS The Republican presidential candidate Newt Gingrich discusses whether he can again become a contender for the nomination as Super Tuesday approaches. He also appears on ''Meet the Press,'' at 10:30 on NBC.

headline: Fox's 'Idol' and CBS Are Leaders
summary: The ratings for ''American Idol'' reversed their course on Thursday night, growing slightly compared to last week, which provided Fox with a win for the night in the 18-to-49-year-old demographic coveted by advertisers. CBS drew the most viewers over all. An average of 17.9 million people watched ''Idol,'' barely beating last week's total of 17.4 million but the show was also up 4 percent in the 18-to-49 category. Again, not a large gain, but a change from the downward trend that followed earlier episodes. The CBS lineup continued its strong performance as ''The Big Bang Theory'' drew 16.1 million total viewers and beat ''Idol'' with adults 18-to-49 in the half-hour they went head to head, while ''The Mentalist'' had its largest audience of the season with 14.4 million viewers.

headline: First Lady Brushes Aside Book's Account of Friction
summary: Michelle Obama dismissed a new book's portrayal of her role as first lady, saying it played off an image of her as ''some angry black woman'' and insisting that she had played little role, at least directly, in the West Wing of the White House. ''I don't have conversations with my husband's staff,'' she told Gayle King of CBS News in an interview broadcast on Wednesday morning. ''I don't go to the meetings.''

headline: ‘Good Wife’: Diane Is the Moral Center
summary: Part 9: The cast and creators of “The Good Wife” talk about how CBS has tried to change the show.

headline: What's On Sunday
summary: 8 P.M. (CBS) THE 66TH ANNUAL TONY AWARDS Neil Patrick Harris, above, once again will sing and dance his way through the role of host for this ceremony honoring excellence on Broadway, to be broadcast live from the Beacon Theater in Manhattan. Performers include the casts of the nominees for best musical and musical revival -- ''Newsies,'' ''Nice Work if You Can Get It,'' ''Once,'' ''Evita,'' ''Follies,'' ''The Gershwins' Porgy and Bess,'' ''Jesus Christ Superstar,'' ''Leap of Faith'' -- as well as ''End of the Rainbow,'' ''One Man, Two Guvnors,'' ''Peter and the Starcatcher,'' ''Ghost the Musical'' and ''Godspell.'' ''The Book of Mormon,'' last year's winner for best musical, will also be featured. Ellen Barkin, Candice Bergen, Jessica Chastain, Sheryl Crow, Nick Jonas, Angela Lansbury, James Marsden, Trey Parker, Jim Parsons, Mandy Patinkin, Tyler Perry, Bernadette Peters, Christopher Plummer, Paul Rudd, Amanda Seyfried and Matt Stone are among the presenters. 10 A.M. (Fox) FOX NEWS SUNDAY Chris Wallace interviews Gov. Mitch Daniels, Republican of Indiana; Dennis Van Roekel, president of the National Education Association; and Thea Lee, deputy chief of staff for the A.F.L.-C.I.O., about the effect of Wisconsin's recall election on the electoral map.

headline: Public Opinion: Support for Cutting Back Mail
summary: An overwhelming majority of Americans support the Postal Service's plan to end Saturday mail delivery, according to a poll conducted by The New York Times/CBS News. The survey found that about 7 in 10 Americans say they would favor the change as a way to help the post office deal with billions of dollars in debt. The Postal Service continues to suffer losses of $36 million a day and is headed for projected losses of about $21 billion a year by 2016.

headline: Paid Notice: Deaths LANIN, MIKE
summary: LANIN--Mike. President of Howard Lanin Productions passed away in New York on April 14, 2014 at age 90. In 1952 Mike hired a 22-year old conductor for a nationwide Gershwin concert tour that ran for two seasons (1952-54) and played in 170 cities. His name: Lorin Maazel. It was the only orchestra in history dedicated exclusively to the music of one composer. Mike pursued his interest in George Gershwin in collaboration with Michael Feinstein. Mike, a well-known producer of shows for large corporations (IBM, Coca Cola, CBS, AT&T) hired star performers such as Harry Belafonte, Tony Bennett, Liza Minnelli, Diahann Carroll, Leslie Huggams, Lena Horne, Bob Hope, Duke Ellington, Ella Fitzgerald, Ray Bolger, Doc Severinsen and Bill Cosby among others. Memorable productions Mike presented include The Royal Danish Ballet in its US debut and The Conservatory Without Walls, a glittering event in honor of the country's greatest Afro-American musicians which launched the Duke Ellington Fellowship Fund at Yale University. Mike also served on the board of The Martha Graham School of Contemporary Dance. Mike Lanin was born in Philadelphia on March, 8, 1924, the son of the band leader Howard Lanin and the nephew of Lester Lanin, the internationally known society band leader. During World War II he enlisted in the U.S. Army Air Corps. At that time he discovered a young and talented pianist, still unknown, Bobby Short. They became friends for the rest of their lives. Mike was a graduate of Yale University where he was an imaginative caricaturist for the Yale Record. He is also remembered for his fond portrayal of Orson Welles' Citizen Kane. Mike was an elegant man both in appearance and in spirit. He was always courteous, soft spoken, never one to boast of his many achievements and of his friendships with famous artists. He was a loyal friend, a witty but considerate companion with a dry sense of humor. He was an entertaining guest. Mike has been called "the dean of entertainment who pioneered the theme party, the pops concert, the anniversary revue and the multimedia production." He was an avid reader and traveler. He kept homes in New York and Paris. He is survived by his wife of 45 years, the love of his life, Yvonne Constant-Lanin, a performer herself and a frequent guest (45 times) on the Johnny Carson Show. It was always a pleasure to see how much Mike enjoyed his wife's performances. He was proud of her interpretations of French and American songs. At her recitals he would greet friends with a radiant smile. He was also proud of Yvonne having been named "Chevalier des Arts et des Lettres", an important French cultural award. Other immediate survivors include his sister, Suzanne Lande, his adopted daughter Kristina Stufano from a previous marriage, his stepson, Gerard Pinguet and numerous grandchildren.

headline: Kennedy Center Honors for Hoffman and Letterman
summary: WASHINGTON- The Kennedy Center for the Performing Arts on Wednesday named Buddy Guy, Dustin Hoffman, David Letterman, Natalia Makarova and Led Zeppelin to receive this year's Kennedy Center Honors . The award is given for lifetime achievement in the performing arts. David M. Rubenstein, the chairman of the Kennedy Center, said the recipients demonstrated "extraordinary talent, creativity and tenacity" over their careers.

headline: A Media Personality, Suffering a Blow to His Image, Ponders a Lesson
summary: When Lynda and Stewart Resnick, the Beverly Hills entrepreneurs who founded POM Wonderful, wanted to host a dinner at their Aspen home in 2006 to talk about the Iraq war, they assembled a list of 22 A-list guests, including Queen Noor of Jordan, George Soros, the financier, and Senator Dianne Feinstein, Democrat of California.Leading the list of journalists was one of their favorite guests: Fareed Zakaria , the Indian-born Harvard Ph.D and foreign-policy specialist who had turned himself into an unlikely media star.

headline: What's On Today
summary: 10 P.M. (Science) TED TALKS In this collection of the best TED conference talks, the producer and director J. J. Abrams tells of a ''mystery box'' he received as a child that he never opened, explaining that his fascination with the unknown drives his work. Bonnie Bassler, above, a molecular biologist, discusses a chemical language that allows bacteria to communicate. Robin Ince, a comedian, riffs on the relationship between science and wonder. And the inventor Skylar Tibbits speaks about the future of building and the nascent science of self-assembly. 8 P.M. (CBS) UNDERCOVER BOSS The chief executive of Yankee Candle learns how his company works at the store level when he dons a disguise (a curly wig and a soul patch) and pretends to be a new hire. But his go-getter attitude raises eyebrows when he expends considerable effort on customer service, and he almost blows his cover when he speaks up testily about a store's sloppy appearance.

headline: Paid Notice: Deaths MCQUADE, JAMES R.
summary: McQUADE--James R. Of New York, NY and Spring Lake, NJ, passed away on October 4, 2012 at his home in Spring Lake, NJ after a brief illness. He is survived by his beloved wife, Constance Nugent McQuade; his aunt, Anne Maguire Fedigan and his brother-in-law, Joseph C. Nugent. James was Vice President of CBS Radio and General Manager of WCBS News 88. He graduated from Fordham Preparatory School and Georgetown University. He served as a First Lieutenant in the United States Air Force. He was a Board Member of the former St. Vincent's Hospital & Medical Center, Mary Manning Walsh Nursing Home both New York City, Boy's Hope and the St. Vincent's Fund Inc. He received an Honorary Degree from St. John's University. He was a member of the Spring Lake Bath & Tennis Club, the Spring Lake Golf Club and past President of the Green Gables Croquet Club. Also survived by his nieces Constance O'Leary Keller, Heidi Bovers Johnston and Hope O'Leary Frenette and nephews, William, Peter, Richard, Paul and Joseph Nugent O'Leary, Mark and Gregory Nugent and their families. Visitation will be held from 3-7pm on Sunday, October 7, 2012 at O'Brien's Funeral Home, 2028 Hwy 35, Wall, NJ. Mass of Christian Burial will be celebrated on Monday, October 8, at 11am at St. Catharine's Church in Spring Lake, NJ. Burial will follow at St. Catharine's Cemetery in Sea Girt. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to Meridian at Home Hospice, 1345 Campus Parkway, Suite A2, Neptune, NJ 07753-9930.

headline: A Narrower Lead, but Big Changes Probably Aren't the Cause
summary: We are beginning to see more national surveys now, including this week's New York Times/CBS News poll, which show Mitt Romney with a slight lead over President Obama in the general election matchup. To be sure, there are also a number of polls that put Mr. Obama slightly ahead. But his lead does seem to have narrowed - from about three or four points in an average of national polls a month or two ago to more like a point or so in surveys today. Has something fundamental changed in the race?

headline: Unleash the Crowd, Gingrich Says
summary: Watch the latest video at video.foxnews.comNewt Gingrich insists his fans will not be silenced. Mr. Gingrich, a former House speaker, on Tuesday morning threatened not participate in any future debates with audiences that have been instructed to be silent. That was the case on Monday, when Brian Williams of NBC News asked the audience of about 500 people who assembled for a debate in Tampa to hold their applause until the commercial breaks.

headline: After 36 Marathons, One Radio Goes Silent
summary: For each of the 36 years that the New York City Marathon has existed as a five-borough race, Steve Mendelsohn could be found in the lead vehicle with the race director, cruising along with the lead male runner and relaying messages on his ham radio. But in November, Mr. Mendelsohn will not be there. He died Wednesday morning of pancreatic cancer at his home in Dumont, N.J., said his wife, Heidi. He was 67.

headline: 'Housewives' Is a Winner
summary: Television viewers tuned in to say goodbye to the residents of Wisteria Lane on Sunday as the series finale of ''Desperate Housewives'' on ABC was the most-watched program of the night. The two-hour show added more viewers every half hour and finished with an average of 11.1 million and a 19 percent bump in the 18-to-49-year-old demographic compared to last week, according to Nielsen. While far below the 24 million viewer average of the show's water cooler-fueled first season, the finale was easily the best ratings performance for the series since March 2011. Elsewhere, ''Survivor: One World'' helped CBS secure second place with an average of 10.2 million viewers for the two-hour finale and another 8 million for the reunion episode that followed.

headline: Inside the Times
summary: International AMID FLEDGLING CEASE-FIRE,

headline: After a Short and Stormy Tenure as a Current TV Anchor, Olbermann Is Fired
summary: 10:06 p.m. | Updated For nearly a year now, Al Gore and Joel Hyatt have been building their liberal cable news channel, Current TV, with the mercurial television anchorman Keith Olbermann at its center. This week, the center collapsed.

headline: What’s On Sunday
summary: 10 P.M. (13) DEFIANT REQUIEM: VOICES OF RESISTANCE (2012) In 1944 a chorus of 60 inmates at the Terezin concentration camp in Czechoslovakia performed Verdi’s Requiem, led by the conductor Raphael Schächter and accompanied by a single piano, for senior Nazi officers and members of the International Red Cross. (Above, a re-enactment of the performance.) The men and women were singing what they dared not say, reimagining the Catholic work’s Latin text — which promises divine judgment against evil — as a condemnation of their captors. This documentary, in honor of Holocaust Remembrance Day, follows the conductor Murry Sidlin as, 60 years later, he realizes his dream of bringing his chorus and orchestra to Terezin to honor Mr. Schächter and others who were imprisoned. 10 A.M. (ABC) THIS WEEK Dan Pfeiffer, a senior adviser to President Obama, appears here and on “Fox News Sunday,” at 10, to discuss topics including tensions on the Korean Peninsula; a disappointing new jobs report; the president’s budget proposal, which includes cuts to Medicare and Social Security; and gun legislation. Senator Lindsey Graham, Republican of South Carolina and a member of the bipartisan Senate group known as the Gang of Eight, which is overseeing immigration legislation, continues the discussion on “Meet the Press,” at 10:30 on NBC. Senators Charles E. Schumer, Democrat of New York, and John McCain, Republican of Arizona, hold forth on the same topics on “Face the Nation,” at 10:30 on CBS.

headline: Twist for Online Viewing
summary: The N.C.A.A. men's basketball tournament is less than a month away, and Turner Sports on Thursday announced a new wrinkle for the rabid online viewing of it: a $3.99 pay option. Fans eager to watch the games streamed live - but who choose not to authenticate their cable, satellite or telephone company accounts on one of Turner's three Web sites - will have to pay the fee.

headline: Girlhood Memories of Another Ship Turned on Its Side
summary: First thing Saturday, Pierette Domenica Simpson's boyfriend called and said, ''Go online. You'll be interested.'' She checked the headlines. Something about an Italian ocean liner in trouble. The way the ship was listing, the report that it was taking on water, the light from the cabins reflecting in the water, the passengers' struggle to clamber into lifeboats - everything seemed so familiar. ''I thought, 'How can this be? It's 56 years later,' '' Ms. Simpson said.

headline: Paid Notice: Deaths EBERHARDT, JOHN HENRY
summary: EBERHARDT--John Henry, 92 of Palm Beach FL, Cherry Grove, NY, and Water Mill, NY passed away March 17, 2014. He was born November 18, 1921 in Newark, New Jersey. The son of Ulrich Seth Eberhardt and Ruth Schmidt Eberhardt, and is survived by William Eberhardt. John was one of four children. A child prodigy artist, he was painting murals in his church at the age of nine. John became a scenic artist and set designer. He worked for CBS, numerous Broadway productions, and also owned his own display business "On Display". He was a pioneer developer of Cherry Grove, Fire Island, NY. A self-taught architect, he built over fifty unique houses and his own personal residence, the magnificent "Belvedere", a Baroque Fantasy Palace that is now a Hotel. A long time Palm Beach resident, his home "Villa Fontana" is a showcase of his extraordinary talent. He was always the gracious host, opening the doors to many memorable parties and charity events. He will be remembered for his love of life and positive attitude no matter the circumstances. John had a great passion for animals, especially rescue dogs. He was never without a Dalmatian, his favorite breed. Memorial donations may be made to Peggy Adams Animal Rescue League, 3100/3200 North Military Trail, West Palm Beach, Florida 33409. Special thanks to Hospice of Palm Beach County.

headline: Paid Notice: Deaths OFFNER, ERIC DELMONTE
summary: OFFNER--Eric Delmonte, born in Vienna, Austria in 1928, founder of the jazz organization, The Sidney Bechet Society, son of Sigmund and Kathe Offner, died in his home in Manhasset Hills, New York, on June 3, 2014. Mr. Offner was twice widowed, having lost his beloved Julie Cosentino in 1959 and Carol Marcus in 1981, and divorced from Barbara Shotton. In 1938 he escaped with his immediate family to London. He was evacuated to Northhampton during the blitz under the care of the Halsey family. He immigrated with his biological family to Rio de Janeiro before settling in New York. Mr. Offner received his B.B.A. City College, 1949, and his JD, Cornell Law School, 1952. He is the author of numerous books on trademark law, including "International Trademark Protection." He lectured at George Washington University Law School, 1968-1972 and was a professor at Hofstra University Law School. He helped represent the American Bar Association with respect to the Trademark Registration Treaty, 1969-1973. He was a partner at the law firm of Hazeltine, Lake & Waters and later founded Offner & Kuhn, which represented leading brands like Canada Dry, CBS, and Mitsubishi on trademark law. In the late 1970's before its recognition by the US, Mr. Offner was a state guest of China to lecture on international trademark law. Mr. Offner was a soccer fanatic and was outside counsel to the US Soccer Federation in the 1970s and 80s. He helped sign Pele to wear Pony shoes upon Pele's arrival in the United States to play for the New York Cosmos in 1975. He was also counsel to celebrities including Liberace, Ernest Borgnine, and Dawn Steel. At the Sidney Bechet Society, Mr. Offner produced live jazz concerts for 17 seasons with leading musicians like Evan Christopher and Bob Wilber. Mr. Offner is survived by his son Gary Offner, his daughter-in-law Kathy Offner, and his two grandchildren, Grant (age 10), Kelly Rose (age three) and predeceased by his granddaughter Avery Grace. A memorial will be held on Sunday, June 8, 1:30pm at the Unitarian Universalist Congregation, 48 Shelter Rock Road, Manhasset, NY, 11030. In lieu of flowers, donations can be sent to Reach the Children, 14 Chesham Way, Fairport, NY 14450. Please note Eric Offner's name on any donation.

The son of Ulrich Seth Eberhardt and Ruth Schmidt Eberhardt, and is survived by William Eberhardt. John was one of four children. A child prodigy artist, he was painting murals in his church at the age of nine. John became a scenic artist and set designer. He worked for CBS, numerous Broadway productions, and also owned his own display business "On Display". He was a pioneer developer of Cherry Grove, Fire Island, NY. A self-taught architect, he built over fifty unique houses and his own personal residence, the magnificent "Belvedere", a Baroque Fantasy Palace that is now a Hotel. A long time Palm Beach resident, his home "Villa Fontana" is a showcase of his extraordinary talent. He was always the gracious host, opening the doors to many memorable parties and charity events. He will be remembered for his love of life and positive attitude no matter the circumstances. John had a great passion for animals, especially rescue dogs. He was never without a Dalmatian, his favorite breed. Memorial donations may be made to Peggy Adams Animal Rescue League, 3100/3200 North Military Trail, West Palm Beach, Florida 33409. Special thanks to Hospice of Palm Beach County.

headline: Bret Michaels Settles Suit About Injury at Tonys
summary: The curtain has come down on a lawsuit filed against the organizers of the Tony Awards and CBS by Bret Michaels, who said he had been injured by a piece of scenery in the awards show but has reached a settlement in the case, The Associated Press reported. Mr. Michaels, the frontman of the rock group Poison, was performing in the opening number of the 2009 Tony Awards show at Radio City Music Hall when a descending backdrop hit him on the head as he was leaving the stage. Mr. Michaels, who broke his nose and received three stitches in his lip, filed suit against the producers of the Tonys show, saying he was not warned about the set change in the opening number and that his injury contributed to a brain hemorrhage he was treated for in 2010. His lawsuit also named CBS, which shows the Tonys ceremony, saying the network did not have to broadcast his accident, which became a widely circulated video clip on the Internet.

headline: David Axelrod on “Face the Nation”
summary: In an appearance on CBS, David Axelrod says that Mitt Romney "hasn't been able to make the sale to his own party."

headline: Analysis: Comebacks and Consequences on Signing Day
summary: National signing day has turned into a made-for-television affair, with recruits selecting their universities' caps before crowds of friends and family members and an audience at home. The 2012 version of this annual rite yielded a few additional themes. The strong recruiting classes signed by Ohio State and Miami on Wednesday showed that prospects are willing to overlook N.C.A.A. sanctions (or the threat of penalties, in Miami's case) if the coach can sell the program.

headline: Paid Notice: Deaths KANTOR, ALICE
summary: KANTOR--Alice, passed January 6th. Fled Austria in 1938, and settled in New York. She was a researcher for Time Life and for CBS. She leaves behind her brother Gideon. She was a courageous woman and will never be forgotten.

headline: What's On Today
summary: 8 P.M. (CBS) 2 BROKE GIRLS The season ends as Max (Kat Dennings) and Caroline (Beth Behrs) plot to attend a fashion gala at the Metropolitan Museum of Art, where Martha Stewart (as herself, above left, with Ms. Dennings, center, and Ms. Behrs) is scheduled to be a guest so they can get her to taste their cupcakes. In the 200th episode of ''Two and a Half Men,'' at 9, Alan (Jon Cryer) is showered with affection when he returns from the hospital, but Zoey (Sophie Winkleman) isn't sure he deserves all the attention. Jason Alexander guest-stars as Alan's cardiologist. And in ''Mike & Molly,'' at 9:30, the wedding rehearsal of Molly (Melissa McCarthy) and Mike (Billy Gardell) is sabotaged by their family and friends. 7 A.M. (CUNY) ONE TO ONE In the first installment of a two-part interview, Sarah Burns, the author of ''The Central Park Five: The Untold History Behind One of New York City's Most Infamous Crimes,'' discusses the 1989 beating and rape of a white female jogger in Central Park, and the resulting arrest and imprisonment of one Latino and four black teenagers who were later exonerated. The book will soon be made into a documentary by Ms. Burns and her father, the filmmaker Ken Burns. In ''African-American Legends,'' at 8:30, Walter Dean Myers discusses his appointment as the national ambassador for young people's literature. And at 9 ''CUNY Forum -- Redistricting: Mapping the Future of New York's Political Communities'' reports on the redrawing of legislative districts following the 2010 census.

headline: As Gay Marriage Gains Ground in Nation, New Hampshire May Revoke Its Law
summary: As same-sex marriage supporters celebrate victories in Washington and Maryland this month, they are keeping a wary eye on New Hampshire, where lawmakers may soon vote to repeal the state's two-year-old law allowing gay couples to wed. A repeal bill appears to have a good chance of passing in the State House and Senate, which are both controlled by Republicans. The bigger question is whether they can muster enough votes to overcome a promised veto from Gov. John Lynch, a Democrat.

headline: What's On Sunday
summary: 8 P.M. (13); 9:30 P.M. (21) NATIONAL MEMORIAL DAY CONCERT This annual tribute will welcome troops who have returned from Iran and Afghanistan while examining the plight of homeless American veterans. Gary Sinise and Joe Mantegna team up for the seventh time as hosts of this live broadcast from the West Lawn of the United States Capitol. Selma Blair, Ellen Burstyn and Dennis Franz will read stories written by Brigette Cain, a young war widow; Amy Neil, a psychotherapist; and Larry Michaelis, who was injured during the Vietnam War. Jessica Sanchez, Daughtry (above), Natalie Cole, Trace Adkins and Russell Watson will perform, accompanied by the National Symphony Orchestra under the direction of Jack Everly. Other participants include Colin L. Powell, members of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, the Army Herald Trumpets, the Army Chorus, the Soldiers' Chorus of the United States Army Field Band, the Navy Band Sea Chanters and the Air Force Singing Sergeants. ''Hell and Back Again,'' an ''Independent Lens'' presentation at 9:30 on Channel 13, follows Sgt. Nathan Harris of the Marines as he transitions to civilian life after a life-threatening injury in Afghanistan. 9 A.M. (CNN) STATE OF THE UNION WITH CANDY CROWLEY The former New York City mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani, a Republican, and Representative Debbie Wasserman Schultz, the chairman of the Democratic National Committee, discuss the presidential campaign and the parties' agendas. Gen. Peter W. Chiarelli, a former Army vice chief of staff, discusses medical treatment for veterans and post-traumatic stress disorder.

headline: Bearcats Knock Off Florida State in a Far-From-Pretty Game
summary: NASHVILLE -- CBS slotted Florida State and Cincinnati as the late game on Sunday night, with tip-off coming at nearly 10 p.m. Eastern. Being cast in a time slot when the game would finish when many in America had gone to bed was a subtle way for CBS to acknowledge the obvious -- this game would not be pretty. And the instincts of the network executives proved correct, as Florida State and Cincinnati did not put on an aesthetic display of basketball in the N.C.A.A. tournament's Round of 32. With big bodies colliding into one another, sixth-seeded Cincinnati outmuscled third-seeded Florida State, 62-56.

headline: Inside The Times
summary: INTERNATIONAL NETANYAHU SEEKS EARLY ISRAELI ELECTIONS

headline: On The Campaign Plane: Secret Service Gun Left Behind
summary: TAMPA, Fla. -- A Secret Service agent was pulled off Mitt Romney's campaign plane on Wednesday after accidentally leaving her loaded handgun in the bathroom. A CBS News producer found the gun in the lavatory as the Republican nominee flew from Tampa, Fla., to Indianapolis for a speech on Wednesday. An agent on the plane was alerted and retrieved the gun without incident.

headline: What's On Today
summary: 7 P.M. (HBO) ONE DAY (2011) Anne Hathaway and Jim Sturgess (above) portray Emma and Dex -- she's bookish, serious and from a family of modest means; he's dashing, irresponsible and wealthy -- who meet, as drunken university graduates, on St. Swithin's Day in 1988 and proceed to reunite on that date, July 15, each year. Rafe Spall and Romola Garai play the characters who would seem to be Emma and Dex's perfect matches. Ken Stott and Patricia Clarkson are Dex's parents. Lone Scherfig, ''a veteran of the Danish Dogme 95 movement, whose previous English-language films are 'Wilbur Wants to Kill Himself' and 'An Education,' can be a wonderfully centrifugal director, wandering away from the center of a conventional narrative toward its scruffy margins, where the interesting stuff happens,'' A. O. Scott wrote in The New York Times. ''Her eccentric eye and offbeat rhythm sustain 'One Day' through its stretches of banality and mitigate some of its flaws. Among these are a superficial sense of history -- remember how girls used to wear their hair? remember nuclear disarmament? -- and, more seriously, a late, disastrous dive into the deep end of weepitude.'' 7:45 P.M. (Bravo) THE SILENCE OF THE LAMBS (1991) Just in time for dinner -- fava beans and a nice Chianti, perhaps? -- the network offers back-to-back screenings of this Jonathan Demme thriller about Clarice Starling (Jodie Foster), an F.B.I. trainee who enlists the help of Hannibal Lecter (Anthony Hopkins, above), a sociopath with a taste for human flesh, in tracking a serial killer. The film won Oscars for best actor, best actress, best screenplay based on previously published material, best director and best picture.

headline: Romney Assures Evangelicals That Their Values Are His, Too
summary: LYNCHBURG, Va. -- Mitt Romney traveled to Liberty University, the spiritual heart of the conservative movement, on Saturday, seeking to quell concerns about him among evangelical voters by offering a forceful defense of faith and Christian values in public life. At a graduation speech at the college, founded by the evangelical leader Jerry Falwell, Mr. Romney made the case that he is bound theologically and politically to the same belief and value system as Christian conservatives, though he never explicitly mentioned his Mormon faith.

headline: What's On Today
summary: 8:30 P.M. (13) FAUST Des McAnuff, the artistic director of the Stratford Shakespeare Festival, whose revival of ''Jesus Christ Superstar'' is now on Broadway, makes his Metropolitan Opera debut with Gounod's ''Faust,'' updated to the 20th century. Jonas Kaufmann stars as a nuclear scientist, despairing of the effects of his life's work, who makes a contract with the Devil. Marina Poplavskaya, above with Mr. Kaufmann, is Marguerite, Faust's love interest and eventual victim, and René Pape reprises his role as Méphistophélès. Yannick Nézet-Séguin conducted this ''Great Performances at the Met'' presentation, which was shown live in movie theaters on Dec. 10. ''It is better if a production does not look too deeply for elements of existential despair that are simply not in the piece, and that seems the problem with the new 'Faust,' '' Anthony Tommasini wrote in The New York Times, adding that this co-production with the English National Opera, ''though rich with ideas and theatrically daring, is finally rather clinical and oppressive.'' 7:45 A.M. (IFC) AWAY FROM HER (2007) Fiona and Grant, a long-married couple played by Julie Christie and Gordon Pinsent, confront Alzheimer's disease in the feature directorial debut of Sarah Polley, who earned an Oscar nomination for her screenplay, based on an Alice Munro short story. ''There is, in Ms. Munro's mature work, a flinty wisdom about heterosexual love, a skepticism about romantic ideals that does not altogether deny their power or necessity,'' A. O. Scott wrote in The Times. ''Ms. Polley, rather remarkably for someone still in her 20s, shows an intuitive grasp of this wisdom and a welcome, unsentimental interest in the puzzles and pleasures of a long, imperfect marriage.'' He added, ''I can't remember the last time the movies yielded up a love story so painful, so tender and so true.''

headline: Paid Notice: Deaths KANTOR, ALICE
summary: KANTOR--Alice, passed January 6th. Fled Austria in 1938, and settled in New York. She was a researcher for Time Life and for CBS. She leaves behind her brother Gideon. She was a courageous woman and will never be forgotten.

headline: Excerpt: ‘Hawaii Five-O’
summary: A scene in Monday’s episode of “Hawaii Five-O” doubled as an ad for Subway.

headline: TV Ratings System Expected to Expand Online
summary: The black labels that tell families what to expect from network television shows will start to appear on the Internet streams of those shows, too. The expansion of the TV content ratings system is expected to be announced by the major broadcast networks on Monday morning. The ratings will be included in all episodic streams on Web sites like ABC.com and Fox.com by December, according to people with knowledge of the plan, who insisted on anonymity because it had not yet been made public.

headline: Corrections
summary: An article on Wednesday about the CBS executive Mike Aresco's being named the commissioner of the Big East Conference gave an outdated title for Sean McManus. He is the chairman, not president, of CBS Sports. (He was president from 1996 to 2011.)

headline: Political Memo: A Post-Primary Window to Define a Challenger
summary: There is no good time for a presidential candidate to face what Mitt Romney faced last week, when The Washington Post reported that he had tormented a fellow student while at prep school in the 1960s. But the months between the end of the primary season and the formal start of the general election at the conventions are an especially perilous period for candidates in Mr. Romney's position.

headline: What's On Today
summary: 9 P.M. (13) DON GIOVANNI Mariusz Kwiecien makes his Metropolitan Opera debut as Mozart's promiscuous nobleman in this new production from Michael Grandage, originally broadcast in theaters on Oct. 29 and presented here by ''Great Performances at the Met.'' Marina Rebeka and Mojca Erdmann sing the roles of Donna Anna and Zerlina, two of Giovanni's conquests; Barbara Frittoli (above, with Mr. Kwiecien) is the fiery Donna Elvira, his spurned lover out for revenge; Ramón Vargas is Donna Anna's fiancé, Don Ottavio; and Luca Pisaroni is Giovanni's hapless manservant, Leporello. Mr. Kwiecien, who injured himself at a dress rehearsal and was replaced for opening night and two other performances, ''looked nimble on his feet, sang robustly and threw himself into the title role,'' Anthony Tommasini wrote in The New York Times. ''Whatever one's take on Mr. Kwiecien's portrayal of a role he considers his calling card, his performance was a triumph of physical rehabilitation and artistic determination.'' Mr. Tommasini called the orchestra's performance under Fabio Luisi, the Met's principal conductor, ''a fleet, clear-textured and wonderfully natural account of this multilayered, ingenious score.'' 7 A.M. (Cinemax) BIG FISH (2003) Albert Finney plays Edward Bloom (Ewan McGregor is his youthful version), a traveling salesman from Alabama who has spent a lifetime shading and embellishing the truth in this fantasy from Tim Burton, adapted from the novel by Daniel Wallace. Billy Crudup is Bloom's estranged son, Will, a reporter in Paris who has been summoned home for a deathbed reconciliation, during which Edward elaborates on his biography. Edward's doctor asks: Wouldn't Will prefer to believe that on the day of his birth his father was subduing a legendary catfish rather than selling household gadgets in Wichita? ''The movie insists that the only possible answer is yes, and thus chooses maudlin moonshine over engagement with the difficulties of real life, which is exactly the choice Edward has made,'' A. O. Scott wrote in The Times. ''In their eagerness to celebrate Edward's grand spirit, the filmmakers wind up diminishing it, declining to explore the causes or the costs of his addiction to fantasy.'' Danny Elfman received an Oscar nomination for best original score.

headline: What's On Today
summary: 8 P.M. (CBS) PERSON TO PERSON Lara Logan and Charlie Rose visit the Los Angeles home of George Clooney, the Omaha office of Warren Buffett (above), and the New Jersey recording studio of Jon Bon Jovi to interview them about their most prized possessions. The program is based on the series originated in 1953 by Edward R. Murrow, who took viewers into the homes of John F. Kennedy, then a Massachusetts senator, and his wife, Jacqueline; Elizabeth Taylor; and Lauren Bacall and Humphrey Bogart. Mr. Clooney received Oscar nominations for best director and best original screenplay for ''Good Night, and Good Luck,'' his 2005 film about Murrow. 12:15 P.M. (HBO) DOWN WITH LOVE (2003) Renée Zellweger stars as Barbara Novak, a Maine author who arrives in Manhattan to publish a manifesto that argues for equality of the sexes, from the bedroom to the boardroom. Ewan McGregor is Catcher Block, a high-flying playboy and magazine writer on a mission to expose the holes in her philosophy by making her fall in love with him. Peyton Reed directed this buoyant homage to Rock Hudson-Doris Day pictures, with its ''deliciously contrived setup,'' A. O. Scott wrote in The New York Times. ''Every inch of every Cinemascope frame -- from the zippy title credits to the geographically absurd Manhattan sets to the modular furniture to the glass martini pitchers -- is designed to plunge you into a fairy-tale 1962.''

headline: Paid Notice: Deaths KRAMER, HERBERT
summary: KRAMER--Justice Herbert, New York State Supreme Court for 33 years, beloved husband, brother, father, grandfather, great-grandfather, respected and beloved colleague, Kings County Supreme Court Justices Association President, CB Chair, Assistant US Attorney, NYU Law School graduate.

headline: What's On Today
summary: 9 P.M. (Starz) MIDNIGHT IN PARIS (2011) In Paris with his fiancée and her parents, Gil (Owen Wilson, above with Marion Cotillard), an aspiring novelist with a nostalgic bent, goes for long walks each night and is magically transported to the 1920s. Though he wakes up each morning in the present, he spends his nights consorting with Picasso (Marcial Di Fonzo Bo), F. Scott Fitzgerald (Tom Hiddleston), Salvador Dalí (Adrien Brody) and other notables, delighting in the glamour of the Paris described as a ''Moveable Feast'' by Hemingway (Corey Stoll). A. O. Scott wrote in The New York Times that the film ''is marvelously romantic, even though -- or precisely because -- it acknowledges the disappointment that shadows every genuine expression of romanticism.'' Woody Allen, who wrote and directed the movie, won an Academy Award for best original screenplay. Noon (13) RICHARD HEFFNER'S OPEN MINDDavid Segal, a reporter for The Times, discusses the quality of education at law schools in the United States and why graduates are not necessarily prepared to practice law.

headline: What's On Today
summary: 6:45 A.M. (HBO) BOBBY FISCHER AGAINST THE WORLD (2011) Liz Garbus (''The Farm: Angola, U.S.A.'') profiles Fischer (1943-2008), above, the prickly individualist from Brooklyn who became a chess grandmaster and in 1972 turned his match with Boris Spassky, his Soviet counterpart, into a global media event. She also documents Fischer's inner turmoil, which in later years prompted him to live in exile in Japan and Iceland and to give voice to a worldview rife with conspiracy theories and anti-Semitism, despite his Jewish background. ''What happened?'' A. O. Scott asked in The New York Times. The film, he wrote, ''tactfully but strongly posits a connection between the genius he brought to an infinitely complex game and the madness that defined his relationship to just about everything else.'' And yet, Mr. Scott added, ''if he had been spared fame, the world would have been denied a share of sublimity, and the kingdom of chess would never have found its wayward, dazzling, tragic prince.'' 8 P.M. (CBS) NCIS When a Navy reservist with high-level security clearance is found dead, Gibbs (Mark Harmon) clashes with Dr. Samantha Ryan (Jamie Lee Curtis) of the PsyOps Division as he tries to uncover the truth about the reservist's apparent suicide. In ''NCIS: Los Angeles,'' at 9, the team is shocked to discover that all evidence points to the guilt of Special Agent Kensi Blye (Daniela Ruah) in the murder of a former colleague of her dead father's.

headline: In Debates, Two Women Will Moderate
summary: The moderating duties for the four presidential and vice- presidential debates this year will be evenly split between male and female journalists for the first time, the Commission on Presidential Debates said Monday, nearly two months before debate season begins.The moderators will be Jim Lehrer of PBS, Bob Schieffer of CBS, Candy Crowley of CNN and Martha Raddatz of ABC, the commission said after a long and mostly secret selection process.

headline: ‘Buckwild’ Suspends Production After a Death
summary: MTV has suspended production on its reality series “Buckwild” in the wake of news that one of its most popular cast members, Shain Gandee, was found dead on Monday. Details about Mr. Gandee’s death remained unclear on Monday, though several news reports said he had been discovered along with two other men, one of them his uncle, in an all-terrain vehicle near his home in Sissonville, W.Va. CBS News reported that the men were last seen at 3 a.m. Sunday in a bar and had told other patrons that they intended to do off-road driving. In the “Buckwild” series off-road driving, which the characters called “mudding,” was central to several of the episodes. The show, which chronicled the daily adventures of a group of young adults from rural West Virginia , had been called “Appalachian Jersey Shore” by some reviewers.

headline: What's On Today
summary: 9 P.M. (13, 49) MARGARET MITCHELL: AMERICAN REBEL Mitchell, above, the author of ''Gone With the Wind,'' won a Pulitzer Prize for her novel and used royalties from it to pay for the education of some the first black doctors in the South. She was also among the first female newspaper reporters in Georgia. This profile, part of the ''American Masters'' series, includes re-enactments of her life based on her correspondence. 11:40 A.M. (IFC) THE TAVERN (2000) A bartender hears the knock of opportunity when offered the chance to own a tavern, only to learn that he is unprepared for the pressure and responsibility of running a small business. Ronnie (Cameron Dye), the man with the plan, doesn't have enough money, so he borrows some from his family and joins with his friend Dave (Kevin Geer), who ponies up the rest. But the competition in Manhattan is tough, and the bar's former owner opens a new establishment that attracts the old customers.

headline: Paid Notice: Deaths NICOTRA, FRANK JOSEPH
summary: NICOTRA--Frank Joseph, formerly of Pelham Manor, died on March 12, 2014, in Minneapolis, MN. He was 87. Frank was the proud son of Italian immigrants, Giovanni and Sebastiana (Arcidiacono) Nicotra and was born December 16, 1927. He is preceded in death by his wife Ruth Nicotra and his daughter Linda Ann Kinsman. A Veteran of WW II, Frank later received his degree in engineering from City College and an MBA from NYU. His professional career included the Department of the Navy, Turner Construction, CBS, and many productive years at Rockefeller Center. Frank had a wide range of interests including travel, the stock market, opera and loved animals. He was a terrific dancer, a patient chauffeur to his wife and family, and a doting husband, father and grandfather. Frank believed the true measure of a man was the ability to weather adversity, and he faced his challenging last years with dignity and humor. He is survived by his son and daughter-in-law, John and Lisa Nicotra of Minneapolis; his granddaughters, Kimberly and Victoria; and son-in-law Eddie Kinsman of Ridgefield, CT. He will be greatly missed. Visiting hours will be held at Pelham Funeral Home, 64 Lincoln Ave., Pelham, NY on Tuesday, March 18th between 2-4pm and 7-9pm. The Funeral Mass will be held at Our Lady of Perpetual Help Church in Pelham Manor, NY, 10:30am on Wednesday, Mar-ch 19th with interment to follow at St. Raymond's Cemetery in the Bronx. Memorials: Doctors without Borders and North Shore Animal League.
