Memorials: Doctors without Borders and North Shore Animal League.

headline: Corrections
summary: An article on Monday about Representative Gabrielle Giffords's decision to resign from Congress in order to concentrate on recovering from her shooting injury, misidentified the television show on which she and her husband were interviewed in November when she demonstrated her improved ability to speak. It was ABC's ''20/20'' program, in an interview with Diane Sawyer -- not the CBS program ''60 Minutes.''

headline: What's On Today
summary: 8 P.M. (CBS) SURVIVOR: ONE WORLD The old saying ''no pain, no gain'' will be tested this week as the competition for $1 million continues. (Above, Greg Smith, left, and Jay Byars during an immunity challenge.) With both tribes living on the same site, drama runs high as the tribal council makes an unexpected decision. 1:30 P.M. (Sundance) GRIZZLY MAN (2005) Timothy Treadwell, who spent many of his summers living with and filming grizzly bears in the Katmai National Park and Preserve in Alaska, below, was killed in a bear attack in 2003, along with his girlfriend, Amie Huguenard. The director Werner Herzog combed through their footage to create this documentary, which casts an unsentimental eye on Treadwell's mission to protect the grizzlies and questions his preparation for life in the wilderness. Interviews with family members and friends shed light on Treadwell's past as an actor who struggled with addiction. And those who last saw him, including the medical examiner who performed his autopsy, depict him as a man who failed to appreciate the power and danger of nature. Writing in The New York Times, Manohla Dargis said that Treadwell's adventures with grizzlies amounted to ''a kind of performance, built on lies and truth and played out on the stage of celebrity.'' She added, ''Even though his choices were dangerous and finally fatal, he traveled a familiar American path shaped by boundless optimism and an almost religious belief in the self.''

headline: A Scorecard Filled with Scholarships
summary: KIAWAH ISLAND, S.C. - Wesley Bauguess still chokes up every time she tells the story of how her husband, Army Maj. Larry Bauguess, died at 36 during efforts to settle a border dispute. It was May 14, 2007, and her husband was participating in a peace meeting involving United States, Afghanistan and Pakistan forces in a tribal region of Pakistan. By all accounts, the meeting was successful. The participants shook hands, posed for photographs and exchanged coins. But as Bauguess and his men prepared to leave, a uniformed Pakistani soldier reportedly opened fire at close range. Bauguess was at the point of attack and shielded others, which allowed his team time to react. Several men were wounded, but he was the only one killed, leaving behind two young daughters, Ryann and Ellie.

headline: For 'CBS This Morning,' Showtime Has Arrived
summary: It is exceedingly rare for a new television newscast to be made almost entirely from scratch, as is the case with ''CBS This Morning,'' which will replace ''The Early Show'' on Monday morning. Many of the producers and talent bookers for ''CBS This Morning'' are new to the network, as are two of the three anchors, Charlie Rose and Gayle King.

headline: Best Sellers: E-Book Nonfiction: Sunday, June 17th 2012
summary: About the Best Sellers: These lists are an expanded version of those appearing in the June 17, 2012 print edition of the Book Review, reflecting sales for the week ending June 2, 2012. An asterisk (*) indicates that a book's sales are barely distinguishable from those of the book above it. A dagger (†) indicates that some retailers report receiving bulk orders. For an explanation of our methodology, visit http://www.nytimes.com/best-sellers.

headline: A New Way To Stream Broadcast Television
summary: 11:40 a.m. | Updated Barry Diller, who created the Fox television network almost 30 years ago, now wants to free it and other networks from the chains of what he calls the ''closed cable-broadcast-satellite circle.''

headline: Letterman Anniversary Is Like a Low-Key Guest
summary: 5:12 p.m. | Updated David Letterman will celebrate 30 years as a late-night television host on Wednesday, though without much fanfare. There has been little media attention paid to the anniversary, and no prime-time special, or even a special celebration, planned by CBS.

headline: What's On Sunday
summary: 9 P.M. (OWN) OPRAH'S NEXT CHAPTER Oprah Winfrey interviews Whitney Houston's daughter, Bobbi Kristina Brown (above, with Ms. Winfrey); her sister-in-law and manager, Patricia Houston; and her brother, Gary Houston, about the speculation surrounding Ms. Houston's death on Feb. 11. 10 A.M. (CNN) FAREED ZAKARIA GPS Former Secretary of State Henry A. Kissinger discusses the political situations in Iran, Syria and other hot spots in the Middle East, as well as in China and Russia. Elliott Abrams, a senior fellow for Middle Eastern studies with the Council on Foreign Relations, and Rula Jebreal, a Palestinian journalist, talk about the visit of Israel's prime minister, Benjamin Netanyahu, to the White House.

headline: Judge Says Aereo, a TV Streaming Service, May Continue
summary: Aereo, the service backed by Barry Diller, can keep streaming for now. A federal judge on Wednesday denied a temporary injunction sought by television broadcasters that would have shut down Aereo, a start-up that streams local TV stations' signals to customers over the Internet without the explicit permission of the stations.

headline: What's On Today
summary: 9:30 A.M. (Flix) THE PREACHER'S WIFE (1996) Denzel Washington, above, plays a trench-coat-and-fedora-clad angel who enters the lives of an urban minister (Courtney B. Vance) facing bankruptcy and the possible demolition of his church, and his neglected wife (Whitney Houston), who also directs the choir, in this update of the 1947 comedy ''The Bishop's Wife,'' starring Cary Grant, David Niven and Loretta Young. Writing in The New York Times, Stephen Holden said Ms. Houston, who died on Saturday, ''barely has to act to bring a gritty nobility to the title role of Penny Marshall's sweetly uplifting film.'' All she has to do, he added, ''is sing, and you begin to believe in angels, miracles, happily ever after and all the other corny items that this inspirational comedy spills across the holiday table.'' Among the movie's highlights are Ms. Houston singing gospel with the Georgia Mass Choir and her pop ballad ''I Believe in You and Me.'' Hans Zimmer earned an Oscar nomination for best musical score. 8 P.M. (CW) GOSSIP GIRL Blair (Leighton Meester) plays Cupid and shoots her arrow in the direction of Dan (Penn Badgley, below, with Ms. Meester) and Serena (Blake Lively). Nate (Chace Crawford) finds Lola (Ella Rae Peck) harder and harder to resist, but the feeling may not be mutual. And Georgina (Michelle Trachtenberg) crashes a Valentine's Day party. The band St. Vincent performs. In ''Hart of Dixie,'' at 9, Wade (Wilson Bethel) has Lemon (Jaime King) disguise herself. And George (Scott Porter) asks Zoe (Rachel Bilson) for her medical expertise.

headline: What's On Today
summary: 2:30 P.M. (HBO2) SEPARATE LIES (2005) In this directorial debut from Julian Fellowes (''Downton Abbey''), who adapted the screenplay from Nigel Balchin's novel ''A Way Through the Wood,'' Tom Wilkinson portrays James Manning, a London lawyer who spares no one his imperious authority, not even his wife, Anne (Emily Watson, above with Mr. Wilkinson). When the husband of their cleaning woman is killed in a hit-and-run accident, James suspects that Bill Bule (Rupert Everett), a family acquaintance who attended a party at the Mannings' home that evening, was driving the car. Then Anne confesses that she and Bill are having an affair -- and that she was behind the wheel. But instead of allowing her to go to the police, James constructs an alibi. ''This powerful performance, equal in stature to Mr. Wilkinson's grieving father in 'In the Bedroom,' pushes 'Separate Lies' halfway toward the rarefied class of that 2001 film,'' Stephen Holden wrote in The New York Times. ''But that's not nearly far enough to begin to lift this intriguing but chilly moral puzzle to anything close to greatness.'' 9 A.M. (CUNY) REVISITING THE GREAT SOCIETY: THE ROLE OF GOVERNMENT FROM F.D.R. AND L.B.J. TO TODAY The roots and legacy of President Lyndon B. Johnson are explored by Robert A. Caro, his Pulitzer Prize-winning biographer; former Vice Present Walter F. Mondale; former Senator George S. McGovern; and the journalist Bill Moyers in this two-hour report, culled from a symposium presented last month by the Roosevelt House Public Policy Institute at Hunter College. Highlights include a panel discussion moderated by Bob Schieffer of CBS News as well as archival photographs and audio recordings of Johnson in conversation with the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. and presenting a speech in 1965 before a joint session of Congress. The program will be repeated a 3 and 9 p.m.

headline: What's On Sunday
summary: 8 P.M. (13, 49) FINDING YOUR ROOTS WITH HENRY LOUIS GATES JR. The married actors Kevin Bacon and Kyra Sedgwick, above, are both descended from prominent American families that have been in this country since its inception. But this episode reveals other similarities, including ancestors who were early abolitionists. Mr. Bacon's Quaker clan repudiated slavery in 1780. And in 1781 Theodore Sedgwick argued the case of Elizabeth Freeman, known as Mumbet, which helped end slavery in Massachusetts. 10 A.M. (ABC) THIS WEEK WITH GEORGE STEPHANOPOULOS In a special Easter broadcast with Jake Tapper filling in for Mr. Stephanopoulos, Pastor Rick Warren of the Saddleback Church in Lake Forest, Calif., talks about the spiritual climate of the nation, culture wars, the intersection of church and state, and keeping faith in difficult times. Mr. Tapper also speaks with Mr. Warren's wife, Kay Warren, about her new book, ''Choose Joy: Because Happiness Isn't Enough.''

headline: What's On Today
summary: 7 P.M. (USA) NFL CHARACTERS UNITE Tony Gonzalez of the Atlanta Falcons, Jimmy Graham of the New Orleans Saints, Hines Ward of the Pittsburgh Steelers (above right, with Carlton Dennis, a student) and Tony Dungy, a former head coach for the Indianapolis Colts and the Tampa Bay Buccaneers, discuss the hate and bigotry they overcame as children to find success in pro football. This documentary also follows the men as they work with teenagers mired in similar situations. 1 P.M. (BET) AMERICAN VIOLET (2009) Nicole Beharie is Dee Roberts, a young African-American mother of four who is charged with distributing narcotics in a school zone in her small Texas town and risks going to trial instead of accepting a plea bargain for a crime she insists she didn't commit. Xzibit plays the father of her two youngest children; his desire for custody may be at the root of Dee's predicament. Michael O'Keefe is the local district attorney who is sued for racial discrimination by an American Civil Liberties Union lawyer (Tim Blake Nelson) on Dee's behalf. And Alfre Woodard is her mother. Writing in The New York Times, Stephen Holden said that this film from Tim Disney, based on real events in 2000, is ''beautifully acted by Ms. Beharie, whose high-strung character is no angel.'' The film was selected as a New York Times Critics' Pick.

headline: Recent Lease
summary: $36/SQUARE FOOT $144,432 approximate annual rent

headline: Paid Notice: Deaths LEIGHTON, HALLIE
summary: LEIGHTON--Hallie Leland, 42, who fought successfully for passage of New York State's Breast Density Inform Bill, while fighting her own losing battle with metastatic breast cancer died on April 30, 2013. She gave media interviews telling her own story, urging women to find out if they have dense tissue, not itself abnormal but sometimes masking tumors in mammograms, and to inquire about further testing. She supported the organization, "Are You Dense?," lobbied for the bill in Albany, and started an advocacy blog. The bill became NYS law in January, 2013. Hallie brought the same passion, intellect, and devotion to this cause as to her other interests and many friendships. Born and raised in NYC, Hallie went to the High School of Performing Arts, attended St. John's College in Annapolis, and graduated from the Santa Fe campus where she was editor of the college newspaper. Her career was varied, but never strayed far from her love of language and writing. She started collecting words at age 13 when she encountered hussar and bivouac in Tolstoy's War and Peace. "I treat words I have just learned like new acquaintances; no matter how well we hit it off on a first meeting, I don't assume intimacy." With her late father, the actor/impersonator Jan Leighton, she co-authored two books, Rare Words I and II (Levenger Press, 2003, 2008), which used humor to help master meanings. After college, Hallie worked at Random House and Knopf, was a writer's assistant on As the World Turns at CBS, and wrote columns for Cotton, Inc. that appeared regularly in Women's Wear Daily. She went to Israel in an arts program in the Negev, where she wrote about the Bedouin and stayed two more years because "the adventure wasn't over," working with organizations that promoted peace between Arabs and Israelis. Back in the U.S. she became Director of Communications for Charity Brands, a firm that connected corporations with good causes. At the time of her death, she was working on a documentary on her father's unusual career - he had played more roles than any other actor (2407) according to the 1985 Guinness Book of World Records. Hallie is survived by her mother, Lynda Myles, her Aunt Wendie Myles, her brother Ross Leighton, and a large, loving extended family. There will be a memorial service to celebrate her life and share memories at The Society for Ethical Culture, 2 West 64th Street, NYC, Thursday, June 13, 5:30pm. Gifts to support Hallie's favored charities can be made to the Jewish Communal Fund (att: Hallie Leighton Tikkun Olam Fund), 575 Madison Ave. #703, NY, NY 10022 or jcfny.org/donate.

headline: What's On Sunday
summary: 8 P.M. (Fox) THE SIMPSONS The series celebrates its 500th episode as Homer's drunken antics, Bart's shenanigans and Lisa's activism get the Simpsons booted out of Springfield. So they move to an off-the-grid, post-apocalyptic encampment called the Outlands. Alison Krauss performs the theme song. 10 A.M. (CNN) FAREED ZAKARIA GPS Gen. Martin Dempsey, chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, discusses the situation in Syria, the possibility of Iran's striking Israel, the strength of the Chinese Army and whether the United States military will be able to defend the nation properly, given proposed budget cuts.

headline: Paid Notice: Deaths GRAD, ROBERT J.
summary: GRAD--Robert John, 65, of Brewster, NY, died April 17, 2013. He was born January 17, 1948. Bob had many loves: science, music, technology and his friends and family. He was a guitar and auto enthusiast and a huge early fan of the Everly Brothers and Bob Dylan. In his teens, he invented, among other things, an early illuminated Frisbee-type device; designed a primitive lie detector faithfully tested out on a partially willing younger brother, and constructed an elevator device that carried pebbles, hair brushes and turtles outside a seventh floor apartment window facing Arnow Avenue in the Bronx. He went on to create and manage computer systems for IBM and CBS and design software programs, working feverishly for years on a high-speed stock-trade software program before the concept became popular, and came close to putting the final touches on it before the onset of an intestinal disorder that eventually claimed his life. He attended Christopher Columbus High School and the Courant Institute of Mathematical Sciences at NYU. He was predeceased by his father, Zoltan, and is survived by his mother, Fay, of the Bronx; his brother, Peter, of Ridgewood, NJ., cousins, aunts and an extended family of close friends from Kerhonkson to Brewster to Cold Spring, NY.

headline: Kristin Chenoweth Recovering After Accident
summary: The actress Kristin Chenoweth was released from the hospital after she was injured Wednesday during the filming of the CBS series ''The Good Wife.'' In a statement on Thursday, Jill Fritzo, a publicist for Ms. Chenoweth, said: ''Kristin has been released from the hospital and is home recovering. She thanks everyone for their prayers and well wishes.''

headline: Preserving Music With Social Significance
summary: Recordings of Donna Summer's ''I Feel Love,'' Leonard Bernstein's first performance with the New York Philharmonic, ''Rapper's Delight'' by the Sugarhill Gang and a 1977 concert by the Grateful Dead are among the diverse entries that will be added to the National Recording Registry, the Library of Congress is to announce on Wednesday. Selected for preservation because they are ''culturally, historically, or aesthetically significant'' the library said in a news release, the 25 sound recordings chosen this year include a CBS radio broadcast of a Nov. 14, 1943, concert given by the Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra of New York and conducted by Bernstein, who filled in when both Artur Rodzinski and Bruno Walter were unavailable; as well as the Grateful Dead's May 8, 1977, performance at Cornell University's Barton Hall, which the library said ''has achieved almost mythic status among 'Deadhead' tape traders because of its excellent sound quality and early accessibility.'' Also chosen for induction were Bo Diddley's single ''Bo Diddley'' (and its B-side, ''I'm a Man''); the Booker T. & the M.G.'s single ''Green Onions''; the 1967 album ''Forever Changes'' by the psychedelic rock band Love; the soundtrack album of ''A Charlie Brown Christmas,'' performed by the Vince Guaraldi Trio; and ''Purple Rain,'' the 1984 soundtrack album performed by Prince and the Revolution.

headline: Critic's Notebook: Playing a Role, Even as Himself
summary: When Richard Dawson first turned up as host of ''Family Feud'' in 1976, some people might well have done a double-take. ''What is this?'' they might have asked. ''An actor disguised as a game show host?'' That's because before ''Family Feud,'' there was ''Hogan's Heroes,'' a popular sitcom about captives in a German prisoner-of-war camp in World War II. Mr. Dawson, who died on Saturday at 79, played one of the prisoners, Cpl. Peter Newkirk, and along with a cast that included Bob Crane, Ivan Dixon, Robert Clary, John Banner and Werner Klemperer helped to prove that Nazi Germany could be funny. Mel Brooks's film version of ''The Producers'' was still three years in the future when the series made its debut on CBS in September 1965.

headline: Another Chance For Arsenio Hall
summary: After an absence longer than many careers in show business, Arsenio Hall will be attempting a comeback in late-night television when a new syndicated show begins in over a year. Mr. Hall and partners that include CBS Television Distribution and stations owned by the Tribune Company announced on Monday that they had agreed to introduce a late-night show starring Mr. Hall in the fall of 2013.

headline: Fierce '60 Minutes' Interrogator Who Didn't Blink
summary: Mike Wallace, the CBS reporter who became one of America's best-known broadcast journalists as an interrogator of the famous and infamous on ''60 Minutes,'' died on Saturday. He was 93. On its Web site, CBS said Mr. Wallace died at a care facility in New Canaan, Conn., where he had lived in recent years. Mr. Wallace, who received a pacemaker more than 20 years ago, had a long history of cardiac care and underwent triple bypass heart surgery in January 2008.

headline: The Money Race: A Milestone for Obama
summary: When President Obama boards Air Force One and departs New York City on Thursday night, he will have hit a notable milestone: He will have held more than 100 fund-raising events for his re-election effort in less than a year. That is more than President George W. Bush held during the entire 2004 cycle, according to unofficial tallies kept by the CBS reporter Mark Knoller, suggesting the intense pace of Mr. Obama's fund-raising as he prepares to battle Republicans and the independent groups likely to spend tens of millions of dollars to defeat him.

headline: What's On Today
summary: 9:50 A.M. (HBO Signature) THE AMERICAN (2010) Before ''The Descendants'' and ''The Ides of March'' brought him Oscar nominations in this latest awards season, George Clooney, above, played a gun-toting expatriate who arrives in a small Italian town after a mishap on his previous job and takes an assignment to build a custom weapon for a sexy assassin (Thekla Reuten). ''I'm out,'' he says at one point, intent on making the kind of human connection that his taciturn temperament and job -- as a hit man, perhaps -- have denied him until now. Soon he has made friends with a priest (Paolo Bonacelli) and a prostitute (Violante Placido), who is so enamored of his prowess in bed that she stops charging him. The film, directed by Anton Corbijn from a script by Rowan Joffe, by ''filtering out any mention of the character's history and suppressing all but the tiniest indications of emotion, tries to strip the man to his essence,'' A. O. Scott wrote in The New York Times. ''But there is not quite enough there: the still waters run very cool but not terribly deep, and 'The American' falls back into a view of its protagonist that is ultimately more sentimental than unsettling or intriguing.'' 9 A.M. (Cinemax) WALL STREET: MONEY NEVER SLEEPS (2010) In this sequel to Oliver Stone's 1987 drama, ''Wall Street,'' Michael Douglas, right, returns as the reptilian Gekko, the ruthless corporate raider who, after serving an eight-year prison sentence, has landed in the public spotlight once again for writing a critical and prescient book about the state of the markets. Shia LaBeouf is the investment banker Jake Moore, one of Gekko's fans and the live-in love of Gekko's estranged daughter (Carey Mulligan). Frank Langella is the old-school broker who has been like a father to Jake. And Josh Brolin is the newest snake in town. Let the games resume.

headline: 'General Hospital' Blessed With a 50th Season by ABC
summary: Maybe it was Farah Fath, a former soap opera star, who said it best on Wednesday when ABC confirmed that it had renewed ''General Hospital'' for a landmark 50th season. Congratulating the cast and crew in a Twitter message, she wrote, ''A soap renewal in 2012 is nothing short of victorious.''

headline: Paid Notice: Deaths KARTIGANER, ESTHER OF NEW YORK
summary: KARTIGANER--Esther of New York, NY, 74, died suddenly of a heart attack on August 1, 2012, in Aspen, Colorado. Esther emigrated from Berlin to New York with her family in her first year of life, and attended the Bronx High School of Science and then Brandeis College, majoring in politics. Her strong will, commitment to detail, and passion for current affairs led to a trailblazing journalism career at CBS News for 40 years, 22 of them as Producer and Senior Executive Producer at 60 Minutes, garnering multiple Emmy awards. She was an active supporter of theater and music, enjoyed skiing, tennis, and swimming, and built a strong network of friends and colleagues across the globe. Esther was passionate about enabling the next generation particularly women to learn and succeed, and served on the Brandeis College Women's Studies Board from 1992 to the present (co-chair of the Board from 2010 to 2012); in her honor, the Esther Kartiganer Prize for Excellence in Journalism was established in 2007 by faculty of the Center. After retiring from CBS, Esther served as a mediator in the New York City Civil Courts and as a member of the Institutional Review Board at Columbia University Medical Center. Her dedication to her family, friends, and causes was unwavering, and her enthusiasm and warmth will be missed dearly by all who knew her. She is survived by her brother Joseph Kartiganer (Audrey), nieces Deborah (Constantin Tanno) and Alison Kartiganer, grand-nephew Nicholas Tanno and grand-niece Christina Tanno. Donations in her memory may be made to the Brandeis College Women's Studies Program. A memorial service will be held in the fall.

summary: KARTIGANER--Esther of New York, NY, 74, died suddenly of a heart attack on August 1, 2012, in Aspen, Colorado. Esther emigrated from Berlin to New York with her family in her first year of life, and attended the Bronx High School of Science and then Brandeis College, majoring in politics. Her strong will, commitment to detail, and passion for current affairs led to a trailblazing journalism career at CBS News for 40 years, 22 of them as Producer and Senior Executive Producer at 60 Minutes, garnering multiple Emmy awards. She was an active supporter of theater and music, enjoyed skiing, tennis, and swimming, and built a strong network of friends and colleagues across the globe. Esther was passionate about enabling the next generation - particularly women - to learn and succeed, and served on the Brandeis College Women's Studies Board from 1992 to the present (co-chair of the Board from 2010 to 2012); in her honor, the Esther Kartiganer Prize for Excellence in Journalism was established in 2007 by faculty of the Center. After retiring from CBS, Esther served as a mediator in the New York City Civil Courts and as a member of the Institutional Review Board at Columbia University Medical Center. Her dedication to her family, friends, and causes was unwavering, and her enthusiasm and warmth will be missed dearly by all who knew her. She is survived by her brother Joseph Kartiganer (Audrey), nieces Deborah (Constantin Tanno) and Alison Kartiganer, grand-nephew Nicholas Tanno and grand-niece Christina Tanno. Donations in her memory may be made to the Brandeis College Women's Studies Program. A memorial service will be held in the fall.

headline: CBS Renews 18 Prime-Time Shows
summary: Flaunting the stability that has made it the top-rated network, CBS on Wednesday announced the renewal of 18 of its prime-time shows in one swoop, assuring that most of the network’s lineup will return next season. Virtually all the calls were predictable because they included most of the ongoing hit series now on CBS. But for at least one show whose loyal fans may have been worried about the future, the news was surely a relief: “The Good Wife” will be back for a new season.

headline: Excerpt: 'NYC-22'
summary: The new police drama, beginning on CBS on April 15, follows a group of rookie officers.

headline: CBS Renews ‘CSI’
summary: CBS announced Wednesday that it has renewed the biggest television hit of the past decade, “C.S.I.: Crime Scene Investigation,” for a 14th season. The network said it had extended the contract of the show’s star Ted Danson and secured most of the cast, including Elisabeth Shue, for another season of episodes.

headline: What's On Today
summary: 9 P.M. (13) GÖTTERDÄMMERUNG Wagner's ''Ring'' cycle concludes with this fourth installment, conducted at the Metropolitan Opera by Fabio Luisi and starring Deborah Voigt, above, as Brünnhilde and Jay Hunter Morris as Siegfried, whose love is torn apart by the curse of the ring. Writing in The New York Times, Anthony Tommasini called this five-hour production, presented here by ''Great Performances at the Met,'' ''the most theatrically effective staging of the four works in this epic series, and the clearest representation of the director Robert Lepage's vision.'' Still, he said of the 45-ton mechanical set at the center of the cycle, ''Part of me wanted to see the machine collapse into a heap of smoldering planks at the end of the Immolation Scene, which would have been appropriate.'' 9:15 A.M. (MoreMax) THE ADJUSTMENT BUREAU (2011) Matt Damon, his toothy grin hinting at a young Robert F. Kennedy, portrays David Norris, a Democratic son of Brooklyn and a favorite in the New York race for the United States Senate. That is, until a damaging photo from his past does in his campaign, and he meets Elise (Emily Blunt), a dancer who innocently causes him to veer off the path that a team of mystery men have secretly plotted for him. Their plan does not include Emily, or free will on David's part, for that matter. Now he must decide whether to give in to their machinations -- or reclaim his life. If George Nolfi, who directed this film and wrote the screenplay, based on a short story by Philip K. Dick, ''doesn't go deep in 'The Adjustment Bureau,' a drilling down to where it hurts (he would rather entertain than pain you), he skates on the gray-blue surfaces of his film with confidence,'' Manohla Dargis wrote in The Times.

headline: THE WEEK AHEAD | THEATER
summary: MARY CHASE was wise about the comforting appeal that a divorce from reality offers. Her play ''HARVEY,'' about a man and his tall, invisible rabbit friend, won a Pulitzer Prize in 1944 and ran in its original Broadway production for more than four years. Now Roundabout Theater Company is reviving Chase's comedy in the first Broadway production of the 2012-13 season. When a show opens amid the feverish fuss about Tony Awards for the prior season, as ''Harvey'' is doing, its performances are often forgotten a year later. But the Roundabout has assembled a cast as likely to be memorable as any, led by Jim Parsons, the two-time Emmy Award winner for his portrayal of Sheldon Cooper, the charming nerd of a theoretical physicist on the CBS comedy ''The Big Bang Theory.'' He plays the rabbit-friendly Elwood P. Dowd, a role memorably played by James Stewart in the 1950 film version and the 1970 Broadway revival. Scott Ellis directs a cast that also includes Jessica Hecht, Charles Kimbrough, Larry Bryggman and Carol Kane. Previews begin Friday at Studio 54, 254 West 54th Street, Manhattan, (212) 719-1300, roundabouttheatre.org; $37 to $127.

headline: BET Show Will Offer News and Commentary
summary: Add BET to the list of channels who will be competing in late-night television. Sometime this fall the channel will start ''Don't Sleep With T.J. Holmes,'' a Monday-through-Friday series that will compete with the likes of ''The Daily Show'' on Comedy Central, ''Chelsea Lately'' on E! and ''Conan'' on TBS.

headline: Excerpt: '3'
summary: The new CBS dating show begins on Thursday.

headline: TV Executive Is Rebuked For Comments on Women
summary: 3:46 p.m. | Updated Even in the absence of Charlie Sheen, the CBS sitcom ''Two and a Half Men'' is still finding ways to cause controversy. This time it's Lee Aronsohn, a co-creator and executive producer of that series, who incensed industry colleagues by suggesting that there were too many television comedies focusing on women.

headline: How the Poll Was Conducted
summary: The South Carolina exit poll was based on questionnaires completed by voters on Saturday as they left primary election locations across the state. The poll was conducted by Edison Research of Somerville, N.J., for the National Election Pool, which consists of ABC News, The Associated Press, CBS News, CNN, Fox News, and NBC News.

headline: After Throat Surgery, Adele to Sing at Grammys
summary: Adele will perform at the Grammy Awards on Feb. 12, making her first appearance since undergoing throat surgery last fall, the National Academy of Recording Arts and Sciences announced on Tuesday. ''It's an absolute honor to be included in such a night, and for it to be my first performance in months is very exciting and of course nerve-racking,'' the British singer and songwriter said in a statement.

headline: CBS Apologizes for Benghazi Report
summary: Accounts differ from a man interviewed by “60 Minutes” who said he was at the U.S. mission the night of the attack that killed Ambassador J. Christopher Stevens.

headline: Excerpt: ‘Golden Boy’
summary: Theo James is an upstart detective in this new CBS series.

headline: Upfronts 2013: CBS
summary: The Times's Bill Carter discusses CBS's programming, after the broadcaster unveiled its plans to advertisers.

headline: Paid Notice: Deaths O'BRIEN, G
summary: O'BRIEN--G. Frank, of New York, NY, aged 73, passed away in Goshen, NY, April 25. Survived by brothers Edward Charles O'Brien and Daniel Rea O'Brien, several nieces and nephews. Frank was a retired File Clerk for CBS Law Dept. New York, NY. Funeral mass 10am Wednesday, May 2 at St. John The Evangelist Church, Goshen, NY. Donations to: www.hospiceoforange.com. Services by Smith, Seaman & Quackenbush, Monroe, NY.

headline: Corrections
summary: An article on Monday about television networks' efforts to appeal to Hispanic viewers erroneously attributed a distinction to ''Modern Family'' on ABC. While it is the highest-rated show among 18- to 49-year-olds, it is not the highest-rated show over all. As the article correctly noted elsewhere, that distinction is held by ''NCIS'' on CBS.

headline: What's On Sunday
summary: 10:30 P.M. (HBO) GIRLS Four single women in their 20s navigate disappointing love lives and careers in New York -- and invite comparisons to Carrie, Samantha and the rest of the ''Sex and the City'' gang -- in this new comedy from Lena Dunham (''Tiny Furniture''). The show stars Ms. Dunham, Zosia Mamet and Jemima Kirke (above, from left) and Allison Williams. '' 'Girls' offers romantic failure wrapped in the trappings of failure,'' Alessandra Stanley wrote in The New York Times. She added, ''The depiction of slacker life in New York, which includes tattoos, drugs, casual sex and abortions, is presented with wry humor, but it could easily be interpreted as a cautionary tale written by the religious right: the lifestyles of these modern women, untethered to responsibility, faith or morality, are parables that could scare Amish youth away from Rumspringa and wayward Mormons back into their temple garments.'' 9 A.M. (CNN) STATE OF THE UNION WITH CANDY CROWLEY Bill Cosby speaks about the Trayvon Martin case and civility within the 2012 presidential campaign. Reince Priebus, the chairman of the Republican National Committee, discusses party unity.

headline: Paid Notice: Deaths MCMULLEN, JAY
summary: McMULLEN--Jay. He was a man of purpose, of integrity and achievement. His life was testimony to the conviction that the documentary film should embody the highest standards of journalism and that serious reporting had a place in television. His career was dedicated to upholding the Murrow tradition at CBS News, an era firm in its belief in the separation of news and entertainment, in non-partisan reporting independent of ratings, and in the nobility of its mission. He was a trusted colleague, a cherished friend and an inspiration. We join the McMullen family in mourning his passing and honoring his legacy. Xiaoyan and Irv Drasnin.

headline: What's On Sunday
summary: 10 P.M. (AMC) MAD MEN In last week's Season 5 premiere, Don Draper (Jon Hamm) was the man of the hour at a surprise birthday party engineered by his new wife, Megan (Jessica Paré, above), but he was embarrassed by her sexy performance of the French song ''Zou Bisou Bisou'' in front of his colleagues. In this week's episode, Don and Harry (Rich Sommer) try to make a client happy. Peggy Olson (Elisabeth Moss), fresh off the disappointment of having her Heinz pitch rejected, takes on new duties at the office. 10:30 A.M. (CBS) FACE THE NATION The program broadcasts an interview with Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr. in which he expresses confidence that the Supreme Court will uphold the constitutionality of the health care law. Bob Schieffer speaks with Newt Gingrich and Ron Paul, both Republican presidential candidates, about the 2012 election. Other guests are Jan Crawford and John Dickerson, both of CBS News; Kevin Madden, a campaign adviser for Mitt Romney; and Gwen Ifill of PBS NewsHour.

headline: Plan to Split News Corp. Helps Stock
summary: On Wall Street, it's called the ''Murdoch discount.'' That's the view that the shares of News Corporation trade lower than the intrinsic value of its many media assets because of the control exerted by Rupert Murdoch. Because of his hold, the argument goes, the company takes on expensive ventures like the $5 billion purchase of Dow Jones in 2007, an acquisition whose value was heavily written down soon after closing.

headline: Super Bowl Ads Recall Days Gone By
summary: The ads CBS broadcast nationally represented a missed opportunity for marketers to show that they understood how modern consumers think and behave.

headline: 'American Idol' Premiere Suffers Drop in in Viewers
summary: 5:16 p.m. | Updated Is this the year that television's powerhouse will start to lose its mojo? Fox's ''American Idol'' took a tumble in the ratings for the premiere of its new season on Wednesday, down more than 25 percent from last year. The falloff was apparent in both the total number of viewers and in the audience that ad buyers most care about - viewers between the ages of 18 and 49.

headline: Phil Ramone, 79, Producer Who Helped Music’s Stars Shine
summary: Phil Ramone, a prolific record producer and engineer who worked with some of the biggest music stars of the last 50 years, including Ray Charles, Frank Sinatra, Paul Simon, Billy Joel and Barbra Streisand, died on Saturday in Manhattan. He was 79. Though it was widely reported that he was 72, public records and his family confirm that he was born Jan. 5, 1934. His death was confirmed by his son Matthew. He did not immediately give the cause, but Mr. Ramone was reported to have been admitted to a Manhattan hospital in late February for treatment of an aortic aneurysm.

headline: On TV, Romney Doesn't Show Immigration Hand
summary: Responding to the challenge that President Obama posed in his order last week to stop deporting some illegal immigrants, Mitt Romney declined to say on Sunday whether he would reverse the president's decision if he takes up occupancy of the White House. Although Mr. Romney said during the Republican primary debates that he would veto the Dream Act, which would provide a path to citizenship for some illegal immigrants, he was more equivocal about Mr. Obama's order last week. It allows work permits and prevents deportation for as many as 1.4 million undocumented immigrants under the age of 30 who were brought to the United States as children.

headline: Corrections
summary: An entry in the What’s on Today television highlights in some editions on Saturday, about “Mayweather” on CBS, a documentary about the boxer Floyd Mayweather Jr., misstated the date of his fight with Robert Guerrero, which will be broadcast on Showtime pay-per-view. It is scheduled for this coming Saturday, not May 8.

headline: Grammy Awards Show Hits a Ratings High Note
summary: The Grammy Awards telecast on CBS smashed every recent ratings record Sunday night, not just for the music awards show but for any awards broadcast, fueled by keen interest in how the show would pay tribute to Whitney Houston, who had died the day before. For its full duration - the show ended out of prime time at 11:33 p.m. in the East - the Grammys attracted 39.9 million viewers, making it the most-watched nonsports program of the television season.

headline: 'Idol' Continues to Lose Viewers
summary: The question of where ''American Idol'' will finally settle in the ratings this season was not answered Wednesday, as television's one-time powerhouse continued to lose viewers. Even worse, the percentage of viewers it lost, compared with the same night last year, was the biggest so far this season. In the ratings that most matter to Fox - viewers between the ages of 18 and 49 - ''Idol'' was down 34 percent from the Wednesday one-hour edition last year. That eclipsed the 25 percent loss it has been averaging for the previous episodes this season.

headline: Ratings Decline Across the Board
summary: In what turned out to be a very rough night for the broadcast networks, almost all of Thursday's programming fell sharply no matter what category or time period is used for comparison. According to Nielsen, Fox's ''American Idol'' had another drop in total viewers, to 13.8 million this week from 15.9 million last week, and in the 18-to-49-year-old demographic its new drama ''Touch'' fell to 7.5 million total viewers from 8.9 million. On CBS ''The Big Bang Theory'' hit a season low in the 18-to-49 category, and ''Person of Interest'' tumbled to its lowest viewership since February, at 13.5 million. ''Grey's Anatomy'' on ABC and ''Community'' and ''30 Rock'' on NBC dropped to season lows in adults 18-to-49 as well.

headline: What's On Sunday
summary: 9 P.M. (AMC) MAD MEN At the close of the fourth season, Don Draper (Jon Hamm, above with Elisabeth Moss) made a surprise proposal to his secretary, Megan (Jessica Paré), and the advertising agency Sterling Cooper Draper Price was reeling from the loss of its biggest account. After a 17-month break, this award-winning series from Matthew Weiner returns with a two-hour premiere. 9 A.M. (CNN) STATE OF THE UNION WITH CANDY CROWLEY David Plouffe, a senior adviser to President Obama, discusses the budget and the 2012 election campaign. Gov. Rick Scott of Florida talks about the Trayvon Martin case, and Senator Lindsey Graham, Republican of South Carolina, answers questions about Afghanistan.

headline: Paid Notice: Deaths BATES, CHARLES T.
summary: BATES--Charles Turner, age 82, of Irvington, NY and Clinton, CT, died of natural causes on August 1, 2014. Charlie was born in Tarrytown, NY to Harry Cole and Helen Turner Bates. Charlie attended Hackley School in Tarrytown and graduated from Hamilton College in 1953. After college he served two years in the United States Army's Ordnance Corps, serving as a translator in France. He graduated from Yale Law School in 1958, and began his legal career at Townley & Updike in New York. Charlie joined the law department at CBS in 1969, rising to the level of Secretary of CBS. Upon retiring in 1988, Charlie embarked on a second career, teaching high school level U.S. History at his alma mater, Hackley. With his second retirement in 1999, he stayed active with travel to all parts of the globe, and volunteering at the Irvington Historical Society and The Church of St. Barnabas, where Charlie, a lifelong member, sang in the choir from childhood until this year. He is survived by his brother, Robert P. Turner of Weston, CT, and eight nieces and nephews, who will miss his wide ranging knowledge and wit, including his clever predictions of next season's events on Downton Abbey. He was predeceased by his brothers David and Harry Bates, also Hackley and Hamilton alumni. A memorial service will be held at St. Barnabas, 15 N Broadway, Irvington, on Friday, August 15 at 11am. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made in his memory to Hackley School or The Church of St. Barnabas, Irvington, NY.

headline: Niagara Tightrope Walk Is ABC Ratings Bonanza
summary: The live telecast of a tightrope walk over Niagara Falls on Friday night did exactly what ABC hoped: it lifted the network to a first-place finish for the night and provided evidence that there's an audience out there hungry for big television stunts. ABC easily surpassed NBC, CBS and the other broadcasters for the night. From 10:30 to 11 p.m., when the daredevil Nik Wallenda finished his walk, ABC netted 13.1 million viewers, according to preliminary Nielsen ratings.

headline: Mitt Romney on 'Face the Nation'
summary: Mitt Romney spoke on President Obama's most recent changes to immigration policy in an interview with Bob Schieffer.

headline: Excerpt: 'The Job'
summary: Five contestants face a potential employer in the CBS reality show competition.

headline: Tony Wins Lift Box Office
summary: The fallout from this month's Tony Awards at the Broadway box office - good and bad - came into sharper relief last week, with the musicals ''Once,'' ''Newsies,'' and ''The Gershwins' Porgy and Bess'' and the plays ''One Man, Two Guvnors'' and ''Gore Vidal's The Best Man'' in the strongest shape among new productions as the summer tourist season begins, according to the weekly ticket sales data compiled by the Broadway League. Moving swiftly after winning the best musical Tony and seven others on June 10, ''Once'' raised ticket prices for swaths of seats last week and also increased its top price for so-called premium tickets to $275 (from $225 a week earlier). The show grossed $955,362 last week, an increase of 13 percent and its largest haul since performances began in February.

summary: $30/SQUARE FOOT $63,120 approximate annual rent

headline: Paid Notice: Deaths SCHEIMER, LOUIS
summary: SCHEIMER--Louis "Lou" (October 19, 1928 - October 17, 2013) Los Angeles, CA - Louis Scheimer, the renowned and much loved animation pioneer has died at his home at age 84, just two days shy of his 85th birthday, from Parkinson's Disease. Lou is survived by his beloved daughter Erika Scheimer and his son Lane Scheimer. At his side over these final days were Erika, who worked with her father for decades at Filmation, the company founded by Lou, Norm Prescott, and Hal Sutherland in the early sixties. Also on hand throughout Lou's final days were his devoted daughter-in-law, Amy Rosenberg, and sundry close friends, former employees and relations. Lou's wife Jay Scheimer, had passed in 2009. Lou often said that Jay was truly the woman behind the man, and she was greatly instrumental in making Filmation a reality. He often said that he could never have survived the early years without Jay's support. They were a most colorful couple; back in the day, some referred to them as the "George and Gracie" of the animation crowd. Lou graduated from Carnegie-Tech in 1952, married in 1953 and moved to Los Angeles in 1955 to work in the animation industry. In 1962, Filmation Studios was created and became one of the world's premiere animation houses. During this early period, the studio produced TV commercials and documentaries. In 1965, the studio unveiled its first Saturday morning series, "Superman", a solid hit which ran for three years on CBS. Soon to follow were a string of shows, including the arrival of "Aquaman", "Batman" and the phenomenally rated "Archies" show. Lou was widely credited with starting Saturday morning cartoons. From the "Archies" cartoons came the number one hit song "Sugar, Sugar", which has been re-recorded through the years some 29 times and counting! It was also the number two song of the 1960's, second only to the Beatles' "I Want to Hold Your Hand". A number one song from a cartoon? This was the first animated show to include original songs with each episode. This was one of many "firsts" achieved throughout the life of Filmation. The praise from critics and viewers alike was even more enthusiastic for Filmation's proudest animation achievement, "Fat Albert and the Cosby Kids". In its twelve year run, "Fat Albert" was acclaimed by parents, educators and children everywhere. It received countless honors, including a number of Emmy nominations and the prestigious Peabody Award. It was the show that Lou was most proud of. From then on, he made it his life's mission to produce children's shows that not only were entertaining, but also contained pro-social values and messages. After "Fat Albert" aired in the early seventies, Filmation had truly come into its own as a giant in the field of animation. Shows broadcast on CBS, NBC and ABC in that time period include "Groovie Ghoulies", "The Brady Kids", "Mission Magic", "Jerry Lewis", the "Fabulous Funnies", "Mighty Mouse and Heckle and Jeckle", "Tom and Jerry", "Space Sentinels", "Lassie", and "Gilligans Island". Subsequently, Lou ventured into live-action shows with such hits as "Shazam-Isis Hour", the original "Ghostbusters", "Ark II", "Space Academy" and "Jason of Star Command". In addition, Filmation made a triumphant foray into theatrical feature production with "Journey Back to Oz" in 1973. That year also marked the first of many prime time specials, including "Oliver Twist", "Treasure Island", "Fat Albert" and "A Snow White Christmas". In 1981, Filmation unveiled "Blackstarr", a sword and sorcery fantasy that rocketed to the top of the Saturday morning ratings. This was not surprising considering Filmation's acknowledged leadership in producing quality animated adventure shows. Beginning with "Fantastic Voyage" and "Journey to the Center of the Earth" in 1967, the studio went on to produce the now classic, Emmy award winning animated "Star Trek" series, as well as animated versions of "Tarzan", "Zorro", "The Lone Ranger" and "Flash Gordon." In 1983, Lou created the marketplace for first-run syndication of animated shows. Filmation took on its most ambitious project to date: the "He-Man and the Masters of the Universe" series. Over the years Filmation produced 130 "He-Man" episodes directly for syndication. Once again, Lou made positive messages a hallmark of the show. The results: another winner, both in domestic ratings and in unprecedented international sales in thirty countries in the first year alone. Two years later, in 1985, Filmation brought He-Man's twin sister "She-Ra, Princess of Power" to the syndicated world. Lou always felt that little girls were underserved in the world of super heroes. He made it a cause to change that with She-Ra. It too was a huge success at home and abroad. After Filmation closed, the now legendary Lou Scheimer had grown to be one of the most loved men in the animation industry. He became known for trying to keep animation in the US, and he fought hard to do so. Additionally, it was of great importance to him that Filmation train the next generation of animators in America. Many of Lou's former employees can, to this day, be found working at Disney, DreamWorks, Pixar and more. Indeed, many will tell you that it was Lou who gave them their start in the business. Lou's legacy of shows saw a whole new life in recent years, as DVD collections of his many shows began to proliferate in the 1990's. The fact that a new generation of kids would be able to watch his Filmation shows gave Lou endless joy. Hundreds of fan mail letters and emails just keep on coming. Google the guy and read all about it. It is a great American rags-to-riches story you will much enjoy. In lieu of flowers, Lou and his family kindly request that donations to Parkinson's research be made in his honor.

headline: Paid Notice: Deaths JENCKS, RICHARD W.
summary: JENCKS--Richard W., retired CBS Broadcast Group President, dies at 93. See news story at MarinIJ.com.

headline: Paid Notice: Deaths MCMULLEN, JAY
summary: McMULLEN--Jay. He was a man of purpose, of integrity and achievement. His life was testimony to the conviction that the documentary film should embody the highest standards of journalism and that serious reporting had a place in television. His career was dedicated to upholding the Murrow tradition at CBS News, an era firm in its belief in the separation of news and entertainment, in non-partisan reporting independent of ratings, and in the nobility of its mission. He was a trusted colleague, a cherished friend and an inspiration. We join the McMullen family in mourning his passing and honoring his legacy. Xiaoyan and Irv Drasnin.

headline: Aldean and Minaj at the Grammys
summary: The country music star Jason Aldean and the rapper Nicki Minaj will be among the first-time performers during the Grammy Awards ceremony on Feb. 12, the National Academy of Recording Arts and Sciences announced on Thursday. Mr. Aldean and Ms. Minaj are nominated for several awards. They will be joined by Kelly Clarkson, Foo Fighters, Bruno Mars and Taylor Swift. There was no word in Thursday's announcement about whether Adele would perform during the ceremony, to be held at the Staples Center in Los Angeles and broadcast on CBS. She had the best selling album last year with ''21'' (XL/Columbia) and is nominated for six awards, including record, album and song of the year. But she underwent throat surgery last fall to stop bleeding in her vocal cords and her participation remains up in the air.

headline: Major Networks Shut Out of Best Drama Category in Emmy Nominations
summary: The winner of the Emmy Award for outstanding drama won't be announced until September. But the category's losers were all identified on Thursday: the big broadcast networks that televise the awards. The networks were completely shut out of the main drama series category for the first time, reflecting the gradual drift of top writers, producers and actors to cable.

headline: U.S. Catholics Welcome a Papal Change
summary: In a New York Times/CBS poll, the majority of Catholics said Pope Benedict XVI made the right decision to step down and hope for a more liberally focused leadership.

headline: Political Ad Database Will Move To the Web
summary: The Federal Communications Commission on Friday approved a proposal to have local broadcasters publish information about political advertising sales on the Web in a government database. Supporters of the proposal said it would give the public more information about the millions of dollars that are spent on ads to influence elections. It had been expected to pass despite deep opposition by the owners of some television and radio stations.

headline: Spare Times
summary: Around Town Museums and Sites

headline: How the Poll Was Conducted
summary: The exit polls were based on questionnaires completed by voters on Tuesday as they left primary election locations in Georgia, Massachusetts, Ohio and Tennessee. The polls were conducted by Edison Research of Somerville, N.J., for the National Election Pool, which consists of ABC News, The Associated Press, CBS News, CNN, Fox News and NBC News.

headline: Historical Society Plans World War II Exhibition
summary: Helping to fill the seemingly endless appetite for information about World War II, the New-York Historical Society is planning a major exhibition on the conflict's effect on the homefront this fall.Titled "WWII & NYC," the exhibition is scheduled to open Oct. 5 and run through May 27. Among the documents scheduled for display is a rare copy of the original Instrument of Surrender , Japan's formal surrender to the Allies on Sept. 2, 1945, that will be exhibited starting on Sept. 21, before the rest of the exhibition opens. The document, one of 20 copies of the surrender agreement created at the time, has not been displayed in New York since 1945.

headline: The New York Times Newsroom Navigator
summary: For more than 10 years, the Newsroom Navigator has been used by New York Times reporters and editors as the starting point for their forays onto the Web.

headline: LL Cool J to Go Solo With the Grammys
summary: LL Cool J will host the Grammy Awards next month, marking the first time in seven years that the show's producers have decided to go with a single master of ceremonies, the National Academy of Recording Arts and Sciences announced on Wednesday. Since 2008, the rapper and actor has been the host for the televised nominations concert the Grammys produces in the fall. This is the first time, however, he will be asked to keep the main ceremony moving along. The awards will be announced on Feb. 12 at the Staples Center in Los Angeles. CBS will broadcast the show, which will feature performances by Nicki Minaj, Foo Fighters, Taylor Swift, Kelly Clarkson, Jason Aldean and Bruno Mars. The last time the awards program had a single host was in 2005, when Queen Latifah, another rapper turned actress, played that role. In the past, the producers have relied on comedians as hosts, among them Jon Stewart, Billy Crystal, Ellen DeGeneres and Rosie O'Donnell.

headline: Check Point: Santorum on Financing for Family Planning Programs
summary: Times reporters take a closer look at some of the statements made by the Republican presidential candidates in Wednesday night's debate. Romney and the Auto Bailout

headline: What's On Sunday
summary: 8 P.M. (Fox) THE SIMPSONS Bart persuades his family to go on a cruise, above, and even wrangles a luxury suite. Now if he can only figure out how to make the vacation last longer than a week. Treat Williams and Steve Coogan guest star. The soundtrack features an original song by Robert Lopez, a creator of ''The Book of Mormon.'' 9 A.M. (CNN) STATE OF THE UNION WITH CANDY CROWLEY John O. Brennan, the chief counterterrorism adviser to President Obama, discusses the war on terror a year after the killing of Osama bin Laden. Mr. Brennan moves over to ''Fox News Sunday,'' at 10, and ''This Week With George Stephanopoulos,'' also at 10, on ABC.

headline: TimesCast | February 14, 2012
summary: Explosions in Bangkok | Santorum ties Romney in latest New York Times/CBS News poll | Underage models at New York Fashion Week.

headline: Paid Notice: Deaths LEVITAN, GEORGE
summary: LEVITAN--George, on May 20, 2012. George was the core and spark of his wife's existence. He was so proud of his career at the United Nations and CBS and never forgot his most remarkable experiences. He shared them all with all of us, as he did his love for Frank Sinatra and French Silk Ice Cream. He will always be remembered by his many nieces, nephews, great-nieces and nephews and great-great-nieces and nephews. He will be sorely missed. He had such pride for his deceased brother Paul and sister Belle. His adoring wife, Sydelle. Family and friends may gather today 11:15am at Gutterman's, 8000 Jericho Tpke, Woodbury, LI. A graveside service to follow 12:30pm at Mount Ararat Cemetery, Farmingdale, NY.

headline: G.M. Won't Advertise In 2013 Super Bowl
summary: 5:59 p.m. | Updated For the second time in a week, General Motors is making news for advertising it will not be running rather than for advertising it is running. G.M. said it would not buy commercial time during Super Bowl XLVII, to be broadcast by CBS on Feb. 3, 2013. The company is not pulling out of the game, because it had not already agreed to buy any spots; rather, it has decided against a buy.

headline: Rosemary Rice, 87, Daughter On Early TV's 'Mama' Series
summary: Rosemary Rice, an actress who found fame in the early days of television playing the perky oldest daughter, Katrin, on '' Mama ,'' a beloved family show broadcast live on CBS for many years, died on Aug. 14 at her home in Stamford, Conn. She was 87. The cause was a heart attack, her son, John Merrell, said.

headline: A History of New York in 50 Objects
summary: Prehistory 1. MASTODON TUSK, ABOUT 11,000 B.C.

headline: A History of New York in 50 Objects
summary: Prehistory 1. MASTODON TUSK, ABOUT 11,000 B.C.

headline: What's On Sunday
summary: 8 P.M. (TCM) WHAT'S ON TONIGHT: EXOTIC PETS This Virginia McKenna-Bill Travers double bill begins with ''Born Free'' (1966), James Hill's drama, based on the 1960 autobiographic best seller by Joy Adamson, in which the married actors, above, play a game warden in Kenya and his wife who face a heartrending decision after Elsa, the orphaned lion club they have raised, becomes too big to keep. The composer John Barry won the Oscar for best original score and, with Don Black, for best original song for ''Born Free.'' Vincent Canby, writing in The New York Times, called the film ''a poignant but happy reminder of the beauty and mystery of the life cycle.'' In ''Ring of Bright Water'' (1969), at 10, Mr. Travers portrays a London civil service clerk whose life is changed when he decides to move Mij, his rambunctious pet-shop otter, to a village along the west Scottish coast. Ms. McKenna plays the doctor who, with her spaniel, captures the pair's attention. 9 A.M. (CNN) STATE OF THE UNION WITH CANDY CROWLEY Rick Santorum discusses his campaign for the Republican nomination. Mr. Santorum also appears on ''This Week With George Stephanopoulos,'' at 10 on ABC.

headline: Americans Divided Over Tax Policy
summary: It may come as no surprise, but Americans are deeply split along party lines when it comes to federal tax policy. A New York Times/CBS News poll released Tuesday found that a majority of Republicans approve of the current tax policy, while most Democrats and independents disapprove of taxing income from capital gains at a lower rate than earned income.

headline: Moonves on I.P.O. for CBS Outdoor
summary: Leslie Moonves, chief of CBS, and Jeremy Male, chief of CBS Outdoor, discuss why the ad business has been an awkward fit in CBS and the prospect of being a real estate investment trust.

headline: The War Logs
summary: An archive of classified military documents offers an unvarnished view of the wars in Afghanistan and Iraq.

headline: What's On Sunday
summary: 9 P.M. (HBO) BOARDWALK EMPIRE Steve Buscemi reprises his Emmy-nominated role as Nucky Thompson, the Atlantic City kingpin, in this Season 3 opener, which finds him making a resolution as he rings in 1923 that leaves his latest foe, Gyp Rosetti (Bobby Cannavale), rather unhappy. Nucky's wife, Margaret (Kelly Macdonald, above, with Mr. Buscemi), tries to build on the Thompson endowment at St. Theresa's Hospital, to the displeasure of her husband. And Al Capone (Stephen Graham) grows irritated by the Irish mobster Dean O'Banion (Arron Shiver). In addition to Mr. Buscemi's, the series received 11 Emmy nominations for Season 2. 10 A.M. (Fox) FOX NEWS SUNDAY Susan E. Rice, the United States ambassador to the United Nations, discusses the recent attacks on American embassies in Libya and Egypt, the Obama administration's handling of the crisis and relations between the United States and the Middle East going forward.

headline: TimesCast | Santorum Catches Up
summary: February 14, 2012 - Rick Santorum catches up to Mitt Romney among Republican primary voters in the lastest New York Times/CBS News poll.

headline: Paid Notice: Deaths LARSON, RUTH M.
summary: LARSON--Ruth Marie. Passed away on August 23, 2012, at 76 years of age, at home in Berkeley, CA, USA with her husband and family and caregivers, after a long and difficult illness with Parkinson's Disease, and having received the Sacrament of Anointing of the Sick by Fr. Bruno Gibson, OP. Surviving are her husband Ronald, and her children Christopher, Peter and Hans, her brother Harris Steiner, her daughters-in-law: Mary, Jennifer, and Anessa, her beloved grandchildren Katharine, Eric and Soren, Alexandra Ruth (in utero), and her nieces Laura Durbahn of Kerman, CA, Cynthia Ganz of Seattle, Elise Winter of Loomis, CA., nephew Carl Steiner of San Diego, and grandnieces and grandnephews. Ruth will be greatly missed by her dear friends: sorority sister and fellow teacher Celia Gunn Ginnado of Arlington Heights, Ill., Sra. Imelda Espiritu of Berkeley, and Christina Ahengua of Richmond. And also her classmates and friends from The Sigma Kappa sorority at UC Berkeley, and her classmates from Kerman HS., the parishioners and teachers at School of the Madeleine, and at St. Mary's College HS. A proud native of California, she was born at St. Agnes Hospital in Fresno. She graduated from Kerman HS with honors, Cheerleader, Girls Athletic Association and Tennis Team letters, International Quill and Scroll Society for Journalism, and a California Scholarship Federation (CSF) Member. The daughter of Thelma Harris Steiner, a California school teacher, and Rene Steiner, a Kerman raisin grower and RFD mailman. Ruth was a member of the The Order of Rainbow for Girls, and a California Raisin Queen. She was a 5-year 4H Achievement Award winner. Following her brother Harris's example, Ruth matriculated at UC Berkeley in 1953 and joined the Sigma Kappa sorority. Walking to class one day in her first year, she met her husband-to-be, and they began an odyssey for life. Ruth as: teacher, then through the active years of raising her boys, as an interior designer and her designs include offices and living areas for the Christian Brothers-De La Salle Institute Winery (her leaded glass door panels bearing the CB seal are still in use at the Sutter Home Winery in St. Helena, CA.) For nearly six years she was national sale representative for her partnership in the Abundance Winery in Sonoma. In the latter role she was thrilled to encounter a former member of her son's class at the Madeleine - he was a competitor salesman at a dealer in Chicago. He afterward joked of losing that sale, as it was unfair to have to compete against "a Mom with all that charm." â€¨Meantime, she completed her studies at UC, graduating BA as an UC Alumni Scholar in the same ceremony with Ron gaining his JD. Now all of the Larsons were Cal Bears. Ruth was active in the School of the Madeleine at their family parish: re-founding the Bridge Club, leading the Cub's Scouts, and singing in Father Larry's choir. The boys went on to the St. Mary's College High School where she helped the Brothers of the Christian Schools, Eunice Jackson and other mothers, found the Belles of St. Mary's as a scholarship organization for the school. She didn't know "slow." She spent her days and nights teaching, counseling, feeding and loving her family, gardening, playing the piano at midnite home sessions, dancing at the Parish parties, traveling with Ron, skiing with the boys, and as a member of the Art Deco Society of San Francisco. Always a lady: raised by her Convent trained mother, she was initiated in 1953, by her new friend on Milvia Street, Pat Sager, to wear gloves and scarf and hat and take lunch at the City of Paris. A propriety she must have been one of the last to relinquish. But she wore her scarves and gloves until the day she died. All Services will be at the St. Mary Magdalen Catholic Church 2005 Berryman St, Berkeley, California 94709 (510-526-4811) as follows: Thursday, September 6th at 7PM - The Holy Rosary of the Virgin Mary; Friday, September 7th at 10:30AM - Mass - followed immediately by reception and refreshments in Norton Hall (directly under the Church - entry from the parking lot). Private interment services are pending. â€¨SUNSET VIEW MORTUARY â€¨Telephone (510) 525-5111 â€¨

headline: Paid Notice: Deaths RACIES, LAWRENCE
summary: RACIES--Lawrence. November 23, 1916 - April 12, 2013. Beloved husband of Gail Williams. Father of Robin Hammond, Lawrence, and Phillip Racies, grandfather of nine, uncle to three nieces and a nephew. Left the University of New Hampshire to go on the road with comedian Red Skelton. A veteran of WWII, a CBS News cameraman, and an inveterate teller of jokes. He was a longtime fighter for a universal healthcare system in the USA. A celebration of his life will be held at St. Paul's Church, 315 West 22nd Street, on May 9th at 3pm.

headline: The TV Watch: Larry King Returns To Talk, But Online
summary: Larry King has told viewers that he wants to be frozen after his death. And that's fitting because the talk show host's new Web endeavor on Hulu, ''Larry King Now,'' is almost exactly that - his persona is cryopreserved on the Internet, in suspenders, if not suspension, in fine fettle and ready for television resuscitation sometime in the future. ''Larry King Now,'' which Mr. King created in partnership with a new digital video network, Ora TV, is an example of how the Internet accommodates old age as easily as youth. Justin Bieber and Lena Dunham got their D.I.Y. start on the Internet. Older stars who have retired from television but still have an itch to be on camera can keep their careers going online. It's probably an even better alternative than cable, because most people don't surf their remotes as far as AXS TV, the cable network formerly known as HDNet, where Dan Rather went after he left CBS News.

headline: What's On Sunday
summary: 9 P.M. (13, 49) WALLANDER III: AN EVENT IN AUTUMN Kenneth Branagh, above, returns as Inspector Kurt Wallander, Henning Mankell's scruffy Swedish sleuth, in a new season of this ''Masterpiece Mystery!'' production. In this first of three episodes, a pregnant woman appears to have leapt to her death from a ferry. Or was she pushed? The case seems to have little effect on Wallander's new life with Vanja (Saskia Reeves). But then the couple discover the corpse of a woman who was murdered a decade ago on their property. And as the two investigations become entangled, a calamity strikes one of Wallander's colleagues, leading him to blame himself. Turns out he has a good reason to do so. 10 A.M. (ABC) THIS WEEK George Stephanopoulos interviews Representative Paul D. Ryan of Wisconsin, the Republican vice presidential nominee.

headline: What's On Today
summary: 8 P.M. (CBS) TEACHERS ROCK PRESENTED BY WALMART AND 'WON'T BACK DOWN' -- A CONCERT AND CHARITY EVENT BENEFITING TEACHERS AND EDUCATION Garth Brooks, Carrie Underwood, Josh Groban (above) and others perform in honor of American educators at this event taped on Tuesday at the Nokia Theater in Los Angeles. A number of stars -- including Dave Grohl of the Foo Fighters, Usher, Adam Levine and James Valentine of Maroon 5, Meryl Streep, L L Cool J, Jack Black and Morgan Freeman -- talk about teachers who influenced their lives. The program also features clips from the forthcoming movie ''Won't Back Down,'' starring Viola Davis and Maggie Gyllenhaal, about two mothers determined to transform a failing urban school.8 P.M. (HGTV) HGTV GREEN HOME 2012 GIVEAWAY Monica Pedersen randomly draws the winner of an environmentally friendly, 2,300-square-foot farmhouse in the Atlanta area with three bedrooms, two-and-a-half baths and an open floor plan in a 900-acre community connected by walking paths.

headline: Paid Notice: Deaths O'BRIEN, G. FRANK
summary: O'BRIEN--G. Frank, of New York, NY, aged 73, passed away in Goshen, NY, April 25. Survived by brothers Edward Charles O'Brien and Daniel Rea O'Brien, several nieces and nephews. Frank was a retired File Clerk for CBS Law Dept. New York, NY. Funeral mass 10am Wednesday, May 2 at St. John The Evangelist Church, Goshen, NY. Donations to: www.hospiceoforange.com. Services by Smith, Seaman & Quackenbush, Monroe, NY.

headline: What's On Sunday
summary: 8 P.M. (13, 49) ROYAL MEMORIES: PRINCE CHARLES' TRIBUTE TO THE QUEEN The prince recounts events from the public and private lives of his mother, Queen Elizabeth II, punctuating his memories with photographs and videos from the queen's private collection, many of which she shot herself. Highlights include footage taken at Buckingham Palace on Coronation Day, above, as the queen juggled her official role with that of a mother; scenes from family holidays, like a sequence of the young prince and his sister, Princess Anne, playing on a beach in Norfolk; and time spent on the royal yacht Britannia and at Windsor and Balmoral Castles during the 1940s and '50s. 10 A.M. (ABC) THIS WEEK David Plouffe, a White House senior adviser, speaks with George Stephanopoulos about the presidential race, the coming Democratic National Convention in Charlotte, N.C., and how President Obama can convince voters that he deserves a second term.

headline: 'Today' Show Streak at Top Is Halted by 'GMA'
summary: Update, 1:55 p.m.| ABC's ''Good Morning America'' appears to have prevailed over NBC's ''Today'' show in weekly viewership for the first time in over 16 years. Preliminary Nielsen ratings show that ''GMA'' had an average of 5,147,000 total viewers for the week of April 9 -- 13,000 more than the ''Today'' show, which averaged 5,134,000.

headline: Paid Notice: Deaths SILVER, BEN
summary: SILVER--Ben Peabody. Award-winning CBS television news reporter and journalism professor, father to six and grandfather to eleven, died from complications of Parkinson's Disease May 2 at his home in St. Louis Park, MN. He was 85.

headline: Vice President Biden on CBS
summary: In an interview, Vice President Joe Biden offers a variety of critiques of Mr. Romney.

headline: 'The Lorax' Rules the Box Office Again
summary: A fuzzy orange cartoon character humiliated Eddie Murphy and one of Pixar's top directors at the weekend movie box office. For the second weekend in a row, ''Dr. Seuss' The Lorax'' (Universal Pictures) -- featuring that fuzzy character and the voice of Danny DeVito -- was North America's No. 1 movie. It took in an estimated $39.1 million for a new total of about $122 million, according to Hollywood.com, which compiles box office data. Finishing a distant second with about $30.6 million in ticket sales was Disney's ''John Carter,'' a space epic directed by Andrew Stanton of ''Finding Nemo'' and ''Wall-E'' fame for Pixar. Analysts say Disney faces a $100 million to $165 million loss because of the film's poor opening-weekend results. Disney noted that ''John Carter'' took in an additional $70.6 million overseas and said the film received a B-plus score from audiences in exit polls. ''Project X'' (Warner Brothers) was third, taking in about $11.6 million for a two-week total of $40.1 million. ''Silent House,'' an inexpensive horror movie from Open Road Films, placed fourth, with about $7.01 million, while ''Act of Valor'' (Relativity Media) was fifth, taking in $7 million for a three-week total of $56.1 million.

headline: NBC Renews 'Smash' ...
summary: Undoubtedly with some sense of relief and satisfaction, NBC announced Thursday it would bring back ''Smash'' for a second season. The Broadway-based drama, on which the network lavished attention and promotion, has performed reasonably well in its 10 p.m. Monday slot - and far better than anything NBC has tried in that time period in many years. It is by far the top-rated drama now on NBC.

headline: Paid Notice: Deaths FLOOD, JAMES, J.
summary: FLOOD--James, J.,55, of Manhattan, NY, died Friday, August 9, 2013. Predeceased by his parents, Jim was the devoted only child of James J. and Doris (nee Baker) Flood. Survivors include his maternal aunt, Audrey (Peter) Hickey (nee Baker), his paternal aunt, Sally (the late Robert) Flood and cousins Johanna Kagel, Tara, Catherine and (the late Denise) Hickey, Robert, Stephen, Thomas and John Flood. Jim was a 1979 magna cum laude graduate of Fordham University and earned his MBA from Manhattan College in 1985. He began his career at the CBS Broadcast Group, answering viewer questions about news programming, leaving for the opportunity to work at the New York City Mayor's Office of Operations. He became a manager for the New York City Department of Homeless Services, which led to a position as the Director of Human Resources for Common Ground in 2000, a nonprofit social services organization in New York City whose goal is to create high-quality permanent and transitional housing for the homeless. Jim was born and raised in the Bronx, was devoted to his faith, and was a member of the Church of St. Raymond and St. John the Evangelist. Jim was a Manhattan resident for over 30 years. The wake will be at Frank E. Campbell The Funeral Chapel at 1076 Madison Ave., Manhattan, NY on Friday August 16th from 2pm-4pm and 7pm-9pm. Mass of Christian burial 10am on Saturday August 17th at St. John the Evangelist, 348 East 55th St., Manhattan, NY. Interment at St. Raymond's Cemetery following the mass, 2600 Lafayette Avenue, Bronx, NY. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to the American Cancer Society.

headline: Paid Notice: Deaths COLMAN, HENRY
summary: COLMAN--Henry. He was best known as the Producer of the Love Boat and Hotel television series, died on November 7, 2012 at the age of 89. His long career began in live television on Robert Montgomery Presents and Kraft Television Theater. It followed with stints as Associate Producer on Dr. Kildare and Peyton Place. He held executive positions with CBS, Paramount and Screen Gems. He produced many movies for television. He was a longtime member of the Writers Guild of America and wrote episodes for the Love Boat. In recent years, he interviewed many industry notables for the archives of the Television Academy. He served in the Army Air Corps as a navigator on a B-29 in WWII. He earned his BA from Columbia and acted with the Virginia Barter Theater Company. He is surived by his wife Donna Brainard; children Cathy and Richard; and his sister, Hedy Roche. No services were held. Contributions to a charity of your choice can be made in his memory.

headline: Preview: 'Inside Llewyn Davis'
summary: Oscar Isaac and Adam Driver in a clip from the Coen brothers’ new movie.

headline: What's On Today
summary: 9 P.M. (13, 49) PAUL McCARTNEY'S LIVE KISSES On Feb. 9 -- the 48th anniversary of the Beatles' famous appearance on ''The Ed Sullivan Show'' -- and just hours after being awarded a star on the Hollywood Walk of Fame, Paul McCartney (above) performed works from his latest album, ''Kisses on the Bottom,'' at Capitol Studios, where it was recorded. He was joined by collaborators on the recording including the jazz pianist and singer Diana Krall and the guitarist Joe Walsh. Others, like Eric Clapton and Stevie Wonder, discussed the album's creation. The playlist in this ''Great Performances'' presentation features ''Home,'' ''More I Cannot Wish You,'' ''Always,'' ''Bye Bye Blackbird'' and a flubbed first take on ''My Very Good Friend the Milkman.'' 10:30 A.M. (CUNY) INVITATION TO WORLD LITERATURE David Damrosch, a professor of comparative literature at Harvard, introduces ''My Name Is Red,'' Orhan Pamuk's 1998 murder mystery set in Istanbul during the 16th century and told from 12 viewpoints. Among those interviewed are Mr. Pamuk, who in 2006 was awarded the Nobel Prize in Literature; Erdag M. Goknar, the book's translator; Walter Andrews, a professor of Ottoman literature at the University of Washington; and Mr. Pamuk's high school basketball coach. (Repeated at 3:30 and 8:30 p.m.)

headline: A Top 10 Emerges From the Fog
summary: What a wild night at Radio City Music Hall. Three offensive tackles and three pass-rushers in the first six picks. Two guards in the top 10 for the first time in N.F.L. history. A 5-foot-8 receiver drafted at No. 8 over all. And that was just in the first 90 minutes. Shockingly, Florida State’s EJ Manuel was the first quarterback off the board, going to the Bills at No. 16, and the only quarterback picked in the first round. Buffalo fooled everyone by seemingly feigning interest in Syracuse quarterback Ryan Nassib. Even with a weak quarterback class, that is a big surprise. Apparently those late first-round picks were not as valuable for trade bait as everyone believed.

headline: Clip: 'Inside Llewyn Davis'
summary: Oscar Isaac, Justin Timberlake and Adam Driver perform "Please Mr. Kennedy" in "Inside Llewyn Davis."

headline: 'Downton Abbey' Sets Itself Apart
summary: The Season 2 premiere of ''Downton Abbey'' on PBS on Sunday drew an average of 4.2 million total viewers, a number that would impress even the most cold-hearted dowager. That performance doubled the average prime-time rating for PBS, according to Nielsen data, and the show experienced an 18 percent jump in the 18-to-49-year-old demographic when compared with the typical rating from the first season. It was a quiet night on Monday among the broadcast networks as CBS and Fox ran repeats to avoid direct competition with the title game of the college football Bowl Championship Series on cable. ABC won the night over all, but a new episode of ''The Bachelor'' hit a series low in the 18-to-49 demographic and dropped slightly in total viewers, to 7.2 million from the 7.7 million who watched last week's premiere episode.

headline: Paid Notice: Deaths RACIES, LAWRENCE

Father of Robin Hammond, Lawrence, and Phillip Racies, grandfather of nine, uncle to three nieces and a nephew. Left the University of New Hampshire to go on the road with comedian Red Skelton.
